PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Education

To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens, teachers and parents working in and for the interests of the pupils in government schools and colleges throughout Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. We deplore the unprincipled and self-interested attacks being orchestrated by minority sects and groups against the policies and person of the Commonwealth Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, the Hon. Senator Susan Ryan.
2. We fully support the Federal Government's actions in reducing funds for the wealthiest private schools, and in breaking the nexus between government and non -government school costs.

3. We endorse the Federal Government's principled opposition to the provision of 'base grants' to all non-government schools, as a positive step towards fulfilling their commitment of primary obligation to Australia's government schools.

4. We call upon the Federal Government however to recognise that its failure to create an adequate general recurrent resource base for government schools through providing increased recurrent grants, will undermine its own special programs and thus frustrate its own stated educational objectives of greater equity and participation.

5. We support the Federal Government's stated policy of entering into direct negotiations for joint agreements on these grants with State/Territory Governments, to ensure a planned programme of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Childs (from 218 citizens), Robertson (from 188 citizens) and Zakharov (from 10 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition from parents representing the government schools in New South Wales respectfully showeth that:
1. They call on the Federal Government to re-affirm publicly that its primary obligation is to government schools.
2. They support the Federal Government's policy decision which have reduced funding to wealthy private schools and which have broken the nexus between government and non-government school costs.
3. They endorse the Federal Government's opposition to the provision of a 'base grant' to all non-government schools.
4. They ask that the Federal Government create a general recurrent resource base which is adequate for government schools through the provision of increased recurrent funding.

5. They call upon the Federal Government to negotiate agreements with State/ Territory Governments which will ensure a planned program of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Ryan (from 367 citizens) and Scott (from five citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to undermine civil liberties and religious freedom.
It could also be a means of undermining the traditional family structure of our nation.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
should delay the Bill and ask:
That the Government set up a Joint Parliamentary Committee to examine:
(a) the implications of the U.N. Covenant for public policy, the extent of Australian commitments, responsibilities and accountability in terms of the Covenant;
(b) the full effects of the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 for public policy in giving effect to the U.N. Convention.
The Terms of Reference of the Joint Parliamentary Committee to be widely publicised and oral and written submissions sought from the interested organisations and individuals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain elected representatives and officers of local governments in Australia shows that
General revenue grants to Local Government under personal income tax sharing entitlements have increased by 8.2 per cent in 1983-84 over 1982-83,
The inflation rate over the same period was 11.2 per cent,
The increase in grants to State governments over the same period was 11.8 per cent,
Increased demands are being made on local government authorities to participate in Federal Government programs e.g. Community Employment Program,
The Labor Party made a pre-election commitment to allocate not less than the real value of the previous year's allocation in general revenue grants to Local Government.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government will amend the local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act of 1976, to provide a real term minimum guarantee to local government general revenue sharing arrangements in 1983-84, and in future years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Archer (from eight citizens), Jessop (from 54 citizens), Teague ( from 19 citizens) and Watson (from 29 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Wynyard Airport, Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Tasmania shows:
(a) We are shocked and disappointed at the Federal Government's decision not to upgrade the Wynyard Airport.
(b) This decision will inevitably lead to downgrading and closure of the Wynyard Airport.
(c) Closure of Wynyard Airport will cause grave hardship and inconvenience to the people of the North West and West Coast regions of Tasmania.
(d) We urge the Federal Government to immediately reverse this disastrous decision.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Archer (from 56 citizens), Walters (from 154 citizens) and Watson ( from 660 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Subsidy for Student Colleges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the reduction in the subsidy to tertiary student residential colleges of twenty-five per cent announced in the Federal Budget will:
1. Increase the financial hardship already being experienced by Australian students.

The cut in subsidies to colleges will undoubtedly increase fees for that accommodation in 1984. Many students will be forced out of tertiary education as they will not be able to meet these increased costs particularly as the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme only gained a maximum increase of $2.80 per week in the Federal Budget.
2. Decrease access to education for country students

Many country students live in college accommodation either to attend tertiary institutions in the metropolitan area or in regional centres. The cut in the subsidy to residential colleges will even further disadvantage this group of students who already have comparatively low participation rates in tertiary education.
Your petitioners therefore call upon Senate to ensure:
(1) That the full subsidy to student college accommodation is immediately restored.
(2) That the Federal Government assume financial responsibility for all student college accommodation to prevent the planned closure of colleges in Victoria.
(3) That two student representatives are appointed to the committee of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission reviewing student housing.

(4) That new forms of college accommodation are investigated which would be more appropriate to the needs of the current student population, i.e. accommodation appropriate for students with dependant children.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 could be used to support the provision by the Commonwealth Government of funding, counselling, etc., for deliberately procured abortions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled.
Should amend the Sex Discrimination Bill so as to prevent it from being used in support of deliberately procured abortions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Bjelke-Petersen (from 127 citizens) and Jessop (from 15 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That, with the exception of the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches:
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Colston (from 41 citizens) and Zakharov (from 147 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally-funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Local Government: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in November 1978 more than sixty two per cent of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory in a referendum rejected the introduction of territorial government or local government in the Australian Capital Territory.

That until the findings of the Commonwealth Grants Commission Inquiry into Australian Capital Territory finances have been made public and there has been a Referendum of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory as to their attitude to territorial or local government.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Government take no further action or legislation in respect of territorial or local government in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Oath of Allegiance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Protest to the proposed change to the Oath of Allegiance in which recognition of God and the Queen would be deleted.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should- Request that the Oath of allegiance remain unchanged.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: -I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate deplores the action of the Attorney-General in misrepresenting the stance of the Australian Democrats on the Constitution Alteration Bills by purporting that support given by the Democrats to allow the people of Australia to vote in a Referendum on changes to the Constitution implies support for a Yes vote on those items.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans for Senator Walsh) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act relating to insurance intermediaries.
Bill presented, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purpose of the Bill is to regulate the activities of life and general insurance brokers and to an extent, life and general insurance agents.

The introduction of this legislation was foreshadowed in a Press release issued by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 17 October 1983 in which he announced the Government's decision to proceed with legislation based on the Law Reform Commission's report (No. 16) of 25 January 1980 on insurance agents and brokers.

I should mention by way of general background that the Commission's report was considered by the former Government but it decided not to proceed with legislation of the kind recommended in the report. However, a private member's Bill based on the Commission's draft Bill was introduced into the Senate in 1981 by Senator Gareth Evans, as shadow Attorney-General. The Bill was passed by the Senate but not by the House of Representatives.

During the election campaign earlier this year the Labor Party said that in government it would give priority to enacting legislation in relation to insurance agents and brokers and insurance contracts of the kind recommended by the Law Reform Commission reports on these two important subjects. I have already introduced a draft Bill, proposed by the Treasurer and me, on insurance contracts.

Similar arrangements to those outlined by me in my second reading speech on the Insurance Contracts Bill, are envisaged in relation to the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Bill. It is the Government's intention to let both Bills lie on the table to enable public submissions to be made on the detailed provisions of the Bills. In addition, the Government proposes to hold consultations with the insurance industry and consumer and other relevant groups before seeking passage of the Bills.
Public submissions in respect of the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Bill 1983 should be sent to the financial institutions division of the Department of the Treasury by no later than 3 February 1984.

The Government will also be seeking consultations with the governments of the States and the Northern Territory with a view to assessing whether a uniform approach in this area of legislation is possible.

In conjunction with the various consultative processes mentioned above, the Government will be undertaking an assessment of the financial and administrative implications of the Bill based on the principle of the Commonwealth obtaining full cost recovery from the industry in respect of the legislation.
A description of the provisions of the Bill is contained in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated to honourable senators for information.

In very general terms, the Bill is aimed at strengthening the financial stability of the insurance industry overall; protecting the insuring public against the negligence or misconduct of an agent or broker; and encouragement of practices consistent with the interests of the insuring public and the maintenance of standards of conduct or, and quality of advice offered by, agents and brokers.
The main provisions will:
Establish the responsibilities of insurers for the conduct of their intermediaries;
determine the arrangements concerning the discharge of financial obligations between an insured and intermediaries;
deal with questions of misrepresentation by insurance intermediaries;
require annual registration of brokers and permit suspension or cancellation of registration;
establish financial controls and requirements for insurers indemnifying brokers in respect of liabilities arising out of or in the course of their business operations; and
establish measures to minimise the risk of compromise of a brokers impartiality .

In considering the regulatory controls which should be imposed on insurance intermediaries the Government has given very careful consideration to the extended credit terms available to many brokers and the practice whereby some brokers invest for lengthy periods and for their own benefit, the premiums and other moneys paid to them by clients.
In keeping with the Law Reform Commission's conclusions, the Bill will require brokers to maintain an 'insurance broking account' and to invest in prescribed securities.

The Government believes, however, that even with these controls there could be adverse implications for stability of the industry and the interests of the insuring public if the period for which brokers may invest clients' moneys remains open-ended. Successive Insurance Commissioners and the Law Reform Commission have been highly critical of the extent of the credit terms generally available to brokers and it is not uncommon for the financial strength of an insurer to be very heavily dependent on the premium moneys held or invested by brokers.

Against this background the Bill contains provisions aimed at placing constraints on the time for which brokers may hold and invest the moneys they receive from clients. In pursuing these controls the Government is mindful that to the extent that the provisions lead to any fall-off in investment income it will be open to brokers to seek adjustments such as increased commissions and fees to cover the costs of their services.

Taking the Bill as a whole, the Government believes that it will make a very worthwhile contribution towards establishing appropriate standards and practices in a relatively unregulated area of the insurance market. Clearly, the Bill will provide increased protection for the insuring public and will complement the supervisory systems already established under the Insurance Act and Life Insurance Act.
I commend the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Bill to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not usual to speak immediately to the second reading of a Bill, and I do not intend to trespass on that practice. However, I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that an important Bill has just been introduced. It is fairly typical with the changed order of business that one starts the day with a bevy of Liberal and National Party senators, a bevy of Australian Democrat senators and few, if any, Government senators. I raise that because there is a certain reluctance on the part of the Opposition to continue to maintain the House if the Government does not take this chamber seriously. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave not granted.
Debate (on motion by Senator Collard) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Gareth Evans) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

As honourable senators will know, following repeal of the Salaries and Wages Pause Act the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission handed down its decision in the National Wage Case. The Commission enunciated Principles of Wage Determination which provide for a 4.3 per cent National Wage adjustment and, in the future the adjustment of wages on a six-monthly basis in line with movements in the Consumer Price Index, unless the Commission is persuaded to the contrary.

In relation to offices which are subject to the Remuneration Tribunals Act, the Government took the view that it would be appropriate to apply the 4.3 per cent salary adjustment to those offices. Accordingly, the Special Minister of State made a submission to the Tribunal on behalf of the Government and on 11 November the Tribunal reported upon, and determined, new rates of remuneration and cost- related travelling allowances for offices within its jurisdiction. Details of the new rates are included in the Tribunal's report which was presented to the Senate on 29 November.

Where the Tribunal has determined new rates of remuneration those rates are immediately payable, with effect from 6 October. In the case of members of the Judiciary, however, the Constitution provides that they shall receive such remuneration as the Parliament may fix. Clause 6 of this bill therefore amends Schedule 3 of the Remuneration and Allowance Act to prescribe increased rates of remuneration contained in the Tribunal's Report No. 2.

Section 66 of the Constitution prescribes, subject to the Parliament otherwise providing, a maximum annual sum for the payment of salaries of Ministers. Clause 8 of the bill increases that annual sum having regard to the ministerial salaries contained in the Tribunal's Report No. 1.

The Bill also makes a minor amendment to the Remuneration Tribunals Act. Where a new office is created the Act as it now stands prevents the Tribunal making a determination in respect of the remuneration of that office until a person is appointed to it. The proposed amendment will enable the Tribunal to make such a determination after an office is created but before an appointment is made to it . I am sure that honourable senators will agree that this is a sensible amendment which will enable potential appointees to an office to know the level of remuneration it will carry.
Further information on the clauses of the Bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated to honourable senators.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Collard) adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received letters from the Leader of the Government, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and the Leader of the Australian Democrats nominating Senators Jack Evans, Georges, Hearn and Scott to be members of the Select Committee on Animal Welfare.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans)-by leave- proposed:

That Senators Jack Evans, Georges, Hearn and Scott, having been duly nominated in accordance with the Resolution of the Senate dated 17 November 1983, be appointed as Members of the Select Committee on Animal Welfare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the motion moved by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). I merely wish to place on record the fact that it is a matter of regret to the Opposition that the Senate did not see fit to support the Opposition's view that the Committee should be a committee of six. I understand that the view taken by the Government and, I think, supported by the Australian Democrats was that the workload of committees was such that to man a committee of six was not appropriate, and that therefore we would restrict it to a committee of four. The disadvantage from the Opposition's point of view is that this meant that we could have only one representative, because the Democrats, who had brought forward the motion for the Select Committee, were also to be represented as part of the four. That means that we were not able to do as we wished, which was to have a representative of the Liberal Party of Australia and a representative of the National Party of Australia on the Committee. Senator Scott will represent the interests of the combined Opposition on that Committee. We wish it to be made clear to the Senate that, if we had had our way, we would have participated on a broader basis.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:

That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to make provisions in relation to the evidence that may be given in certain foreign proceedings, to provide a right of action in Australia in respect of the enforcement outside Australia of certain foreign judgments, and for related purposes.
Bill presented, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave, Mr President, to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of the Bill I am introducing today is to consolidate and expand Australian laws which protect Australian trading interests and policies against the extra-territorial enforcement of foreign laws. I would like to outline, for the benefit of Honourable Senators, the historical and policy context in which the Bill has been prepared and the principal provisions proposed. A detailed description of the provisions of the Bill is contained in the Explanatory Memorandum which has been circulated to Honourable Senators for information.
Existing Commonwealth Legislation

In November 1976 the Parliament enacted the Foreign Proceedings (Prohibition of Certain Evidence) Act. The purpose of that Act was, briefly stated, to enable the Attorney-General to make orders, subject to parliamentary disallowance, to prohibit the production of documents located in Australia and, in certain circumstances, the giving of evidence in foreign proceedings. The Attorney- General could make orders where he was satisfied that the foreign court was exercising jurisdiction contrary to international law or comity or that the imposition of the restrictions specified in the order was desirable for protecting the national interest.

In March 1979 the Parliament enacted the Foreign Antitrust Judgments ( Restriction of Enforcement) Act. That Act, which was confined to foreign antitrust judgments, enabled the Attorney-General to prohibit the enforcement of such judgments on grounds which, whilst not identical, were broadly similar to those enabling the Attorney-General to prohibit the production of evidence under the Foreign Proceedings (Prohibition of Certain Evidence) Act. As in the case of that Act orders of the Attorney-General were subject to parliamentary disallowance. The Attorney-General could also permit the partial enforcement of foreign judgments for a reduced amount specified in the order.
The 1981 ''Recovery Back'' Bill

In June 1981 the former Government introduced the Foreign Antitrust Judgments ( Restriction of Enforcement) Amendment Bill 1981 (which I shall hereafter refer to as the ''Recovery Back Bill''). The Recovery Back Bill would have enabled an Australian defendant to a foreign antitrust judgment, where an order had been made under the Foreign Antitrust Judgments (Restriction of Enforcement) Act, to recover back from the foreign plaintiff any amount which had been recovered under the prohibited judgment in an overseas country in excess of the amount specified.
The former Government did not seek passage of the Recovery Back Bill following the signing of the Antitrust Co-operation Agreement between Australia and the United States on 29 June 1982.
The Antitrust Co-Operation Agreement

The Commonwealth legislative measures that I have referred to above were introduced against the backdrop of the troubled relations between Australia and the United States in relation to the extra-territorial enforcement of U.S. antitrust laws. That legislation was directly occasioned by proceedings in the United States relating to trade in uranium and, more particularly, the Westinghouse suit for private treble damages. Without wishing to go over the entire Westinghouse saga, I would like to point out that the private suit by Westinghouse to recover treble damages from a number of Australian companies, who were among the list of defendants in the proceedings, related to conduct that, although in breach of U.S. antitrust laws, took place outside the United States and in compliance with Australian Government policies for the marketing of uranium.

The deterioration in relations in this area between Australia and the United States had become so serious that the matter was raised in discussions between the President of the United States and the then Australian Prime Minister in June 1981. The outcome of these discussions was a renewed negotiating effort to reach agreement. These efforts were ultimately successful and on 29 June 1982 the Antitrust Co-operation Agreement was signed. The Agreement is designed to provide a framework for the resolution of conflicts which might arise between Australian national interests and policies and the implementation of United States antitrust laws.
In the brief, the Agreement contains the following major provisions:

A requirement for the United States to give Australia prompt and detailed notification of any U.S. Department of Justice or Federal Trade Commission antitrust investigations that might have implications for Australia's national interests.
The option for Australia to notify the United States of any Australian policy that might have implications for U.S. antitrust laws.
Either party may seek consultations after a notification, or on a potential conflict that has come to its notice other than by notification.

Conflicts to be resolved with due regard to each other's sovereignty and to considerations of comity, with parties being prepared to consider modifying policies or modifying or discontinuing antitrust investigations. In the latter case, the United States will give the fullest consideration to activity involving Australian export or marketing measures.

The United States Government will intervene in private antitrust actions to inform the court of the substance and outcome of the consultations, where the matter before the court includes activity that has been the subject of notification and consultations under the Agreement.
Where national interests are not affected, both countries will co-operate in restrictive business practice (antitrust) investigations.
In the event that a conflict cannot be resolved using the mechanisms of the Agreement, both countries can protect their national interests as they see fit.
The Present Position

When the Labor Government came into office in March this year, the general climate between Australia and the United States in relation to the extra- territorial enforcement of U.S. antitrust laws had improved significantly, in no small measure due to the fact that both countries were trying to abide by the spirit and the letter of the Agreement.

The Labor Government has thus been able to formulate its policy on the protection of Australian trading interests and policies against the extra- territorial enforcement of foreign laws in the light of this much improved relationship between the two countries. In reaching its decision to introduce the Bill at this time, the Government has also had regard to my discussions with Government representatives during my visit in June to the United Kingdom and the United States. As I said then to U.S. officials, it is better to introduce protective legislation now, during a period of improved relations, than to leave it until some crisis arrives, and so heighten what would be at that time a public perception of conflict between our two countries. I would anticipate, on the basis of the responses I received in Washington, that the United States Government would understand the need for Australia to have protective legislation.

At this point, I would like to welcome, on behalf of the Government, the report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence on '' Australian-United States' Relations: the Extraterritorial Application of United States' Laws'' which was tabled last week. The Government is pleased to note that one of the Committee's major recommendations was the introduction of legislation to deal with problems arising from the extraterritorial application of foreign laws. The present Bill is consistent with that recommendation.
The essence of the Labor Government's policy in this area, which has already been explained to the United Kingdom and United States Governments, is as follows.

First, in line with the conclusion of the Parliamentary Joint Committee that both countries should seek to implement both the letter and the spirit of the Agreement, the Government reaffirms Australia's commitment to the consultative approach of the Antitrust Co-operation Agreement between Australia and the United States. It is the Government's firm belief that jurisdictional conflicts between the laws and policies of sovereign governments should be resolved if at all possible by consultation and not by unilateral legal or executive action. The Government will advocate this approach vigorously in its dealings with individual foreign countries and in relevant international fora. I note that the Parliamentary Joint Committee recommend that Australia participate actively in international attempts, such as those within the O.E.C.D. and U.N.C.T.A.D., to reach broadly acceptable arrangements to avoid or resolve conflicts in the application of national trading laws.

Secondly, nothwithstanding the protection afforded by the Antitrust Co- operation Agreement, the Government cannot ignore the fact that the underlying jurisdictional threat to Australian sovereignty and to our export and other trading policies still remains. There has been no significant change in U.S. domestic antitrust laws to take account of foreign government interests, and no modification of their wide jurisdictional claims. Article 4.2 of the Agreement recognises that if after consultation, no means of avoiding conflict has been found, each Party ''shall be free to protect its interests as it deems necessary ''.

While articles 4 and 6 of the Agreement also make some progressive steps forward in providing protection against private antitrust proceedings, our central concern remains. That is, private plaintiffs, who account for about 95 per cent of U.S. antitrust actions, are under no obligation to consider the national interests of other countries when they initiate their actions or in the conduct of the case. The U.S Deputy Secretary of State, Mr Kenneth Dam, in a speech earlier this year acknowledged that private treble damages actions are not within government control and as a result are often referred to in this context as ''rogue elephants''. I note that the obligation in the Agreement on the U.S. authorities to intervene in private proceedings is at best a limited and indirect restraint on private plaintiffs and in any event the weight to be given to the U.S. Government's intervention is left to the court to decide.

Thirdly, since Australia first came up against the vexed issue of the extra- territorial enforcement of foreign laws, it has become apparent that the problem goes very much wider than the antitrust field. The serious conflict between the United States and European countries within the Atlantic Alliance over the measures taken by the United States under the U.S. Export Administration Act with regard to the construction of the Soviet gas pipeline has focused attention on the wider implications of the problem of extra-territoriality. As the Parliamentary Joint Committee concluded, a number of important questions relating to the extra-territorial application of U.S. laws such as the Export Administration Act have not been affected or resolved by the signing of the Agreement. The problem can extend into many areas such as companies and securities regulation, banking, commodity futures market regulation, taxation, and laws related to enforcing national security or foreign policy controls over trade.

Accordingly, consistently with the recommendation of the Parliamentary Joint Committee, the Government believes that Australia should have available to it a comprehensive arsenal of defences which it could use as a last resort, should the resolution of conflict through the consultative approach fail. It is unacceptable to the Government that at the present time Australian businesses, unlike their counterparts in countries like the United Kingdom, have inadequate protection against the crippling damages and costs awards that are usually made in foreign antitrust private treble damages suits. Nor have they means of protection against the extra-territorial effect of judicial and executive orders made under other foreign laws which may be inimical to Australia's national interests. I wish to emphasise, however, that in line with the Government's firm belief in the consultative approach in this area, the substantive provisions of the proposed legislation will only operate when activated by an Order made by the Attorney-General.

When in Opposition, the present Government gave broad bi-partisan support to the legislative measures that were introduced by the Fraser Government. The Government in a real sense is completing the task that was begun by the former Government. Indeed, when the former Attorney-General, Senator Durack introduced the Recovery Back Bill he said:

''It is also designed to underline the seriousness with which the Commonwealth Government and the Parliament continues to view this problem. For here, I believe that I express, in a complete sense, a national voice. The two previous Acts were enacted by the Parliament with bipartisan support and, whatever differences in nuance may emerge, the Opposition has been at one with the Government in its concern.''
I would certainly hope for the reasons I have outlined above, that the present Bill will receive the support of the whole Parliament.
Content of Bill
I will briefly mention the major provisions contained in the Bill.
Prohibition of the Giving of Evidence

Division 2 of Part II of the Bill replaces the Foreign Proceedings (Prohibition of Certain Evidence) Act 1976. The purpose of the provisions, like the earlier Act, is to enable the Attorney-General to make orders to prohibit the production of documents located in Australia and, in certain circumstances, the giving of evidence in foreign proceedings. The Attorney-General may make orders where he is satisfied that the making of the order would be desirable for the protection of the national interest. The Attorney-General may also make orders where he is satisfied that the assumption of jurisdiction by the foreign court or the action taken by the foreign authority is contrary to international law or is inconsistent with international comity or international practice.
Enforceability of Judgments Given in Foreign Antitrust Proceedings

Clause 9 of the Bill replaces the Foreign Antitrust Judgments (Restrictions of Enforcement) Act 1979. These provisions, like the earlier Act, which are confined to foreign antitrust judgments, will enable the Attorney-General to prohibit the enforcement of such judgments in whole or in part. This gives the Australian Government the flexibility to respond to the foreign judgment according to the circumstances. Thus, if an adverse decision given against an Australian defendant in U.S. antitrust proceedings appeared to be justified, but the enforcement of a treble damages award in Australia would be contrary to the national interest-the treble damages award may for example threaten the financial stability of the Australian enterprise-then the Attorney-General could allow enforcement in Australia of only the compensatory (non penal) part of the treble damages award. The grounds upon which such orders may be made are broadly similar to those enabling the Attorney-General to prohibit the production of evidence under Division 2 of Part II of the Bill.

The Parliamentary Joint Committee recommended that, along with the earlier legislation, the Government should introduce legislation to enable Australian residents, or those doing business in Australia, to recover back damages enforced against them under a foreign antitrust judgment. This is done in the '' recovery-back'' provisions which are contained in clause 10 of the Bill. This right of action, given to an Australian defendant to recover back damages enforced against that defendant, is given only where the Attorney-General has made an order that a foreign antitrust judgment should not be enforceable in Australia in whole or in part. The right of recovery-back, which is given only to Australian defendants as set out in sub-clause 10 (4) of the Bill, is for any amount obtained by the foreign plaintiff from the Australian defendant in excess of the amount specified in the Attorney-General's order. The ''recovery back'' provisions are based on the provisions contained in the 1981 Recovery Back Bill although they have been refined to avoid the complexity of the earlier Bill. A series of examples illustrating the operation of the recovery-back provisions is contained in the Explanatory Memorandum.

In line with the recommendation of the Parliamentary Joint Committee that Australian defendants should be able to recover the costs of defending a foreign antitrust action, clause 11 of the Bill gives a right to an Australian defendant (including an Australian statutory authority) to recover reasonable costs and expenses incurred by it in defending private antitrust proceedings. This right of action is severely restricted--

(a) it is conditional upon an order being made by the Attorney-General either on national interest grounds or on the ground that the assumption of jurisdiction or the manner of exercise of jurisdiction by the foreign court or the exercise of power or the manner of exercise of power by the foreign court, was contrary to international law or inconsistent with international comity or international practice;

(b) it is confined to private proceedings for multiple damages where it is possible for the foreign court to assume jurisdiction simply upon there being an adverse effect on that country's trade or commerce; and
(c) it is further restricted to foreign proceedings where a successful defendant is not entitled to recover costs. This is peculiar to private antitrust proceedings in the United States.
Clause 11 of the Bill can be justified on three grounds:

An Australian defendant with no physical tie with the territorial jurisdiction of the United States can be put to considerable expense because s.12 of the U.S. Clayton Act (which provides for service on a corporation wherever found) enables a United States plaintiff to draw the Australian defendant into United States antitrust litigation.

United States antitrust law does not allow a successful defendant his costs. This, when coupled with the widespread use of contingency fees, encourages United States plaintiffs to bring specious actions in the hope that the huge costs burden alone will compel the defendant to settle out of court.
The costs burden in large United States antitrust cases is of a magnitude unknown to our legal system and it is not uncommon for costs to amount to millions of dollars.

I should also mention that for both recovery-back and recovery of costs, orders would not in general be made where conduct, in respect of which a foreign judgment was given, took place entirely within a foreign country. We cannot discount, however, the possibility that situations may arise where it would be appropriate for an order to be made where conduct did take place entirely within a foreign country. An example would be where the costs or damages awarded in a private suit against an Australian defendant were considered to be so high as to be contrary to the national interest, e.g. they might threaten the solvency of an Australian company, with consequences for the enterprise in which it was engaged and for the employment of Australian workers.

Clause 12 of the Bill provides for the enforcement of a ''recovery-back'' judgment on a reciprocal basis after agreement with countries that have '' recovery-back'' provisions that correspond with those in the Bill. The United Kingdom has shown considerable interest in developing the concept of reciprocal enforcement with Australia and has made provision for such a system in Section 7 of the Protection of Trading Interests Act 1980 (U.K.). The Parliamentary Joint Committee recommended that consideration be given to reciprocal enforcement of recovery-back judgments, only if Australian interests are further threatened or damaged by foreign laws. The Government considers it prudent, however, to deal comprehensively with the problem of extraterritoriality, rather than to introduce additional legislative proposals at a later stage if Australian interests should come under active threat from foreign laws. In this way, we avoid heightening what I said earlier would be a public perception of conflict between Australia and the foreign country.

The Parliamentary Joint Committee recommended that the legislation should prohibit compliance by Australian residents or those doing business in Australia with orders of a foreign country which might damage Australia's trading interests. This is dealt with by clauses 13 and 14 of the Bill. Clause 13 is concerned with foreign executive orders, and clause 14 with foreign judicial orders.
Actions and Decisions of Foreign Governments Affecting Australia

The purpose of Clause 13 of the Bill is to counteract the problem created by foreign laws relating to trade or commerce that would enable foreign governments or their agencies to impose obligations upon persons or corporations in Australia. Clause 13 of the Bill will enable the Attorney-General to make an order prohibiting the performance of the obligation where he is satisfied that the act or decision of the foreign government or agency would or might adversely affect the national interest. The topical example of such a foreign law is the U .S. Export Administration Act. A provision similar to this clause (s.1 of the U. K. Protection of Trading Interests Act 1980) enabled the United Kingdom Government to counter U.S. executive orders which were directed at U.K. companies with the purpose of blocking the construction of the Siberian Gas Pipeline, contrary to the national interests of the United Kingdom and the other European States.
Prohibition on Giving Effect to Certain Foreign Judgments

The purpose of clause 14 of the Bill is to enable the Attorney-General to block judgments or injunctions of a foreign court (but not money judgments) where the object of the judgment is to require the doing of an act or thing in Australia, or to prohibit the doing of such an act or thing, or to require a person to refrain from conduct in Australia. The Attorney-General may make an order based on national interest grounds similar to those in clause 13 of the Bill. Possible instances where this clause could be called into operation could include divestiture orders and 'cease and desist' orders made under U.S. antitrust laws.
Miscellaneous

Part V of the Bill contains general provisions relating to parliamentary disallowance of orders and instruments made under the Act, jurisdiction of the Federal Court, service of notice of orders, offences and regulations.
Financial Impact Statement
The Bill will not necessitate any increase in the existing staff establishment of my Department and will have no impact on Government revenues.
The Government will not be seeking passage of the Bill in the present Sittings unless any unforseen developments arise.
The Government commends the Foreign Proceedings (Excess of Jurisdiction) Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Collard) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of amendments to this clause that have been circulated by me, by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and by the Australian Democrats. They all deal with the same issue , namely, the provisions which enable the regulations providing for ballot papers at referendums, as they relate to absent voters, section votes, postal votes and so on, to be subject to modifications made by the Chief Australian Electoral Officer. The Opposition's amendments seek simply to delete the right of the Chief Australian Electoral Officer to modify those provisions. They tie in with subsequent amendments that will be made to provide for the form of ballot papers to be amended and so on. The point I wish to make is that I think it would be more appropriate if I moved these amendments first to get the issue determined because I think the amendments of the Government and of the Democrats simply provide for another form of words relating to the power of the Chief Australian Electoral Officer.

—If I understand what is being proposed, Senator Durack wants to proceed with his amendment to leave it out entirely at this stage; or does he want to seek leave to bring together and debate as a whole all of his subsequent amendments dealing with the same topic?
—I was suggesting that it would be more appropriate if we dealt with the Opposition amendments first because, if they failed, it would be appropriate to deal with the modification of the words.
—Certainly, I accept that. Does Senator Durack not want to deal with other than the amendments to clause 4 at this stage?
—I think it would be suitable to deal also with similar amendments which deal with modifications to clause 9.

—The matter can be tested by reference to clause 4. Perhaps in the debate Senator Durack can refer to the subsequent clauses, so that he is putting the whole proposal as one, and we can debate it in those terms even though formally considering only clause 4.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-That agreed, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 3, clause 4, paragraph (f), proposed paragraph 4 (2) (ga), lines 40 and 41, leave out ', subject to any modifications made by the Chief Australian Electoral Officer,'.

(2) Pages 3 and 4, clause 4, paragraph (f), proposed paragraph 4 (2) (gb), line 46 (page 3) to line 1 (page 4), leave out ', subject to any modifications made by the Chief Australian Electoral Officer,'.

As I have already indicated, the amendments are for the purpose of removing the power of the Chief Australian Electoral Officer to modify the ballot papers for a referendum which this Bill provides may be held in the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory. The object is simply to remove that discretion. The Opposition believes that the form of the ballot papers should be determined preferably by Parliament, although some regulations may be required and have been made. If there should be any changes in the ballot papers, they should be made by the Parliament, or by an instrument which is disallowable by the Parliament, and should not simply be at the discretion of the Chief Australian Electoral Officer.

I understand that the proposal is to give the Chief Electoral Officer the power to modify ballot papers so that they can be made appropriate for the Territories . In other words, where there is a reference to the States there ought also be a reference to the Territories. As I said, I have other amendments to freeze the forms of the ballot papers in Forms C and D. Those amendments will take account of the new situation of the Territorians having the right to vote. The ballot paper will refer to the appropriate State or Territory. As a result of those amendments there will not be any problem, which I believe this provision which we are seeking to leave out was designed to achieve. I do not put this amendment simply as a consequential amendment. The Opposition intended, at all times, to remove the power of the Chief Electoral Officer which is unreviewable by the Parliament. We believe it is not a correct principle for this Parliament to adopt. That is the reason we are seeking its deletion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Australian Democrats will not be supporting the Opposition's amendments in this regard. If one looks at the actual clause, we are referring only to very formal but very minor types of changes to the ballot papers. I think the foreshadowed amendments that I put forward simply cover the matter without any further complications. However, since we circulated our amendments, the Government has circulated amendments in relation to this issue. We are happy to accept the Government's amendments. They essentially have the same effect as the amendments which I originally proposed. I think there is no undue delegation with the insertion of the words that the Government intends adding. The Chief Australian Electoral Officer is very tightly circumscribed in what he is able to do and, indeed, he would be able to change it only in a very limited and very formal way. I do not believe it is necessary to go to the point of actually having regulations on this issue which may, in themselves, be very complicated due to the fact that when one wants to change something simply from 'Territory' to 'State' it seems that the draftsmen get overly excited and cover pages and pages.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we have not had any case and neither would I believe there would be any case that the Chief Australian Electoral Officer would seek, in any way to exceed any powers granted to him under this provision, providing it is circumscribed in the way that either the Democrats' amendments or the Government 's amendments suggest. I think that would be sufficient to pick up the problem raised by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will oppose the amendments proposed by Senator Durack, not with any great passion because, in a sense, this debate, at the moment, is wholly academic given the Government's intention, which I understand will be supported elsewhere, to prescribe in the legislation the form of the ballot papers to be used in the forthcoming 25 February referendum. All that is involved now in the consideration of this clause is a debate about some hypothetical future referendum and the laws that will govern the form of the ballot paper in such a future referendum. The Government's position in relation to any such future referendum is that it would prefer to leave the existing legislation as it is, that is, conferring a capacity in the Parliament to allow, in turn, regulations to be produced prescribing the form of the ballot paper rather than necessarily having to adopt, as part of the legislation, the ballot paper in each case. To that end we want to have a legislative scheme which is a fair and workable one and one that accommodates the concerns expressed about such a scheme by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government will wish to proceed with its own amendments to these clauses which proceed on the assumption that ballot papers may be prescribed by regulation but ensures that there is no excessive delegation of too wide a discretion in that prescription process. In a sense, as I say, the debate is an artificial and an academic one because it is the Government's intention next year to consolidate this legislation governing the conduct of referendums in a single new, streamlined piece of legislation which we will be debating again.

The legislation is in rather a muddle at the moment, full of transitional provisions which are consequential upon the recent passage of further amendments to the mainstream electoral legislation. It does badly need to be tidied up and sorted out, and I suggest that the occasion of that exercise next year would be a more appropriate time to debate the larger question as to whether for all future referendums the ballot papers should be individually prescribed in legislation specifically designed for those referendums or whether, rather, we should have a general scheme of the kind that is now proposed in different ways by both the Government and the Opposition.

The only further point I make is that the Government's approach to this-which is to delete entirely references to regulations and to make provision for a permanent floating form of legislative ballot paper, the terms of which are set out, or circumscribed, by enactment itself-may be a legitimate way to proceed, and I believe we can debate that further next year. The only difficulty I see in the way of immediately adopting, for the purposes of some hypothetical future, the Opposition's proposals is that I believe they are probably unreasonably narrow to the extent that the form proposed would require the full title of the proposed legislation to be set out in the terms of each question.

One of the difficulties we feel, which indeed justifies our approach to the exercise this time round, is that being required to set out the full long title of a Bill, with all the mumbo-jumbo that is necessarily involved in that, does create an unnecessary obstacle to understanding on the part of the voters in the polling booth. While it may well be appropriate next year to debate this in terms of setting out some general legislative prescription of the form that Senator Durack proposes, I believe that there is room for further debate as to what that particular legislative model should contain. It is really on the basis of considerations such as that rather than on the basis of any more fundamental principle that the Government opposes the Opposition's proposal at this stage and will similarly oppose the further amendments that Senator Durack has foreshadowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think it is good enough for this Parliament to determine what it thinks ought to be done at this stage, given the fact that, according to the Attorney-General, there will be amending legislation next year. We do not know what that will necessarily contain. We do not know whether the Government will still be of the same view next year; it seems quite often to change its views about what legislation it will have in the constitutional area. As amendments to this important legislation, the Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Act, are before us we ought to deal for the future, with the question in principle as we see it at this time. It is true that amendments will be moved later by the Attorney-General in respect of the forthcoming referendum. At this stage of the Committee debate we do not know whether they will be passed, but even if they are passed they leave open for all future referendums the position of Australian Capital Territory and Northern Territory ballot papers.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, I believe it is the business, responsibility and duty of this place to decide what is the appropriate law which should apply in all future referendums regardless of what we do specifically in relation to the forthcoming referendum. We should be doing it now, while the matter is before us, and not accepting some statement by the Attorney-General that the Government intends to bring in amending legislation next year to cover future referendums other than the forthcoming one. As I have said, the Opposition will be moving a series of amendments which make it unnecessary for this discretion of the Chief Australian Electoral Officer to be included.

Senator Macklin has spoken to the amendments and indicated his objection to them. I draw his attention to Opposition amendment No. 10 which does set out a form of the ballot paper providing for the insertion of the State or Territory. By that amendment we are bringing the ballot papers up to date. The ballot papers will then be quite applicable to the new situation provided by the passage of this Bill in respect of ballot papers to be issued in the Territories and for Territorians to vote.

The only purpose of this provision in the Bill seems to me to be due to the fact that the existing ballot papers in the schedule do not provide for the insertion of the name of a Territory, obviously because there was no voting in the Territories. We believe that it is proper that the Act should set out the form of the ballot paper and should not be subject to modification by the Chief Electoral Officer. So I persist with the amendments Nos (1) and (2) but draw the Committee's attention to the fact that they are part of a scheme of amendments. We have not yet dealt with the others. I think the decision in relation to these should be made in relation to the whole scheme of the Opposition's amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, we have reached a ridiculous stage where we are now passing legislation for each referendum. Surely we are not going to have the situation where the government of the day, whichever party it happens to be, which wants to alter the Constitution is going to be able to set out a ballot paper without any consultation with those opposing it in words that it chooses and really rigs the ballot paper, because this is what the Government is doing on this occasion. It is referring to its description of simultaneous elections and it is referring to its description of all the other questions that are being put.
—That is not the right clause. You are on the wrong clause.

—I am not, because I am speaking to our amendment which does away with that and which would allow the ballot paper to continue in its normal form, in the way it has been ever since we have held referendums. Now if we do not go back to using that particular ballot paper which enables the legislation to apply to any referendum, no matter when it occurs or what it refers to, we will have this situation that we are facing at the moment-legislation being passed for a particular referendum. As I have just said, we are going to end up with legislation that is being rigged by the Government to suit its particular interpretation of what the constitutional alterations will say.

SPEECH.PARA: I appeal to the Australian Democrats to look at the old ballot papers. They have served us well ever since we have had referendums. Senator Evans shakes his head because he has not won on the simultaneous elections referendum; so he says the ballot paper has not served us as well as it should have. But the point is that we have used this particular form of ballot paper. The Australian Electoral Office distributes to every letter-box the cases both for and against the referendum proposals. People, in the quiet of their homes, are able to read what the simultaneous elections proposal means and what alterations to parliamentary terms entail. The ballot paper does not have to have the description on it. The voters can go into the booths knowing what the referendum is about because they have all received pamphlets in their letter-boxes. I believe that if we allow any government, no matter what its political persuasion, to put its own interpretation on constitutional alterations, we are really entering a whole new ball game.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many Australians out of 10 would you believe would go to the ballot box that well informed?
—I would say that, by the time the $1.25m has been spent on advertising the Yes case, they will certainly know what that is all about.
—That is not what I asked. I am serious.

—I know the honourable senator is and that is why I am treating it seriously. Even if they do not read all the literature that will be put in their letter boxes-and as the honourable senator well knows, there will be quite a bit-they will have read at least the first page.
—If.

—Okay; I think the majority of Australians will read the first page. The rest of the information will be provided through television. I am serious when I say that there is no way that the referendum is not going to be fought, and fought quite hard, when an amount of $1.25m is to be spent. We know that the Government has already arranged for kits to be put out for the Yes case . It has already spent a lot of money. I ask Senator Button to allow Senator Chipp to hear my answer to the question he asked me.
—Senator Walters, this is not Question Time.
—I am not suggesting that it is, Mr Temporary Chairman.
—Senator Walters, will you direct your remarks through the Chair.
—I am not suggesting it is Question Time, Mr Temporary Chairman, but I am objecting to Senator Button taking Senator Chipp's attention away when I am answering one of his-
—Senator Walters, I am objecting to you directing your remarks other than through the Chair. Will you please continue.
—I am directing my remarks to you and I am saying to you that I object to Senator Button taking Senator Chipp's attention away from the answer I am giving in response to one of his interjections.
—Well, that is of great import to this Bill.
—Mr Temporary Chairman-
—He is all ears now.

—Yes, he is. Mr Temporary Chairman, as I said, I believe the public will be well informed because even if they do not read what is put in their letter boxes the arguments will at least be put very clearly and on numerous occasions on television. As we know, no-one can escape the media. Therefore, both sides will be put. The No case, which will also be financed with public money, will also be supported by the Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe it is terribly dangerous for the government of the day to put its interpretation on the question of constitutional alteration. Such an approach opens up a Pandora's box and does away with the democratic aspect of referendums . I appeal to the Democrats to let us get back to the old ballot paper system under which I believe the situation is put very clearly.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Australian Democrats have been appealed to I presume in regard to the Opposition's amendment. However, listening to Senator Walters, I was unable actually to work out what her appeal had to do with the amendment before the Committee. The Government will not be given any power as a result of this legislation. This clause is concerned with the Chief Electoral Officer. An appeal has been made to us to get back to the old ballot paper. I think it is useful to note that the old ballot paper did not contain information of the sort referred to by Senator Walters. For the first time the people of the Territories will have the right to vote in a referendum. What we are on about in this clause is to enable the old ballot paper to be changed so that it can be used in the Territories. I am sorry, but I did not quite follow the appeal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macklin, I have subsequent amendments relating to changing the form of ballot papers which include the name of the State or Territory. As far as I can see, that is the only reason why the Chief Electoral Officer should be given the power to modify the existing ballot paper.
—The Government has that in its amendment as well. So we probably don't even need this clause.

The amendments do make it clear that if we are retaining the capacity to prescribe ballot papers, albeit not for the purpose of the forthcoming referendum, to meet the points raised by the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills and the concern of many honourable senators, the Bill ought to be more tightly written to ensure that the only kinds of modifications that can be made by the Chief Australian Electoral Officer are those necessary for the technical purposes of adjusting the form of the ballot paper for the particular jurisdiction in which it is couched. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Page 4, after clause 5, add the following new clause:
'5A. Section 6A of the Principal Act is amended-
(a) by inserting ''in the English language'' after ''pamphlet'' in sub-section (1); and
(b) by adding after sub-section (2) the following sub-section:

''(3) The Chief Australian Electoral Officer shall cause the text of the pamphlet referred to in this section to be translated into such languages as are prescribed, and shall cause copies of those translations to be printed and to be made available in such quantities and at such places as are prescribed.''.'.

The amendment looks at an issue that I believe it is important to address if we are looking at change in the Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Bill. I refer to the problem that I raised in my second reading speech confronting the ethnic communities. We have sought here to cause the Chief Australian Electoral Officer to pay attention to the dominant ethnic languages in Australia and to make provision for the booklet with the Yes and No cases to be printed in the dominant ethnic languages and provided at appropriate places. Our suggestion has been that these could very well be the post offices around Australia. There could be a differentiation in relation to the dominant ethnic groups without particular areas of Australia, rather than seeking an across the board operation . The point I make-it has been raised with me by a number of ethnic communities- is that the items in the Constitution are of a technical nature and that, while one may have a reasonable grasp of the second language, that grasp sometimes fails when one moves into an area where the vocabulary is specialised and the concept is technical. I think this is one such area and I am quite sure that the ability of many of our new citizens to engage in the full democratic process in Australia will be greatly enhanced by making provision for those booklets to be provided in a manner which will allow those citizens to understand the complexities of the changes to the Constitution that are needed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has quite a profound sympathy for the intent behind this particular amendment but regrets that it finds itself, for essentially practical reasons, unable to accept it. The problem is essentially a logistical one. First, the time constraints are very narrow between when the Yes and No cases have to be completed and submitted to the Chief Electoral Officer and when they have to be printed up and got out to electors. I am instructed that it is very difficult indeed for the Electoral Office to meet the timetable involved in translating the Yes and No cases after their submission, including getting the translations approved by the proponents of the Yes and No cases respectively, because it will be appreciated that there is a lot of room for argument about the appropriateness of a particular translation and the fairness with which the points are put and the language in which they are expressed.

SPEECH.PARA: Following that, there is the further logistic difficulty of getting the appropriate printing and distribution done. I appreciate that the Australian Democrats have gone out of their way to simplify that by allowing for prescribed locations to be identified. But there is very great difficulty, even so, in working out to the satisfaction of the respective ethnic communities and in a way that will be genuinely useful to the members of those communities, what the best such locations are and what numbers of copies and so on need to be provided at each of those locations in order to satisfy the likely demand. It may be that this is something to which we can give further attention when we have slightly more time to consider all these complexities than we have within the time frame of this referendum.

I have not mentioned the additional cost involved. That, of course, is another consideration but not a decisive one manifestly. What we are proposing to do in relation to this referendum to meet the very valid point of the necessity to communicate with the ethnic communities is to take out advertising through the Australian Electoral Office, not through the Commonwealth, the Special Minister of State (Mr Beazley) or anyone else, in the major ethnic Press and, in that advertising, to set out in some appropriate summary form, approved by the proponents of the Yes and No cases respectively, an account of what the referendum proposals are about and what the arguments are. It is very difficult at this stage to be precise as to how extensive that advertising will be or how rigorous the summaries will need to be in terms of abbreviation because we do not yet know what the length of the No case in particular will be. It could be as long as 10,000 words-2,000 for each of the five proposals. It could be much shorter than that as the Government is proposing its case should be. For those reasons we hope that the Democrats might reconsider whether they will press this particular amendment. The Government will undertake to communicate as best it can to ethnic communities, in the way that I have indicated, what the substance of these referendums is about. The Government undertakes to consider this matter further next year in the course of reconsidering what the longer term future of this framework legislation should be.
