TALK.START.PARA: —I have an amendment-I notice that the Australian Democrats have one in almost indentical terms-to add proposed new clause 5A which will amend section 6A of the principal Act. That section deals with the Yes and No cases. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Page 4, after clause 5, insert the following new clause:
''5A. Section 6A of the Principal Act is amended by adding at the end thereof the following sub-section:
'(3) No monies shall be expended by the Commonwealth in respect of the presentation of the argument in favour of, or the argument against, a proposed law other than in respect of-
(a) the publication of the pamphlet referred to in this section; or
(b) meeting travelling, accommodation or other ordinary expenses of members of the Parliament, including Ministers, that are lawfully payable by the Commonwealth.'.''.

This amendment was foreshadowed by me at some length during the debate on the second reading of the Bill. It relates to the decision of the Government to spend $1 1/4m of taxpayers' money on promoting the referendum campaign, in addition to the distribution of a document setting out the Yes and No case. The document relating to the Yes and No cases will be carefully prepared by the parliamentary proponents for and against the referendum. That document has to be distributed to every elector. It is an even-handed expenditure of public money. It provides, as I have said, for both sides of the argument to be placed before each elector. Some cases are a little on the technical side, a bit detailed, lengthy or whatever, but the fact of the matter is that that is the choice of those who are proposing the Yes case or the No case. As I said, the great virtue of it is that it is even-handed.

But what the Government now proposes to do-for the first time so far as I am aware-is to use further taxpayers' money to promote one side of the argument, namely its case. The Government in this case has initiated these referendums and it will be writing the Yes case. In addition, it wants to spend another $1 1/4m of taxpayers' money to advertise in the media arguments for its Yes case. I believe that is the responsibility of the party in government, not the Government. The Yes campaign and the No campaign, like an election campaign should be conducted by those who are taking a particular line in relation to the referendum or election. The campaign should be conducted and paid for by those who are, in their private capacity, supporting or opposing it.

It should not be the subject of government expenditure, and large government expenditure at that. In view of the fact that the Government is now seeking to spend this money, to establish this most undesirable precedent, the Opposition believes that we should take the opportunity of having this Bill before us to prevent that being done. That is the object of this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats had foreshadowed an amendment but I wish to speak to the Opposition's amendment which is in identical terms to the amendment we foreshadowed. The proposition is to continue the tradition which has been maintained through referendum campaigns that there ought to be even-handedness from the point of view of the moneys expended by the Commonwealth in relation to both the Yes and No cases. The Attorney-General in his response at the second reading stage of the debate canvassed a number of reasons as to why this position ought to be changed. I believe that some of those reasons in terms of logic, if taken into other areas, would produce anomalous results. For example, the Attorney suggested that the Yes case starts behind the No case. I think that must be an undoubted observation. I also draw the Attorney's attention to the fact that governments start behind oppositions in every by-election that has ever been conducted in this country. The Government has won only one, I think, since Federation. Surely we are not suggesting, therefore, that governments ought to expend money on government campaigns in by-elections to get them level. The proposition, if taken into those areas, does not hold up. I suggest that as principals we need to be pretty careful about what we are doing. I think the principle of even-handedness is one we must abide by and hold on to. However, I raise a query with the Opposition about its amendment. It is a matter which I have only just noticed. It relates to the way in which the amendment is drafted. I am worried that if this amendment is carried it could be detrimental to the Australian Electoral Office which is required, under the Act, to commit other expenditures, for example, in relation to newspaper advertisements or to the item we have just been discussing , advertisements in the ethnic Press. The Australian Electoral Office has a whole range of responsibilities in relation to referenda.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps we need to check my point that this amendment does not refer to or in any way preclude any of the other expenditures which are required by the Act. Perhaps this matter can be settled so that we can be assured that each of those items required by the Act, particularly those involving the Electoral Office, will be able to go ahead. The problem we have is a delicate one from the point of view of this place. This chamber undoubtedly has power to pass this amendment . If it does, the Bill will go back to the House of Representatives. In dealing with this item, the House of Representatives can do what it will, but if it does not accept the amendment the Senate must decide what to do when the Bill returns . I think this problem has to be addressed.

This Bill provides the technical means of enfranchising the Territories in relation to referenda. I seek a response from the Attorney to the point I now raise about what will happen if the Bill comes before the Senate a second time and we wish to press this amendment. As a result of what happened yesterday, the Democrats are now much more open-minded about pressing this amendment. My worry is twofold. I am concerned that if we pressed the amendment and the Government failed to accept it we may disfranchise both Territories from voting in referenda.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not us.
—That would be the result of the vote here, so I do not think we are able to shuffle it off quite as easily as that.
—That's blackmail.

—Yes, blackmail has gone on for quite a long while in this Parliament. The other problem that I believe strengthens the hand of the Senate to press the amendment if it is not accepted by the Government is the fact that if this Bill is not passed referenda may very well be held quite unconstitutionally. Legislation has already been passed to give the vote to the people in the Territories. If we fail to give them that right, the people in the Territories may very well take action to have all the referenda thrown out on the basis of their not having the right to vote. If that is the case, I suggest that the Senate has overwhelming control of the situation. We ought to press as firmly as possible to re-establish the status quo in relation to the way in which these campaigns are conducted.

SPEECH.PARA: Other honourable senators might be able to speak more authoritatively than I can, but the Attorney raised an additional point to which I seek a response. He said that the governments of Queensland and Tasmania intended to use public moneys to finance the No case. The Attorney read out a statement from the Premier of Tasmania which in fairly clear and explicit terms committed the Premier to expend public moneys. I question whether the Premier of Tasmania will ever get any public moneys, given the difficulties of his budgetary situation. The Attorney said that the Premier of my State, Queensland, also intended expending public moneys. I have attempted to check this. I have been unable to ascertain whether the Premier has anywhere committed his Government to expend public moneys.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has been around longer than Gray.

—He has indeed. The Attorney said that the Premier had committed public moneys for that purpose. I ask the Attorney where that information came from. As I understand the situation in Queensland, the Premier has indeed said that he will campaign. It is the legitimate right of Premiers to campaign, as it is for every member of this Parliament, to spend public moneys in their campaigns in the normal course of events. That has always been the case and will always be the case. Indeed, in the second half of the Liberal amendment that right is specifically taken care of. Members of parliament, including Ministers, will go about their normal campaigning activities and will expend public moneys in doing so.
—Commonwealth moneys.
—They are Commonwealth moneys and they will certainly be expending those moneys. It is important to realise that.
—They are Commonwealth members, though.

—In the past, State members have felt that in a change to the Constitution, which is a State and Federal matter, State parliamentarians have as much right to engage in campaigning as have Federal members. It is a compact.
—But the amendment relates only to Commonwealth members.

—The amendment relates only to something over which this Parliament has control; that is, the Federal members of parliament. It explicitly excludes those members of parliament who should be able to engage in such activities. Therefore, I think that the Opposition would accept, as do the Democrats, that it is a legitimate right of State parliamentarians also to engage in campaigning and to use whatever public finance is available to them. The only objection that the Democrats have is to the additional funds which the Government intends to use exclusively for the Yes case. We would be much more relaxed about the matter if the Attorney had said that, having expended so much money on holding the campaigns, it was worth while to engage in a television campaign to raise the issues with the members of the public and to do this, as in all other matters, in an even-handed way. I believe there is a good argument for that. The argument that we are to spend a great deal of money and that to spend a little more in elucidating the matter in the new area of communications, television, is a worthwhile one. The proposal, if adopted, would be an advance. We would be relatively relaxed about that matter. However, the Senate has very little power to engage in activities of that kind. If the Attorney wishes to come forward with some type of amendment, I am quite happy at this stage to adjourn this matter to see whether the Government can come up with a proposition which will enable an even-handed way of dealing with the matter to be adopted, so that television may be incorporated into the promotion of both the Yes case and the No case. I think that is a legitimate policy decision that governments are quite entitled to make. If this Government makes that decision, I do not see any opposition coming from the Democrats. Given the issues that I have raised, we would be inclined to believe that this matter must be pressed, and pressed vigorously, so that we do not have a breakdown of the even-handed way in which referenda funding has been treated in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will stick to its guns on this matter and will continue to resist equally vigorously the particular amendment that is now proposed, to the point, if necessary, of bringing the matter back to the Senate later in the week or next week, as Senator Macklin has foreshadowed we might. The reasons that we are proposing to do this are essentially those I set out last night. I do not want to generate yet another round of debate. We had a robust and vigorous debate on this last night and I think the issues have now been pretty well canvassed. For the record , I summarise briefly the Government's position.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point, as Senator Macklin reminded us, is that it is the Government's very strong view that as a matter of historical record and political reality the Yes case, whatever its intrinsic merits or advantages, always starts way behind the eight ball when it comes to the conduct of any referendum campaign.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is because you have always asked the wrong questions.
—We cannot always have asked the wrong questions, Senator. There have been at least eight occasions this century on which the voters have thought that the matters ought to be supported-
—They were the government aberrations, the only occasions on which you have been right.

—I am endeavouring to keep this debate in a low key, relaxed and friendly tone, so I shall not respond to some of the more vigorous interjections that I am now receiving. I simply make the point that No cases, by their very character, tend to be easier to put to the Australian electorate because of the almost inevitable complexity of referendum proposals. The fact is that very rarely do voters approach these things with a familiar set of party reference points to guide them, as they do when going into an ordinary election, and natural apathy or indifference tends to result in a no response unless people are argued out of it. In order to argue them out of it, there is a strong case for saying that there just needs to be a differential amount of resources expended on getting both cases equally into the plane of consciousness of the voter so that he or she can make some kind of reasoned choice between them. One needs to spend additional resources just to get, as it were, the Yes case into the perception of the voter in question. It is really with that object in mind, and nothing more sinister, and in order to get, perhaps, a more even-handed approach to the matter, that we are wanting to spend additional resources in this way. I do not think that that is a Jesuitical argument. It is very apparent from the course of history in this country that that is the way the world works.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point I made, which I will repeat, is that a further reason why the Yes case will start behind the eight ball in this instance is that Mr Bjelke- Petersen, on behalf, so he says, of the people of Queensland, and Mr Gray, on behalf of the Tasmanian Government, have both indicated that they will be campaigning very vigorously. In the case of Mr Gray, that commitment has taken a very explicit form-to spend the taxpayers' money in Tasmania. I repeat for the record the exchange that is recorded, certainly in the program the World Today on 5 December and, I suspect, in several other places on that day, in which Mr Gray was asked by the interviewer, Philip Russell:
Will you be spending State money on this?
Mr Gray's answer was: 'We certainly will'. It is true, as Senator Harradine interjected earlier, that Mr Bjelke-Petersen is a little more wily in this respect than his southern colleague.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say 'wily'.

—The honourable senator said that he had been around longer . As such, I do not have any equally explicit and, perhaps, equally naive confession on the public record from Mr Bjelke-Petersen. But what I do have and what we all have are numerous statements, going right back to before there was any talk of a government Yes case advertising expenditure, of Mr Bjelke-Petersen 's intention to campaign vigorously, to wage an election-style campaign against these referendums. The history of Mr Bjelke-Petersen's election-style campaigns in Queensland has been one of a very willing desire on his part to spend Queensland taxpayers' money. Most recently one thinks of the anti-Medicare campaign that was waged, a purely political campaign, by Mr Bjelke-Petersen, in which very large sums of taxpayer's money were expended, and which generated criticism at the time. There have been numerous other instances of departmental advertising being conducted with Minister's photographs on it in a way clearly and palpably designed to generate political support.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Bjelke-Petersen has been around for a long time. He does not have quite the same budgetary constraints as Mr Gray. I have no doubt whatsoever that very substantial moneys will be poured into the campaign through him and through the resources that lie behind him. So that is a further problem. It is my knowledge at present that there will not be similar compensating resources spent by the Labor States. They will be doing some campaigning. There will be some speech- making and certainly some appearances on the media. But there is no intention and no capacity on their part to spend money on television advertising or anything of this kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —How vigorous a campaign?
—They advertised last time.
—What happens if they change their mind? Will you rush back and give us our money?

—If the honourable senator asks me very nicely, I will certainly give proper consideration to that. The third point I make is that the advertising that is here proposed is based around proposals which, although the debate in this place would not make anyone think so, have been the product of a great deal of bipartisan cross-party consensus. There has not been unanimity. Obviously, the voices that have been heard in this debate amply demonstrate that , within the major party opposite. There has been objection--
—You should not judge the extent of opposition just because they may have the loudest voices.

—That is true. But it is the case that the Liberal Party and the National Party, nationally, have supported these proposals. It is also the case that the Australian Democrats have supported their being put to the people. I appreciate the distinction that that does not necessarily involve overt support for them. But certainly these proposals have been, as I keep on saying, the subject of either unanimous or strong majority support at successive meetings of the Australian Constitutional Convention. If that process means anything, if that process is to continue to get the kind of support that honourable senators opposite seem willing to give it, that support at successive Conventions ought to be reflected in a willingness to campaign actively and vigorously to implement the products of those cross-party, cross-government agreements that have been put together so painfully and painstakingly over such a long period. So it is not the case that being put to the people here is something which is a partisan preoccupation of one side of politics, and one side only. As I said yesterday, it may well be less appropriate for government expenditure on advertising of the Yes case to be made in the context of what is manifestly a partisan consideration. The kind of referendum proposals now going forward justify the additional impetus that will be given from additional relatively low key Yes case advertising of the kind proposed.

SPEECH.PARA: My second last point-it is not quite the final point because I have one other in my quiver to direct particularly at the Democrats-is that the amount in question is small. It is something over $1m, and that phases into a degree of insignificance by comparison with the $21m that it seems that the conduct of the referendum will cost us. Of that $21m, $5m will be spent, as I said yesterday, on the production of the Yes/No pamphlet to be distributed to every letter-box in the nation. So there is already $2.5m in that sense being spent on the No case and its distribution and, of course, on the Yes case as well. But the comparative amounts indicate that this is not some massive overkill exercise. It is a supplementation exercise at the margin.

The final point I make, which may have some appeal to the Democrats, is that if the amendment is passed in its current form, it will be quite impossible to initiate the kind of ethnic advertising of which we spoke earlier today, because with the way in which the amendment is couched, no moneys can be spent on the Yes case otherwise than in the context of the formal official Yes case pamphlet. I draw that small consideration to the Democrats' attention in particular. As much as we want to spend that extra money on both Yes and No case advertising, through the ethnic Press, on advertisements to be drafted by the Chief Electoral Officer, we shall not be able to do so if this amendment is passed in its present form.

To repeat, I hope that those arguments will, if not proving sufficient on the day-to-day basis to persuade honourable senators opposite to reject this amendment, at least lodge in the consciousness and be appreciated as a quite genuine and sincere set of arguments which are not designed to generate some partisan ramp but are simply designed to get a better appreciation of what the consensus Yes case, as it has evolved, means in the minds of Australian voters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment, which will guarantee that fairness prevails in the presentation of both of the cases for the referenda. The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) seems to have a bull- headed, paranoid approach to the matter and a determintion to win the Yes case at all costs, or rather, at an excessive cost to the taxpayers. This amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: No moneys shall be expended by the Commonwealth in respect of the presentation of the argument in favour of, or the argument against, a proposed law other than in respect of-
(a) the publication of the pamphlet referred to in this section; or
(b) meeting travelling, accommodation or other ordinary expenses of members of the Parliament, including Ministers, that are lawfully payable by the Commonwealth.

That will guarantee that both cases will be restored to equality as far as the presentation of the cases is concerned. Of course, the Attorney has already appropriated $1.25m from the Advance to the Minister for Finance of the Yes case . Such appropriations from the Advance to the Minister for Finance are supposed to be used for urgent and unforseen purposes. This $1.25m does not come into that category and in my view it is tantamount to a misappropriation of taxpayers ' funds. The Attorney-General says that the Yes case is way behind the eight ball. That may be so but I do not say it is way behind; I say it may be slightly behind the eight ball as far as the constitutional change is concerned. However, it rapidly catches up when one considers the support that is being given, and has already been given unfairly, to the Yes case as opposed to the No case. Added to that, of course, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Government Ministers have extraordinarily large staffs to assist them in the campaign. They have the capacity to travel in VIP aircraft-I have no doubt that that will occur-and they have the advantage of media impact that puts the proponents of the No case at a tremendous disadvantage.

The Attorney criticised the Queensland Premier for stating that he will campaign vigorously for the No case and also he criticised the Premier of Tasmania for making the same statement and offering to co-ordinate the efforts of the smaller States. After all, these States have an incredibly strong interest in the referendum proposals. If Robin Gray did make any undertaking to spend funds within the State to assist the No case, I believe it was brought on because of the miserable attitude of the Attorney-General and the Government in providing funds for the Yes case without equal provision for the No case. I was impressed by Senator Macklin's contribution in this matter.

If the Government is reasonable and fair, it ought to reconsider its attitude and provide equal funding so that the people of Australia can be presented with a No case of equal proportion to the Yes case and be given and equal opportunity to become informed on the matters arising from the referendum proposals so that they can make an intelligent assessment of what is required when they go to vote . Therefore, I think the amendments by the Opposition must be supported and pushed to the extreme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, contradicted himself repeatedly when he was telling us that the Yes case starts so far behind that the Government needs to spend $1.25m to bring it to at least and equal situation with the No case. He also told us that Australian citizens have in the past voted for alterations to the Constitution. No money was spent at that time to bring the Yes case up to equal parity with the No case. Both sides were put equally and the Australian citizens were able to make up their minds on what they were voting for. There was no need for vast sums of money to be spent. Senator Gareth Evans says that $1.25m is not a vast sum of money, that it is very little, just a drop in the ocean, and that we should not be complaining. He said that the House of Representatives would knock it back and that it would come back here. I hope the Attorney will listen as he is wandering around the chamber because I am asking him several questions and I do not want to have to ask him these questions again because he has not heard them. I would be grateful if he could take part in this Committee stage of the Referendum ( Constitution Alteration) Amendment Bill.
—I beg your pardon?
—I knew the Attorney was not listening. It is very difficult when one is asking him questions and he is wandering around the chamber chatting to people.
—I am now alongside you.

—I would like him to listen. He said that the House of Representatives would knock this change back and that he would perhaps bring the matter in again, later in the week or next week. I want to know just when it will be coming in. Is he using intimidatory actions by saying that it will come up next week when the House of Representatives has risen. If we want to send it back, will we then have to bring back the whole of the House of Representatives to Canberra? Is that the sort of intimidation that the Attorney is trying to use . If so, I am quite sure that neither the Australian Democrats nor the Opposition will respond to that sort of intimidation. As I have said, previously money has not been spent on such issues and yet the Australian people have been able to vote for alterations when they think them necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: What will happen in the future? If this proposal gets through, if we set a precedent of governments spending $1.2m or any money on one side of the case, what will happen in the future? Will we see a situation arise, as I indicated earlier in another part of the debate, of the government of the day describing the alterations to the Constitution in its terms, in the way it believes they ought to be described to the people? Will it be open to governments to appropriate any amount of money to push their side of the constitutional alterations so that the people of Australia will be deluged with just one side of the referendum questions? I have grave concern in this regard. I ask the Attorney whether he will answer the question that I have put to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a few words in support of the Opposition's amendment. I really feel that there are two sides to this referendum, the Yes case and the No case. I do not see why the Government should not be even handed about the amount of money that it will use for advertising. This morning I was speaking to the Queensland Premier, whom I know fairly well, and I asked him whether he intends to spend Queensland's money on promoting the No case in the referendum. He said very strongly that he intends to campaign vigorously for the No case. He has been around for a long time, and I say to the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) that he intends to be around for a long time yet, campaigning vigorously in this referendum and also in further State elections. In the last referendum he campaigned very strongly and I was glad that he was successful; certainly, the people voted No. I am sure that he will work hard to make sure that the No case gets up on this occasion. It is quite wrong that the Government can spend $1.25m advertising the Yes campaign but not give the same amount of money in an even handed way to the No campaign.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already expressed to the Senate my very strong opposition to any expenditure of public funds on either case. The Committee is aware of my views on that matter. There are a couple of specific questions which I wish to raise with the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and again, as it was with Senator Walters, it is somewhat difficult. People realise that a lot of things are being done in great haste at the present moment . Nevertheless, there are some specific questions which I wish to direct to the Attorney, now that I have his attention, as to the legality of the proposed expenditure. I ask the Attorney: Has he sought the advice of his Department about the legality of the expenditure? What advice, if any, was received? Is the Attorney aware of attempts made in 1977 to spend public funds on the referendum campaign? The advice given at that stage, I understand, was that it would not be legal to make that expenditure. I understand also that the situation was similar in 1967. I do not know what the advice was in 1974, but I ask the Attorney: Is he aware of that situation? Will he confirm or deny these allegations and, in particular, answer the question on the advice he has received to the present moment?

SPEECH.PARA: I also wish to raise with the Attorney the question of the use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance. The Attorney, when he was an Opposition senator, was on the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations with me when it brought down a series of recommendations about expenditures out of the Advance to the Minister for Finance. In response to those recommendations, the then Minister for Finance, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, made a statement in the Senate on 26 May 1981. Recommendation 1 stated:
Expenditure from the Advance in addition to items already appropriated for, or new items, be permitted only in 'urgent and unforeseen' circumstances.
Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle said:

The Government accepts that the issue of funds from the Advance be on the basis that the contemplated expenditure is deemed to be 'urgent and unforeseen' at the time of preparing the relevant Appropriation Bills and cannot reasonably await the passage of an Appropriation Bill.

His Excellency, the Governor-General, on the occasion of the opening of this Parliament, announced what the Government's policies would be in relation to parliamentary, legal and constitutional reform and said:

A wide range of proposals and legislation designed to enhance the quality of government in Australia and to strengthen the foundations of parliamenary democracy will be submitted for your consideration.

The Governor-General devoted four of the following paragraphs to discussion about proposed constitutional reform. I acknowledge that, at that stage, the Government was talking about a fixed-term parliament and was proposing that funds be expended on fixed-term parliament reform which the Government has not proceeded with. Nevertheless, it is clear that as long ago as 21 April this year , the Government contemplated substantial constitutional alterations. In those circumstances it is my belief that, at the time of the preparation of the Appropriation Bills, the Government must have known that it intended bringing down some constitutional changes along the lines, at least some of them anyway, proposed for this constitutional referendum.

TALK.START.PARA: —So it is not urgent and unforeseen.

—As my colleague Senator Jessop said, so it is not urgent and unforeseen. Therefore I put to the Attorney-General-after all, he is the first law officer of the Commonwealth and so we have difficulty in asking anyone else to advise us-whether it is a fact that, under the proposed expenditure from the Advance to the Minister for Finance, this expenditure cannot be made because the expenditure was not urgent and unforeseen at the time of preparing the relevant Appropriation Bill. I hope I get a proper answer to those questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not wish to and nor can I, in the Committee stage, canvass the matters that were canvassed, as the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) said, during the rather vigorous second reading debate last evening. I raise a couple of matters that have been raised this morning by the Attorney-General. The first matter that he raised in opposition to the amendment now before the Committee was that this amendment was not adequate and not appropriate because it sought to prevent expenditure of funds on the Yes case to the exclusion of the No case but that, in Tasmania, the Premier is proposing to spend Tasmanian taxpayers' money on the No case and not on the Yes case and therefore the evenhanded approach is not being applied there . There are two things about that. First of all, the No committee has not been contacted by Mr Gray in respect of that matter. He went off on his own on that matter and in respect of a number of other matters without consultation with those of us who have the constitutional responsibility to prepare the No case. Of course, he is entitled to do that. It should be borne in mind that the Attorney-General should not use the actions of someone over whom nobody in this chamber has control as an argument against what has been now properly put by the Opposition, by the Australian Democrats and by me that there should be an even handed approach by the Commonwealth in respect of grave constitutional issues that are placed before the people.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point that I wish to reiterate is that that expenditure of money should be even handed and not necessarily carved up in accordance with the numbers of senators and members who voted for the proposition and those who voted against the proposition in this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no record of those numbers; we voted only for having a referendum.

—Yes, exactly, that is true. There is the third reading vote to consider. That will sort out those who are in favour ultimately and those who are against. The point that was made last evening was that the people have proven in the past that they reject almost unanimously proposals that have come from the Parliament. I instance again the nexus proposal and the simultaneous elections proposal. I ask the Attorney-General to take those matters in hand and bear in mind that whatever other people might do outside this Parliament, those actions have been taken without consultation with people involved with the No case and we should not have those problems visited upon us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, without recant and resawing the sawdust, it is a fact that it is quite improper for the Government to fund one side of an argument. It tends, of course, to distort the presentation of the argument and to distort the full force of the arguments on both sides. It will have the effect, of course, of extinguishing and submerging the No case. Already the Government, as it well knows, has a very significant advantage over the small group of dedicated, responsible and highly intelligent members of the No case who will be putting that argument. The Government has the advantage, as has already been pointed out, of VIP aircraft-
—Overnight allowances for their Ministers when they are travelling.

—That is right, high overnight allowances for their Ministers as they travel from State to State in pursuit of Yes votes. Of course the Government recognises that the Prime Minister is able to attract a great deal more media attention than the modest proponents of the No case, so already it is starting with a significant advantage. It would not require $1.25m to put its point of view if it had any confidence in the capacity and ability of the average citizen to understand both sides of the argument.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) says that invariably the Yes case starts behind the eight ball. The facts of the matter are that on the occasions when a sensible proposition which has been in the best interests of all States has been put to the voters, the majority of people in the majority of States has cast votes in favour of the proposal. On the occasions when proposals have been put which could impair and impinge upon the rights of people in the less populous States, the questions have been resolved in the negative. It is a reflection not of the lack of understanding of the people in Western Australia, Tasmania and Queensland that so many proposals have been defeated but more of the fact that they have a very clear understanding of what has been put. It is very much as a result of the type of questions, which invariably seek to centralise power to Canberra and extinguish or dilute the power and capacity of either the Senate, the States House, or the States themselves, that those proposals have been rejected.

Clearly the Government has a great fear, particularly in respect of the simultaneous elections proposal, that it will for the third time be defeated. That proposal has been defeated twice before and on the last occasion it had the support of both the Government and the Opposition. It was only a small band of senators from Queensland, Western Australia and Tasmania that was able to persuade the majority of people in those States that it was not in their best interests to cast a vote in favour of the proposal. Of course the Government fears a repetition of that and so it is hoping on this occasion to snow the community with $1.25m of advertising, plus all the time it knows it will attract on television and radio, and so distort the argument to the point where the No case will not be heard. That will give the clear impression that there is no No case, only a Yes case.

I must say that of all the arguments I have heard put forward in this chamber by the Attorney-General during the time I have been a senator, the one he has put forward in justification of funding one side and not the other has been by far the worst. Even his presentation showed that he tremored with the logic of his own argument. He took up the point made by Senator Macklin in respect of ethnic understanding of the propositions and said that that would not be followed up because of the time frame. I wonder whether he can tell me whether part of the $1.25m is to be spent on 0-28 ethnic television. In fact, there will be some education of those people for the Yes case, but not the No case.

The Government knows that it is breaking all the standard principles and rules and the very fundamental concept which is contained in the Referendum ( Constitution Alteration) Act that there shall be put to the voters of Australia a maximum of 2,000 words of argument for and against each case. That is the extent and the limit of the contribution the Parliament and the Government can make with public funds in respect of presenting arguments. It is clearly intended in the Act that there should be equal space and an equal maximum number of words so as to ensure that the community is getting both points of view. I find it staggering for a Government which has just imposed upon the taxpayers public funding for election campaigns on the argument that there needs to be a clear understanding of the policies, the arguments and the position of all political parties-not only the major parties but also the minor parties-to now put it to us that only one side of the argument ought to be presented at taxpayers' expense.

That seems to fly in the face of the Government's arguments and seems to be contradictory to the fundamental principles enunciated in support of its logic. I think even Sentator Ray, for all his wily twisting and turning in presenting us with his arguments on the electoral Bill, would have tongue in cheek trying to support this sort of argument. Clearly if the Government, as it pretends, were interested in ensuring that the public is aware of all the arguments, it would ensure that funds be made available for both sides. If the Attorney has the same difficulty drafting amendments of that nature as he has had with other amendments recently, the Opposition will be very happy to accommodate him with an amendmnt which will provide equal expenditure for the Yes case and the No case.

I thought I understood the Attorney-General to be saying that if the majority of senators in this chamber choose to persist with this amendment the Bill will be left to lie on the table and voters of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory will be denied, as a result of the Government's action, a vote in the forthcoming referendum. That, to me, is bald, frank and unequivocal blackmail. It is intended to put pressure on the Australian Democrats, particularly, and the Opposition to a lesser extent to cause them to compromise their integrity and their principles for political expediency. Frankly, I am one of those who take the view that in the final analysis that sin will be visited upon the Goverment and nobody else. It will be properly located where it deserves to be because the people in the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory will understand, very quickly, that they are being denied a vote not by the Opposition and the Democrats but by the Government, and they are also being denied an opportunity to have put to them in a reasonably articulate way the aguments on both sides of the coin. I hope that the Democrats have the courage to stick to their principles and not have a weather eye on the politics of this proposal, and are prepared to stay with the amendment they have already proposed.

The consequences of these referendum proposals are such that they will have enormous influence on the less populous States. The simultaneous elections proposal probably will mean more elections and not fewer; it will mean that the independence of the Senate and of senators will be diminished to a great extent and that the smaller States' representation will lose its capacity to have a proper, equal voice. In respect of High Court of Australia advisory opinions, we know that Senator Evans has an ambition to probe the Consitution as far as he possibly can in respect of external affairs powers to see what further power he is able to draw towards Canberra. As Senator Evans looks frustrated that I am starting a discourse on the virtues of the arguments on both sides, I will leave it at that and continue to say that in respect of this amendment I hope that Senator Evans will be a man of principle, not expediency, and will accept it. If he will not, I hope he will accommodate us by at least giving the No case the same money that he is spending on the Yes case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Chairman, I have circulated an amendment to the Opposition's amendment No. (3) seeking to pick up the point raised initially by me and responded to by the Attorney-General. After the word 'section' in Senator Durack's amendment my amendment would add:

SPEECH.PARA: and any translation into other languages which may be authorised and advertised by the Chief Australian Electoral Officer.

The concern that I had in relation to advertising may be affected. I believe that the explanation of the Opposition's amendment, which states that no money shall be expended by the Commonwealth with respect to the presentation of the argument, would not in any way detract from the ability of the Australian Electoral Office to advertise and carry out its other functions that are necessary. I move:
Proposed new clause 5A paragraph 6A (3) (a), after 'section', insert 'and any translation into other languages which may be authorised and advertised by the Chief Australian Electoral Officer'.

I also wish to respond briefly to the point the Attorney-General made in attempting to paint those who were pursuing the even-handed approach as opposing the referenda. I am not opposing all of them. I will be opposing one but I support the majority of those referenda that are to be put to the people. But I believe there is an argument that when something is put to the people it should be done in a fair way so that the proponents win in a fair way. I hope that the majority of those referenda will be won in a fair way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to accept the addition proposed to my amendment by Senator Macklin. I think it is quite appropriate that the Yes and No cases should be translated into other languages and advertised by the Chief Australian Electoral Officer. The matter will be entirely within his hands. This does not come within the principle we are striking at in the amendment I have moved.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (Senator Macklin's) agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concerned that this debate is not following a very logical and consistent line. I think there is a very important matter of principle that needs to be addressed, and that is whether, as I understand it, for the first time this Parliament is going to support financially the putting of one side only of a referendum case in a propaganda campaign. My understanding is that there are already provisions within our Constitution and within our laws to put both sides of the case and to give each side equal opportuity to put its case. Frankly, I would prefer that, if it were possible, no additional propaganda be permitted. In that way we would get a far more logical and reasoned debate in this place and consideration by the people who ultimately have to determine the fate of these referendum proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: I simply ask the Attorney-General whether this is the first time that one side only has been financially funded by the Federal Government. If so, has he considered the dangers that are inherent in setting a precedent such as this for not just this Government but any future government to pick up this particular approach and to build a whole propaganda campaign around only one side of a referendum issue?

TALK.START.PARA: —I realise there are some time constraints which the Attorney-General has put on this matter and I do not want to take up a lot of time. Most of the things that could be said about fairness and so on have been said. But I find it quite amazing that the Government should threaten that the people of the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory might not get a vote. Perhaps when we look at the way the people of the Northern Territory voted last Saturday we will recognise just why it is that the Government might not want those people to vote, but I cannot understand why the Government would not want the people in the Australian Capital Territory to vote on this matter. The important thing, as Senator Jack Evans just said, is that each side should have an equal go and equal support and that if any money is to be spent an equal amount should be given to both sides of the argument. My personal view is that no money should be spent. Following some telephone conversations that I have had today, I would not be at all surprised to see a High Court challenge on this matter of money being spent on the referendums, even if some is given to the No case a well as to the Yes case. Or course I was one of those who voted against all of these referendum proposals, and I will be doing my best to see that they are defeated. But I suggest to the Attorney- General that he should not underestimate the intelligence of the people of this country. They will be asking themselves: 'Why is the Government spending all this money? Why is it going to all the trouble of flying around the place, as no doubt it will, in VIP aircraft and so on? Why will all the Ministers be spending their time on referendums when they should be spending it in attempting to make life in this country better for the very many people who are finding it very difficult at the moment? I suggest that the Government should not underestimate the intelligence of the people, no matter how much money is spent on the referendums. I believe it will cost about $20m-odd to run them. We are now talking about spending a lot more of taxpayers' money-it is not just money that the Government has; it is taxpayers money-on what I call the attempted forcing through of these referendums by subterfuge. We have to remember that absolutely none of them is essential. This Government could continue to run the country without any of these things being put before the people.
—And much more effectively.

—I am very much against giving anyone an eight-year term in Parliament, and that is what one of these referendums will do. They will also make it possible for some of the State governments to impose sales taxes. I have that in writing from the Attorney-General through what he said in this very place. It would be possible, once the relevant referendum is passed, for State governments with certain manoeuvres to impose a State sales tax. I was talking to an American about it and he said: 'You never want to let that kind of thing happen because that is one of the ways governments can easily increase their money.

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. We are running out of time. Senator Townley is really canvassing issues of another debate which are not relevant to this clause, other than to show the importance of the clause, which he has already established.
—There is no point of order.

—Mr Chairman, I do not like this idea of honourable senators saying that we are running out of time. If we are discussing something important in this Parliament I do not care whether we have to sit here until the week after Christmas.
—You are costing $1.25m.

—I do not care how much it is costing to run this Parliament and I do not care whether we have to bring back the House of Representatives, because this to me is very important. The point about all these referendums, as I have said, is that none of them is essential. The Government could get by without them. They will enable all sorts of things to which the public should be alerted. If the Government is going to try to steamroll us by saying that we are running out of time, it might find it really will run out of time and it will not get done some of the things that it wants to get done.
—I do not want to have Christmas dinner with you.

—I do not particularly want to have Christmas dinner with Senator Missen; I am sure we can agree on that matter. I think we have to be suspicious of what this Government is doing. First of all, it increases the numbers of members of parliament and now it is trying to increase the length of time that members are in parliament. Under our present rules, if a senator gets elected once, he will get a pension. How is that for a good idea? I am sure everybody will be standing for Parliament. Anybody who gets an eight-year term--
—Order! Senator Townley, we are discussing proposed new clause 5A. I would like you to keep to that.
—Mr Chairman, I am perhaps going a little longer that I intended to but I was provoked.
—They get a pension after one election.

—They get a pension after being elected once. I am sorry; I am replying to an interjection and I should not do that. The point about pensions is a very important one. Nobody who is elected once should get a pension. Anyway , an eight-year term is too long. I ask the Attorney, if he can, to ensure some even-handedness. I suggest to him that if he does not there will be a High Court case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might briefly reply to the questions that were specifically addressed to me. Senator Lewis asked whether the Government has had any advice as to the legality of expending any moneys other than in the formal Yes-No pamphlet for which the Commonwealth Electoral Act provides. The answer is yes, there was oral advice sought and obtained from the Solicitor-General, Sir Maurice Byers, the substance of which was retailed to me in a departmental minute back in August. That advice was yes, the expenditure could legally be made.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the second question from Senator Lewis about the Advance to the Minister for Finance, I am well aware of the constraints that apply in relation to that as to 'urgent and unforeseen' circumstances and the rest of the variable terminology that has been applied over the years. The situation simply is that I am in no doubt that this is legally and technically within the proper scope of the Advance not least because it has been in doubt up until 17 November as to whether or not these Bills would be passed. It was only on that day that they were passed finally in the House of Representatives. There has been doubt about what the content of the referendums would be until well into this Budget session . There has been doubt as to the timing of the referendum itself being on 25 February as distinct from some later period until comparatively recently, all of which substantially postdated the period for the preparation of the Budget in question. This is a perfectly proper and, indeed, routine use of the Advance. I believe that Senator Lewis should accept that explanation.

As to Senator Macklin's point about who is going to the precipice first in terms of what the Constitution provides, the reality is, if Senator Macklin is listening, that in effect it is something of a Mexican stand-off. Section 128, as it is now framed, does, of course, require the territorians to have a vote. However, they cannot in practice have a vote unless the machinery for doing so is provided by legislation. If this machinery legislation is not passed there will, accordingly, be a situation that, firstly, the territorians will not be able to vote and, secondly, the validity of the referendum itself would be put at risk. So if the Australian Democrats insist on pursuing their objections to this, not only will they be denying territorians a vote but also they will be creating a situation where the whole validity of the entire constitutional referendum itself and the value--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is absolute blackmail.
—I am putting a serious point.
—Of course it is.

—I am not debating the merits of it. I am answering a technical question. The merits of their basic endeavour of getting these proposals before the Australian people will also be put at risk. That is the reality of it.
—Absolute blackmail; there is no other word for it.

—We can debate that next week if the situation arises. Finally, Senator Walters asked me about bringing the House of Representatives back. It is very likely that the House of Representatives will be coming back for one day anyway next week. That depends on the fate of quite a bit of other legislation that has to be dealt with in this place in the next two days. Should it become necessary for the House of Representatives to be brought back as a result of further developments in the Senate next week, of course it will be. What we do obviously want to do, and I will be very grateful for the co- operation of honourable senators if they could help in this respect, is to get this Bill passed within the next 20 to 25 minutes.

—I have no intention of holding up the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). The Attorney said in answer to Senator Lewis's question that legal opinion was sought back in August. Why did not the Attorney tell us when the Estimates were being examined that $1.25m or some other amount was to be spent. Obviously last August he decided--
—You did not ask. That is why. If you had I would have.

—During consideration of the estimates of the Department of Social Security I asked on what $53m from the Advance to the Minister for Finance was going to be spent. We were told that $20m was going to be spent in our area. No mention was made at all of any money that was going to be spent on the referendum. I asked the question. Why did not the Attorney have the honesty to tell us before the Appropriation Bills were passed? He knew that he had sought legal opinion back in August and he did not have the decency or honesty to tell the Senate that money was going to be spent on the Yes case only. He knew that the Appropriation Bills would not be passed if he had told us. He says that we did not ask. So much for open government, freedom of information and whatever else the Attorney wears so often on his sleeve. He wears on his sleeve freedom of information and civil liberties. He wears on his sleeve all of these things. Yet, he did not have the decency to say during consideration of the Estimates that he was going to spend this money on the Yes case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In brief answer, I was not specifically asked about referendum campaigns. At that stage, as I recall, the date had not been settled nor had any final decision been made actually to expend any money. That decision was made only recently. There was a question in my mind as to whether, if a decision were made to expend money, in fact that would be legally possible. It was entirely hypothetical at that stage. I do not think the date for the referendum had even been set. There is no attempt to mislead or deceive. I do not think I have ever been in the business of doing that in this Parliament. I regret that Senator Walters chose to put her response in those terms.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is: 'That the proposed clause 5A, as amended, be agreed to'. Those of that opinion say aye.

INTERJECT.PARA: Opposition senators-Aye!

TALK.START.PARA: —Against, say no.
—No!
—I think the ayes have it.
—Mr Chairman, we shall not waste time by dividing on this. However, I want to make it clear that the Government was in fact voting no.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed new clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 6 to 8-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 9 (Forms of ballot-paper).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move amendments Nos (4) to (8), all of which are essentially technical amendments of the same kind as were involved in amendments Nos (2) and (3) which were previously debated. They are essentially hypothetical. They bear no particular relevance to the conduct of this forthcoming referendum because the form of the ballot paper will, I hope, be prescribed in this legislation itself.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a large number of amendments to clause 9. Is it the wish of the Committee that Government amendments Nos (4) to (8) be taken together first?

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Page 5, clause 9, line 27, leave out ''in the case'', substitute ''in a manner necessary for the purposes''.
(5) Page 5, clause 9, lines 38 and 39, leave out ''in the case'', substitute '' in a manner necessary for the purposes''.
(6) Page 5, clause 9, line 41, leave out ''in the case'', substitute ''in a manner necessary for the purposes''.
(7) Page 6, clause 9, line 1, leave out ''in the case'', substitute ''in a manner necessary for the purposes''.
(8) Page 6, clause 9, at the end of the clause add the following paragraph:
'(f) by adding at the end thereof the following sub-section:

''(5) The ballot-papers referred to in sub-sections (1) and (3) may, in a manner necessary for the purposes of voting by Australian Capital Territory or Northern Territory electors, be modified by the Chief Australian Electoral Officer.''.'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been dealing with what are really quite consequential amendments. We have already had the debate on this question. I certainly wish to move the Opposition's amendment No. (4). However, amendments Nos (5), (6) and (7) all were dealt with in the debate that took place earlier on whether the Chief Electoral Officer should have a discretion. The Committee agreed that a discretion should be given but that it should be limited in the way in which the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has moved. Therefore, I propose to withdraw the Opposition's amendments (5), (6) and (7). I will now move amendment No. (4)-
—To which I have no objection, if that helps.
—I am pleased to hear that there is no objection to it. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Page 5, clause 9, before paragraph (a), insert:
'(aa) by omitting from sub-section (1) ''may'' and substituting ''Shall'';'.
This amendment-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is consistent with what we are proposing.
—I think it is.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of amendments to clause 9 which I foreshadowed were consequential upon earlier amendments and, since the matter has been dealt with by the Government's amendments, I will not proceed with them .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The pressures that we are facing in dealing with numerous amendments in such a short time are quite ridiculous. We just have to accept the fact that there is no way in the world that we can do otherwise if this debate is to finish by 12.25 or whatever is the magic hour that we are working to. I did not speak to Opposition amendment No. (4), but Opposition amendments Nos. (4), (8) and (9) are part of a package which is designed to ensure that the ballot papers provided under the Referendum ( Constitution Alteration) Act should be in the form that will be set out in the schedule. I propose moving an additional amendment, to clause 28, to provide for the forms in the schedule. It would be sensible that this debate should have regard to my proposed amendment No. (10) as well, although it is, of course, to a clause that will be dealt with later.
—Your amendment No. (4) has been passed. Do you seek leave to move amendment Nos. (8) and (9) together?
—Yes.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have said. I agreed not to speak on amendment No. (4) because of the pressures that seemed to be brought to bear to hurry on the debate. I now regret that action because it is part of the package and in order to explain my amendments Nos. (8), (9) and indeed (10), when we finally reach it , given the antiquated way in which we seem to deal with amendments in Committee , I need to explain that what we have done by amendment No. (4), although it has been passed, is ensure that the ballot paper that is set out in the schedule to the Act cannot be amended by regulation, or in any other way; that the form of the ballot paper used for referendum purposes should be given statutory force and should be possible of amendment by statutory provision only. That is the purpose of Opposition amendments Nos. (8) and (9), which refer to other provisions of section 14A of the Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Act.

SPEECH.PARA: If my amendments are agreed to, the result will be that there will be a form C for single question referendums and a form D for multiple question referendums. The forms, as I propose to move them in my amendment No. (10), will be those that must be used. They will require that the question upon which people are being asked to vote will set out the long title of the proposed law. That is a very different situation from the one that we have now discovered, namely, that the question on the ballot papers, although set out in forms in the Referendum ( Constitution Alteration) Act, may be amended by regulation. We are well aware of the problem that we now have. The regulations have been made by the Government.

Certainly, further amendments are to be considered by the Committee-whereby the Government is now resiling from relying on those regulations in respect of the forthcoming referendum. It intends to give statutory force, by way of amendment to the Act, to the different questions to be put to the people being other than questions which set out the long title of the proposed law. But the Opposition's view is that the correct principle is that the question should be in the terms of the long title of the proposed law. The reason is that that is the law which has been debated in the Parliament. The whole Parliament has agreed upon the proposed law and on the long title of the proposed law. If there are objections in the Parliament to the nature of the long title-that it is too legalistic for people to understand, is inaccurate or something of the sort-at the Committee stage of the passage of the proposed amendment to the Constitution is the appropriate place to determine what question is to be put to the people. Therefore, this machinery legislation that we are debating, the Referendum ( Constitution Alteration) Amendment Bill, is not an appropriate vehicle, nor are the regulations under it appropriate, for determining the questions that will be put to the people.

The object of the Opposition's amendments is to ensure that the Government may not put through, long after Parliament has discussed the matter and agreed on the questions that are to go to the people, a regulation which provides for different questions to be put on the ballot paper. We regard that as quite wrong . It is an abuse of the Parliament and the legislation should be amended in this way to prevent a repetition in the future of this type of action that the Government has indulged in concerning the forthcoming referendum. This is a quite separate issue from that as to what questions are to be put to the people in the forthcoming referendum. We seek an amendment of the Act for the long term .

The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) says that next year he will bring down legislation to amend the Act. So be it; the fact is that we are dealing with the matter now and ought to be laying down now what we, as a Parliament, consider are the proper procedures to be followed. That is why I move:
(8) Page 6, clause 9, paragraph (d), lines 1 to 3, leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraphs:
'(d) by inserting after sub-section (2B) the following sub-section:
''(2C) The form of the ballot-papers prescribed under sub-section (1A), (2), ( 2A) or (2B) shall comply, as nearly as practicable, with Form C or Form D, as the case may be, in the Schedule.'';
'(da) by omitting from sub-section (3) ''which may be used by any one elector may'' and substituting 'for use by an elector shall'';'
(9) Page 6, clause 9, after paragraph (e), add the following paragraph:
'(f) by omitting sub-section (4).'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a little disappointed that Senator Durack should have chosen to spend 10 minutes debating something which I thought, by agreement, we had already debated in the context of the first amendments dealt with today. We all knew that this was essentially a hypothetical debate. It is not related to the context of the forthcoming referendum. It is simply an argument about what the machinery should be for the future. I made it clear that I was open-minded about what that machinery should be and there will be an opportunity to debate it next year. I thought that we had agreed as a Senate, in the context of the earlier amendments, that, for the moment anyway, in order not to leave the legislation a total mess, we would simply aim at tidying up the existing machinery, which does allow for the form of the ballot paper to be prescribed by regulation. I have believed that that was what we were debating earlier on. I expressed my arguments certainly in my contribution to the earlier debate and I do not propose to repeat them now. I would hope that we could leave the debate in those terms at the moment, on the basis that this matter has already been tested and it really is not something of immediate import. It is something that the Senate will be coming back to next year.

—I wish to make it perfectly clear-I appreciate the time constraints with which the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has asked the Committee to comply and all honourable senators seem to be doing their best to do so-that I support the proposals moved by Senator Durack, notwithstanding the fact that amendments circulated in my name contain other proposals in relation to the questions which apparently are going to be put to the people of the nation on this referendum proposal. I, like Senator Durack, believe that this matter should have been resolved when the Senate debated the constitutional alteration Bills. The long title of the Bills should have been correct. I think it is a great pity that the long title of the Bill relating to so-called simultaneous elections is such a poor title. I cannot see that the Government can escape its liability for giving the Constitution Alteration ( Simultaneous Elections) Bill 1983 that title by saying: 'Mr Fraser's Government did the same thing'. I do not see that that is any answer to it. I think it is a geat pity that we did not correct the long title of the Bill at that stage. Nevertheless, I wish to say that notwithstanding the amendments which have been circulated in my name, I support Senator Durack's proposals. I think it is very important that constitutional alteration legislation in the future be set out specifically so that we know when we are dealing with the long title of a Bill at some future stage that we are in fact at that stage dealing with the question which will be placed before the people.

—I wonder whether the debate at the Committee stage could be adjourned until a later hour this day. I am sure that it would fit in with the plans of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). I see no problem in doing that as far as the rest of the Parliament is concerned. I think it would be a good idea to adjourn the debate now. I feel, as Senator Durack said, that pressure has been put on us. Honourable senators are trying to cut short what they are attempting to say. To me it is an intolerable position. Like Senator Lewis, I have a fall-back position and amendments have been circulated in my name. I support the amendments moved by Senator Durack. I believe that is the line we should be taking. If Senator Durack's amendments are not acceptable only then will I move the amendments circulated in my name.

—In relation to the question of time, I point out that the House of Representatives will get up at 8 o'clock tonight. It would not be possible for any Bill to go across to the House of Representatives without major breaches of the Standing Orders. Standing Orders would have to be suspended, at the very least, to enable this legislation to be dealt with by the House of Representatives tomorrow. This legislation was scheduled originally for debate last Thursday. At the request of the Opposition parties-the request was put to me by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) who said that amendments were in the process of preparation-I agreed on behalf of the Government and after consultation with the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), to have the matter delayed until yesterday, Tuesday, on the basis that the Bill would be passed yesterday, Tuesday. We did not finish the Bill last night for reasons with which we are all familiar. I was told again that the Bill would be dealt with effectively and with dispatch this morning in order to enable it to go to the House of Representatives. Honourable senators know the particular personal constraints that I am under at the moment. I will live with them. I will stay here until 12. 50 p.m. if necessary and arrange for planes to wait and so on. It creates real difficulties for me. If we could possibly dispose of the Bill in the next half hour it really would be consistent with the undertakings that I have been given regularly since last Thursday morning by honourable senators opposite.

—Mr Chairman, through you, I point out to the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) that all honourable senators are seeking to co-operate in the best practical and sensible way they can. It seems to me, taking into account the amendments before the Chair and the foreshadowed amendments, that this Bill will not be passed by 12.50 p.m. I ask the Attorney-General whether, in the event the Bill is dealt with later during the day and the Opposition agrees to the suspension of Standing Orders in the House of Representatives, that creates a problem. Is that the only problem? If Standing Orders could be suspended in the House of Representatives and the matter could be dealt with tomorrow does that cure the problem faced by the Attorney- General?

—I am not sure. I have not been able to check what the situation is in the other House in terms of the legislative log jam. As I understand it the House of Representatives was absolutely dependent on getting the Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Amendment Bill 1983 by lunchtime. I have not yet had word back. The House of Representatives was also expecting the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill 1983 which is the other Bill which involves me. I had understood that we were going to have co-operation in that respect. All the arguments are so familiar to all honourable senators that I think we can deal with the Bill quickly and effectively in the time available if there is co-operation. If there cannot be co-operation a Standing Orders situation will have to be created, but nobody wants to get into that situation in the other House. We want to give the House of Representatives proper notice and proper time.

—I cannot allow to pass the criticisms of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) of honourable senators on this side of the chamber for not having the debate on the Referendum (Constitution Alteration ) Amendment Bill 1983 over and done with by noon today. If the Attorney-General wants co-operation I suggest to him that he stop trying to be the winner in every debate. The truth is that the Government has brought in a whole series of amendments which comprise some six pages. It is a nonsense to say that the Opposition was concerned that it might have to bring in amendments. Of course the Opposition was concerned about amendments because it could see the defects in the Bill. That is the first point I wish to raise. The second point is that the Attorney-General should not say that it is the Opposition's fault in some way or other that this Bill will not be debated in the other place tomorrow. The Government last night at 9.15 p.m. brought on the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 when we were halfway through the debate on this matter. I cannot sit here and allow the Attorney-General to make these allegations improperly and unfairly.

—The matter before the Chair concerns amendments Nos. (8) and (9) to clause 9. I have allowed the debate to widen because the Attorney-General raised another matter but it is not the matter before the Chair. Does Senator Walters wish to speak to the amendments or to the matter raised by the Attorney- General?
—I would like to enter the debate we have been having, Mr Chairman.
—The debate relates to amendments Nos. (8) and (9) to clause 9.

—I feel that the point must be made that the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans) said that we are all very familiar with the debate that is about to take place. That cannot be so. I have just put out my own amendments and Senator Macklin had the decency to say to me: 'I will be most interested to listen to the reasons you will put for moving these amendments'. Unless the Committee has the decency to listen to the reasons put in relation to amendments we might as well all save our time and go home right now. Debate in this place has got to take place in a proper fashion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — I support the amendments moved by Senator Durack. I believe it is necessary to move further amendments which go to the question of the form of the ballot. Do I move those amendments now or wait until the matter is dealt with later? Because of the way the amendments have been circulated I am not sure whether I should move my amendments now.
—Senator Harradine is referring to clause 28A, not clause 9 .

That the amendments (Senator Durack's) be agreed to.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 December 1983, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: — When I first rose to speak on the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill (No. 2) I had got about three minutes up the track and had only made the point that this is a remarkable piece of legislation. Industrial relations is an area that is usually attended by loud banner headlines and condemnation by one party or the other, but on this occasion the Government, by pursuing its approach of consensus, has brought forward legislation that is approved by all the parties. In the vexed and disputatious field of industrial relations, that is an achievement that I think should be acknowledged. The National Labour Consultative Council, consisting of unions, employers and governments, approved nearly all of the amendments before us. Indeed, some of the amendments arose from legislation that the Fraser Government introduced before going to the polls this year. That legislation has been reintroduced by the Labor Government as it was in large part agreed to last year when it was first put to the Parliament. However, the fact that we are able to come forward with legislation that has a remarkable degree of commitment and consensus establishes clearly that the policy of the Hawke Government in seeking agreement and understanding is the correct one.

SPEECH.PARA: One hopes philosophically that by pursuing that policy and persisting with it, industrial disputation will cease to be the controversial political weapon it has been in public debate and that the causes and reasons for it will be more understood by the community. The industrial relations debate can then concentrate on resolving the causes of the conflict and not on blaming the parties. I hope that can evolve as we pursue the approach of trying to find reasonable accommodations for all parties. In the Bill before the Senate today there are a number of areas of change-10 in all. Most are technical and complex, but all are important to one group or another. I hope that in this debate we can have a serious dialogue across the chamber, shuck off our ideological blinkers and get to the merits of the issue so that we can concentrate on understanding what is contained in the Bill.

It is interesting that there is a precedent already in one State of Australia, South Australia, that demonstrates that it is possible on a comprehensive range of industrial relations amendments to achieve consensus. Jack Wright, the Minister of Labour in South Australia, was reported in the Australian on Monday as saying that he had achieved magical agreement across the board with employers , unions and his Government on major revision of the South Australian legislation. This Government has set up the Hancock Committee of Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems, so that we can review the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and all the attendant Acts associated with industrial relations and, for the first time since 1904 when the first Act came in, produce a report which perhaps will capture again that magical consensus and point a new direction for industrial relations. The Hancock Committee, consisting of Professor Keith Hancock, Charlie Fitzgibbon, the former Senior Vice-President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and George Polites, the former Executive Director of the Confederation of Australian Industry, is uniquely equipped to do that.
