When that report is presented, I hope that we will be in a position to have a similarly supported piece of legislation arising from it as we have now.

Perhaps it is in the context of that inquiry-because the existence of the inquiry underpins many of the comments that are to be made about this legislation-that I can make some remarks about a speech made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives, Mr John Howard, a few weeks ago, when he announced a proposal for two parallel systems of wage fixation. In a paper to the New South Wales Industrial Relations Society, which was holding a workshop on wage fixation, he contemplated two possibilities: That unions or employers be able to opt for arbitration and pursue claims and differences in that environment; or that they should be able to adopt and run, parallel with the arbitral setup, a collective bargaining direct negotiation scenario.

It is important to note that what underpins the philosophy of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act is that there must have been or ought to have been direct negotiations between the parties in the first instance, and that if that direct negotiation is not able to bring forth an agreement the parties should submit themselves to the conciliation processes of the Act; and ultimately, if those processes do not work, arbitration is the end result. So what Mr Howard was saying is no different from the fundamental philosophy of the existing legislation. He was couching it with a different emphasis. I can only say that what strikes a discordant note in his paper is the opting out idea of which he has talked, because any practitioner of industrial relations will observe that strong employers will want to opt out and take weak unions or poorly defended workers with them. There are a number of industries that come to mind. The fast food industry employs young workers. In that opted out situation, they would maximise their bargaining power in a collective bargaining environment, which would not be to the advantage of the community. Alternatively, strong unions might wish to opt out and take weak employers with them and force these employers out. Whichever way the opting out into the collective bargaining environment goes, whether it is led by employers exploiting their bargaining position over weak and poorly defended workers or by unions exploiting their position, it is obvious that there will be major disputation at that point. That is not something that the Australian economy or community will tolerate.

I do not want to go into a long analysis of Mr Howard's paper. However, since he has put it forward, I must say that the ideal place for him to canvass his views is before Professor Keith Hancock's inquiry. I would hope that the views that Mr Howard has put and the views of his party would be considered, and that there might thus be a commitment across party lines to the ultimate report that is forthcoming.

Turning to the Bill itself, I start with the amendments concerning complementary industrial relations systems. Mr Howard, in his paper, contemplated the continuance of the arbitration system. As such, therefore, it is obvious that he is interested in having an effectively functioning arbitration system. These amendments help to ensure that. In Australia over the last several years there has been a major debate as to whether there should be one arbitration system. The proponents of that major debate have often argued that Australia is cursed with seven separate arbitration systems-the Commonwealth and the States each with their own. Of course, there are also a number of sub-systems-tribunals such as the Coal Industry Tribunal, the Stevedoring Industry Tribunal, the tribunal for flight crew officers, and so on- which add to the complexity of arbitration authorities.

Without entering the debate which has been strongly argued by people so diverse as the Premier of New South Wales, Neville Wran, when he was beset in that State by disputation at the Kurnell oil refinery, as Gough Whitlam in a major paper last year in which he talked about the need for one arbitration system for Australia, and as Sir Charles Court in Western Australia, who often argued, although he was a rabid anti-centralist, that there should be one central arbitration authority, I think that the amendments in this Bill help to achieve for one authority an effect similar to that which many of the proponents of the one authority line hold as important. Perhaps I may just go back to the prices and incomes accord, which contemplates a centralised wage fixing system, to the National Economic Summit Conference which endorsed that, and to the national wage case decision which endorsed that. By having a central wage fixing system which is supported by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and by the State authorities in the same terms around Australia, we get one method of across the board uniform wage movement, one centralised method. In the terms of the submission put to the national wage case hearing by the Australian Government, it is a system that should not allow sectional claims and should allow anomalies or work value inquiries. In that sense there are no grounds for leapfrogging or for comparative wage justice.

We have a centralised system, and that system brings about, because of the commitment to it by the State tribunals and the other bodies, the same effect as one central arbitration authority might have. The legislation before us recognises the particular marginal areas where that effect may not be so uniformly achieved as would be the desire of the Government, the ACTU and, at the Summit, the employers. There are a number of industries that get involved in conflicts in their particular area because of differences between rulings on conditions or local matters by State or Federal authorities. Unions, for example , in the building industry, are covered in part by Federal jurisdiction and in part by State jurisdiction. When they make common claims, one sometimes finds differing decisions being arrived at by the State and the Federal commissions to sit conjointly on common claims or to delegate responsibility for the commissions to sit singly and to determine all claims on a particular site.

That is a major change. It is important not only in the building industry but also, going to another area, in the Pilbara. Unions in the land-based activities of the Pilbara mining industry are all covered by State awards, but in the loading out and off-shore-based activities of that industry they are all covered by Federal awards and sometimes find themselves in dispute with their employers over the same issue. Under this legislation there would be no different treatment by the different tribunals but, rather, the same treatment by the whole. That is a great and necessary change.

I go to another part of the Bill which is worthy of comment-not that all parts are not worthy of it, but some are more worthy than others. It is the part dealing with the rationalisation of industrial tribunals. As I read it, that is the legalese for the bringing of the Public Service Arbitrator fully into the enclave of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act but with a discrete section in that Act to provide a continuance of his performance of duty. A number of powers dealing with staff selection, employment and promotion are also restored, and provisions on stand-downs and no work as directed no pay--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., the sitting of the Senate is suspended until 2 o'clock.

INTERJECT.PARA: Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before Question Time commences, I inform the Senate that Senator Gareth Evans will be absent from the chamber this afternoon. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Evans in relation to his portfolio or those he represents should be directed to me.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I ask him whether he agrees that the Prime Minister misled the House of Representatives on 17 May this year when he said that apart from Mr Mick Young's 'kick out a Russian' comments before his famous long lunch:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . he has in all other respects acted as we, that is the honourable member and me, would expect him to do-with honour and propriety.

Was this misleading statement caused by the fact that the former Special Minister of State had withheld from the Prime Minister the fact that he had leaked information to his old mate Eric Walsh on the night of 21 April? Does the Minister really believe that a few months absence from the Ministry is sufficient penalty for someone who by his deception of his Leader has caused the Prime Minister to commit the most serious of parliamentary offences?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in the Senate a statement was brought down, in response to the Hope Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies, which dealt very fully in one section with the position the Government took in relation to Mr Young's resignation and to the prospect of his returning to the Ministry. I have nothing to add to that statement. I am not in a position to answer the question about whether the Prime Minister misled the House of Representatives on 17 May because subsequent statements made by the Prime Minister will have very much qualified that situation. I prefer to direct that question to the Prime Minister, which I will do.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: O'CONNOR'S AIR SERVICES PTY LTD: SERVICES IN SOUTH AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. I refer to the impending liquidation of O'Connor's Air Services Pty Ltd, as reported in the Adelaide Press. The airline provided a combined passenger and freight service to various South Australian centres on Eyre Peninsula, in the south-east and in the north of the State. In view of reports that people living in about 12 South Australian country towns, including Naracoorte, Millicent and Streaky Bay, will thereby be deprived of a direct air service, I ask the Minister whether there is any scope for Commonwealth assistance in these sorts of circumstances and, if so, the criteria under which such assistance can be provided.

—I am advised that matters relating to the provision of intrastate air services are essentially ones for State authorities, in this case for the South Australian State Government. The Commonwealth's involvement occurs on some occasions. The Commonwealth can take steps to pay a remote air service subsidy to any particular airline that may be, under certain conditions, unable to fulfil the service, as a result of economic difficulties. From my information this subsidy relates to the remoteness of some centres, inaccessibility of other transport means and frequency of air services provided. Most of the centres serviced by O'Connor's Air Services failed to meet those basic Commonwealth subsidy criteria-in particular that the frequency of air service is well in excess of the once weekly maximum for normal eligibility and that centres are accessible by sealed roads and other transport means including, in some instances, competing air services. Nevertheless, I am advised that possibly services to Minlaton, Cowell, Cleve and Kimba could qualify for the remote air services subsidy if existing services were discontinued. However, the services would need to be conducted at a frequency well below the present five services per week. If the O'Connor's company were to make a formal approach to the Australian Government the Department would be prepared to look at it sympathetically if it meets any of those basic criteria.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate as Minister representing the Prime Minister. I remind the Government Leader of the words of the Prime Minister in the House of Representatives on 23 August when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: It is quite clear why the Minister resigned. He came to me and he pointed out that he had breached confidentiality and he had not informed me of it. On the basis of what he put to me, of course the resignation was accepted.

Now that we have Mr Justice Hope's finding that Mr Young's action was both ' unauthorised and improper', what basis is there for a man guilty of these transgressions returning to the Ministry? As the facts have now been judged as even more serious, is the reason for the change of prime ministerial heart simply that summed up so well on the front page of today's Canberra Times, that is, that Mr Young has the numbers?

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the parliamentary Labor Party, I must say that I am quite uncertain as to whether Mr Young had the numbers. I do not think that is a question. The important question which Senator Teague addresses to me is related purely to the findings of the Hope Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies that Mr Young's conduct was unauthorised and improper. There is no doubt about its having been unauthorised. The real gravamen of the finding is one of improper conduct. In respect of that matter, I draw the attention of honourable senators to the statement made yesterday by the Government in relation to this matter. That statement stands. If people disagree with the statement, of course they will say so. But that is the Government's position.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs seen the report in today's Sydney Morning Herald headed 'Private teachers back Government policy '? In particular, I ask whether the Minister has seen the reported comments of Mr Michael Raper, President of the Independent Teachers Federation of Australia, that:

QUESTION.PARA: Calls for the end of state aid are totally irresponsible. But so too is the misrepresentation of the current funding guidelines by extremists like those at last night's (Monday) Malvern Town Hall meeting in Melbourne.

Do not these remarks from people in a qualified position to judge represent an endorsement of Government policy? What other expressions of support have there been from responsible and important education organisations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was aware of the Independent Teachers Federation of Australia's policy decision to support the Government's guidelines. In fact, its members have been supportive of the Government's guidelines since they were first announced. I spoke at the opening of their conference over the weekend and later met a delegation including their new executive on Monday morning. I am very heartened by what they had to say and I think honourable senators should take notice. They are the professionals who are running the independent schools which have been the subject of controversy in the media recently. They are the people who are committed to the education of young people in these schools. They are the people to whom the concerned parents, from whom we have been hearing a great deal, have entrusted their children. If those parents can entrust their children 's education to these teachers, I think they should take some note of what the teachers have to say about funding policies. They are informed people. They are professional people. They are dedicated people. It will be very enlightening for some of the parents of children in these schools to realise that the teachers, into whose care they have entrusted their children, do endorse the Government's policy.

ANSWER.PARA: I point out to honourable senators that these teachers are not only in a position to make a fair and professional assessment of recent decisions but also are well informed about the range of educational needs across systems. Of course , many of them, as honourable senators will know, will have taught in government school systems as well as private school systems. Many of them will have taught in the better-off private schools. Many of them will have taught in the poorer private schools. So, I think they represent a very broad base of understanding of the needs of children in schools. I think their statements ought to be taken very, very seriously by those who have chosen to participate in the present debate.

Of course, the Independent Teachers Federation of Australia is not the only responsible professional body which has endorsed the Government's guidelines. From memory, teachers federations throughout Australia have done so. The state school parents organisations throughout Australia have done so. Individual principals of state schools have done so. The Catholic education commissions throughout Australia have done so. It is very clear, I think, from the kinds of endorsements that the Government's policies have been getting, that those people who are informed and professionally engaged in the education of children in the government and non-government sectors accept the equity and justice and the positive and constructive effects of the Government's guidelines.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has the Government taken any action with regard to the rapidly deteriorating situation in the Lebanon which threatens the lives of the Lebanese people, the fragile peace in the region and a military confrontation between the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and the United States of America ? Has the Australian Government, as an ally of the United States of America and a high priority target in a nuclear exchange between the super-powers, been consulted by the United States Government as to the nature and wisdom of its current moves towards a potential military confrontation with Syria and its predominant ally, the USSR? Given the fact that, during the October 1973 Middle East crisis, the North West Cape communications base was used to transmit a world wide United States nuclear alert without the knowledge of the then Labor Government, can this Government confirm that to date no such alert has been transmitted and that should such an alert be transmitted this Government would receive prior warning?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of parts to Senator Chipp's question. I will deal with them to the best of my ability in the manner in which the question was asked. First of all, I was asked about the general attitude of the Australian Government to the events in Lebanon. I am unable to provide an answer at this stage-I will seek an early reply-to the question whether the North West Cape communications base has been used to transmit any alert or whether the present Government would be informed about that situation if it arose.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the developments in Lebanon, if there is one encouraging thing in those developments-there are not many-it is that the Secretary of State, Mr Shultz, has gone on record describing the latest air strike as an isolated incident, in terms which suggest it would not be the intention of the United States Government to repeat it. He went on to seek to justify that action as a permissible retaliatory action under the terms of the multi-national force agreement in which the Lebanese Government had authorised the use of United States reconnaissance flights. Those are the words that Mr Shultz used. They do not quite match up with what, in fact, happened. I think there has been a quite hopeful attempt by the United States Government to distinguish the recent developments as an isolated incident. We can only hope that is so. As I said, I will seek an answer to the question of the possible use of the North West Cape base and an answer about the degree of consultation which the United States Government has had with the Australian Government about the role of the United States Government in the Lebanon.

On the more general aspect of the question, I can only say that the Government is very concerned about developments and has, as I understand it, through diplomatic channels, called for caution and constraint in relation to the Middle East situation. Of course, it does that, in a sense, publicly in Australia in answers to questions of this kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Attorney-General explain the stunning hypocrisy of some Opposition Tasmanian senators who bleat about the Commonwealth spending $1.25m of taxpayers' money on the referendum campaign and yet are on record as opposing the simultaneous elections proposal that will cost the taxpayer $17m every time a separate half-Senate election is held?
—I raise a point of order, Mr President. Is this matter not related to a debate currently before the Senate? Therefore, should questions about it be permitted?
—Order! There is no point of order.
—No, I cannot explain this stunning hypocrisy.
—Of course you can't. You don't understand the whole thing.
—I was going to say that I cannot explain the level of stunning hypocrisy because I am stunned by it myself, Senator Walters.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Chaney

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. I refer to standing order 99 which sets out the rules which will apply to questions. Paragraph 4 states:

INTERJECT.PARA: Questions shall not refer to-
(a) debates in the current Session;

We are involved, at this stage, in a debate which relates to this matter. The legislation is only in part dealt with. I think we are in the Committee stage and are dealing with amendments which go to the very point which has been raised . There have been debates on this issue, not only in the current session, but also as recently as last night. Those debates will, I understand, resume today. In those circumstances I ask you, Mr President, to rule the question out of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —I allow the question, but I advise the Minister that he should be careful to keep in mind standing order 99 and he should bear in mind also that a question of ministerial responsibility is involved in this question.

—It was a very simple question. I was about to explain that I could not answer it because I was stunned by the level of hypocrisy which was displayed in connection with this matter. I really have little more to add to that. I should only say that the Government is very conscious of the costs which would be involved on a continuing basis if a referendum relating to simultaneous elections was not carried. But, of course, the costs of referendum proposals have to be considered in all their manifestations. I take it they will be considered by the Tasmanian Government in respect of any costs which it contributes to the forthcoming referendum campaign.

—I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate whether he knows the cost of the referendum campaigns which are being held next February at the insistence of the Government and what the comparative costs would be if those referendums were held in conjunction with a general election, which would, of course, be a course open to the Government.

—Senator Chaney has asked me to do some arithmetic which, so far as I am concerned, is like asking a Minister to advance a legal opinion in this chamber. I am quite prepared to do the arithmetic later and give him an answer in due course.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. It concerns a recent survey of mature age workers undertaken by the Bureau of Labour Market Research and released last week. Can the Minister indicate what programs are available within the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations specifically to assist mature age unemployed people? Will the Department be implementing any additional programs in light of this report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Foreman well knows, because he has asked many questions about the employment situation, the unemployment statistics represent something of a blancmange; we deal with a particular situation in one area, then a new situation emerges in another. That is particularly true in relation to age profiles of the unemployed. As Senator Foreman correctly pointed out, a survey has been conducted under the aegis of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations in relation to mature age unemployed. The Federal Government has in place several programs which offer a range of services, many of which would be applicable to those in the age group to which the honourable senator referred.

ANSWER.PARA: I refer briefly to some of those programs. Firstly, there is the community employment program. The Government expects, given the relatively high level of unemployment amongst those of 25 years of age and over, that the program will achieve a reasonable balance between the participation of both the younger and older age groups. Secondly, there is LATA, the labour adjustment training arrangements, which provide redundant workers with training to upgrade and broaden skills. While I have no specific knowledge of the application of LATA, it has been particularly true in some of the steel centres, for example where there has been unemployment, that that scheme has specifically catered for more mature age workers. I believe it has been quite successful in that respect.

The third general assistance program involves the general training assistance which is provided to individuals with previous labour market experience who, without training or retraining, have difficulty obtaining stable and rewarding employment. There is also, fourthly, the adult wage subsidy scheme under which employers are offered a wage subsidy to provide adult long term unemployed job seekers with a period of stable employment. Finally, in addition to these specific labour force programs, mature age unemployed people may benefit through the various advisory counselling and other assistance services provided by the Commonwealth Employment Service. I must say in relation to the adult wage subsidy scheme that this program was specifically introduced in view of the fact that the recession was found to be severely affecting adult workers.

I should also add that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations will shortly be announcing a thorough external review of departmental labour force programs. He has already indicated that this study should have special regard in its terms of reference to the needs of mature age unemployed people.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister representing the Prime Minister. The Leader will recall that Mr Justice Hope said, on page 195 of his findings, that there was 'a real risk that significant damage could have resulted from the disclosure'. He was referring to disclosures by the former Special Minister of State which His Honour later described as unauthorised and improper. I ask the Leader of the Government whether he agrees with the view of the then Opposition Leader, Mr Hayden, who said on 21 September last year:

QUESTION.PARA: If the Government sets up an independent judicial inquiry then, very properly, if impropriety is established . . . the Government has no choice in the matter. There must be a dismissal of the person who is identified as being guilty.
If he does agree with the Foreign Minister, how can Mr Young possibly return to the Hawke Ministry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand the statement made by Mr Hayden, it was to the effect that if an independent judicial inquiry finds that there is improper conduct and recommends a dismissal, a dismissal should follow. I do not see that as having any particular relevance to the situation in relation to Mr Young's position and the Hope Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies. The Hope Royal Commission provided its report some four months after Mr Young had resigned from the Ministry, for reasons which were stated by him at the time.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said that, I repeat what I said earlier during Question Time: The Government's position in respect of Mr Young was stated yesterday in a statement which I read to the Senate. I have nothing to add to that statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the Government aware of the desperate plight of the famed Nobel Peace Prize winner, Professor Andre Sakharov? Is is a fact that he is gravely ill and has been exiled to Gorky, some 400 kilometres east of Moscow, where he is held incommunicado, cut off from the companionship of his wife and the support of friends? Will the Australian Government make representations to the Soviet Government to provide more humane treatment for this intellectual and moral giant who appears now to be in the twilight of his life?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is aware of reports that Dr Sakharov continues to be harassed by Soviet authorities. In the Government's view, it is a further example of the Soviet Union's disregard for the human rights embodied in United Nations instruments and the 1975 Helsinki Final Act. If the stories circulated in relation to the harassment of Dr Sakharov are correct, they are outrageous and the Government and, I believe, all members of the Senate would totally reject the petty and pernicious attitude of the Soviet Union in relation to these matters.

ANSWER.PARA: Many people in this community, quite apart from those in the Parliament, are concerned at the mistreatment of Dr Sakharov and other Soviet dissidents by the Soviet authorities. The Government itself has completely and repeatedly condemned the abuse of human rights as practised in the Soviet Union.

Finally, let me say that the Government relies not only on outside reports of the treatment of dissidents like Dr Sakharov but also has continued to monitor, through the Australian Embassy in Moscow, the situation of dissidents within the Soviet Union. On a number of occasions it has through the embassy conveyed its views to the Soviet authorities in the strongest possible terms. As long as this Government is in power, it will continue to do so until some justice is obtained .

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. It concerns the report of the Hope Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies and the tabling statement made yesterday. Does the Minister recall saying yesterday that amongst the reasons for Mr Mick Young's return to the Ministry was that he was a 'good man who has made a mistake that he now regrets', that he, his wife and family have suffered and that 'he has spent 30 years working in and for the Labor movement'? Does Senator Button believe that Mr David Combe is also a good man, that he and his family have suffered greatly and that he has worked for the Labor movement for many years? If so, will the Government consider any action to enable Mr Combe to rehabilitate himself in view of the fact that it has decided to reward another person whose actions were strongly criticised by Mr Justice Hope?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course I recall what I read to the Senate yesterday in relation to Mr Mick Young and I agree with the statements which I made and which were quoted by Senator Collard in his question. I do not have a Government view to put to Senator Collard about Mr David Combe. As far as I am concerned, he is a good man, with the various attributes which are ascribed in other circumstances to Mr Young. I cannot quote them all, but let me say that that is my personal belief.

ANSWER.PARA: I think the findings of the Hope Royal Commission were not, however, directed to that question. The question the Hope Royal Commission concerned itself with in relation to Mr Combe was whether he had engaged on a course of action which was undesirable and, if I might use the word, silly.

Insofar as the question of the rehabilitation, as Senator Collard put it, of Mr Combe is concerned, the Hope Royal Commission clearly indicated that as far as the Commission's terms of reference were concerned the incident in relation to Mr Combe was over and that henceforth Mr Combe could proceed with whatever career he wished to follow without any findings of the Hope Royal Commission being held against him in respect of previous conduct. That is a view which I share-

TALK.START.PARA: —Such compassion!

—and, without the assistance of Senator Baume, I hope that that takes place. The general situation in relation to lobbyists was indicated by the Government in a statement brought down yesterday. That will apply to Mr Combe as well as everybody else on an equal basis and I hope that that process will heal as quickly as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. The Federal Government recently announced that it would be establishing a women's information service in Queensland. In view of the attitude of the Premier of Tasmania to the position of women's adviser in that State, will the women of Tasmania have access to a similar service?

—It is the intention of the Government to provide adequate information services for women throughout Australia, particularly in regard to the very wide and ever increasing range of Commonwealth programs designed to assist women. Such programs include the new women's emergency services program, which will be administered by my colleague Senator Don Grimes, the expanded children's services program and the community employment program, which is, of course, of extraordinary importance to women who are suffering from unemployment and other matters concerning their rights, and the new rights to be protected against discrimination, which women will shortly have under the sex discrimination legislation. What we are doing, on the advice of the Office of the Status of Women, which in turn is in touch with women's advisers in all States and Territories throughout Australia, is examining the particular needs of each State and Territory. I am sure that if a need can be established for such an office within Tasmania the resources will be found to fund it. So Tasmanian women also will have the advantage of information about programs which will be of great benefit to them.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: RESIGNATION OF MINISTER ASSISTING THE MINISTER FOR COMMUNICATIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to a recent Press statement of 5 December, headed 'Button wants his uneasy partnership ended '. Is it a fact that the honourable senator has written to the Prime Minister, unannounced, requesting that he be no longer designated as Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications? Was the Minister for Communications aware of the letter before it was sent and has the Prime Minister replied? Does the disagreement that he has had with, for instance, the Government's proposal for the allocation of transponders on the Australian domestic satellite, amongst other things, have anything to do with his desire to leave the communications area?

—I do not know what Press report there was on 5 December and I am certainly not prepared to comment on any heading that was given to that Press report. Yes, I did write to the Prime Minister indicating that I would seek to be relieved of my position as Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications . The Minister for Communications was not informed by me, prior to my writing that letter, of my intention to do so. I felt it appropriate that I obtain a response from the Prime Minister before advising the Minister for Communications . I have now obtained a response from the Prime Minister. The Minister for Communications is now aware of the matter.
—A lack of communication?

—No, not at all. I would have thought that was the proper way to do it. If the honourable senator is concerned about propriety, as he claims in another context, I think it is important that he should recognise propriety here , even in me. Might I just add that speculation about disagreements between myself and the Minister for Communications is pure speculation. It is quite true that I have sometimes different views from other Ministers about various things. That of course would extend to my views about communications matters. But the fact of the matter is that when I became Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications it was not ever intended that I would remain in that role for a long period, and in my letter to the Prime Minister I indicated that I thought it was now time.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: REPATRIATION BENEFITS: MEMBERS OF AUSTRALIAN SECRET INTELLIGENCE SERVICE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. In the event of those involved in the Australian Secret Intelligence Service fiasco being injured or killed, would the Repatriation Commission be required to pay them benefits? What would be the Commonwealth Government's obligation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —There would be three principal areas in which persons involved in activities on behalf of the Commonwealth would be eligible for benefits. If they are involved in the role of a peace keeping force, which I referred to last week-I do not think anyone in his wildest imagination could describe what happened at the Sheraton Hotel as a peace keeping arrangement-or if they are in fact members of the armed forces, and I am not sure whether they are, and if they have served sufficient time in the armed forces, they would become eligible for repatriation benefits if they were injured or killed. Of course I am not able to answer whether they were members of the armed forces. The third case would be if the Commonwealth declared that they were in a war zone. I do not think anyone would say that what happened at the Sheraton was a war zone situation. So in those circumstances I am not able to answer specifically because I do not know.

ANSWER.PARA: In fact, I do not think the Australian Government or the Australian community is yet aware of the particular capacities of those persons involved, whether they were public servants, members of the armed services or what have you. If they were public servants or members of the armed services they would, under certain circumstances, come within the jurisdiction of my Department for benefits and they would also, of course, qualify under the Compensation ( Commonwealth Government Employees) Act. If the farce had developed to a position where, say, a private security guard or a member of the State police had become involved and someone had been killed, compensation probably could have been claimed if they were public servants. If they were public servants they would come within Senator Grimes's area. If they were members of the armed services they would qualify under certain circumstances under legislation administered by my Department. However, I remind the Senate that some of the State police who were involved in the Hilton affair, which was a Commonwealth organised event in Sydney, became involved in a long, protracted struggle to seek compensation for the related injuries and mental breakdowns they suffered as a result of that experience. They did not succeed in getting the previous Government to meet its obligations in respect of that affair.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: IMPORTATION OF NEW ZEALAND FRESH POTATOES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Industry and Commerce, relates to problems which will face Australian potato growers if New Zealand fresh potatoes are allowed into Australia without quarantine restrictions. Are Australian potatoes at present free of serious disease? Is the Government now considering the relaxation of quarantine regulations to allow the importation of fresh potatoes into Australia, especially from New Zealand? Does not New Zealand have potato diseases of which Australia is free? Is the Minister aware of the disaster which would strike the Australian potato industry if potato pests, such as the golden nematode, were introduced into Australia from New Zealand? Would the Minister agree that the risk must be avoided, since prevention is obviously less costly to our potato industry than the eradication of potato pests after their introduction?

—I strive very hard to master the details of my portfolio, but I must say that I have not yet mastered the details in relation to the prevalence or otherwise of potato disease. All I know is that the desirability of importation of potatoes from New Zealand was the subject of an exchange of correspondence between the Minister for Primary Industry and me recently. I am not in a position to answer Senator Hamer's question in detail. The matter is currently under review. As soon as I am in a position to do so, I will give him an answer to the details indicated in his question.

—Is the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs aware of a Mr Barry Everingham, who spoke as a 'concerned parent' at the public meeting on government funding of non-government schools held at the Malvern Town Hall on Monday night? Is this the same Barry Everingham, a relative of the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, who, according to the Melbourne Age of 3 December, became in 1973 the only journalist ever to be expelled from the Parliamentary Press Gallery in Canberra, for being found, without authority, in a suite of offices occupied by Gough Whitlam? Is this 'concerned parent' Barry Everingham the same Barry Everingham who used to write a scandal column called ' Betty' in a Canberra throwaway newspaper?

—I saw the article in the Melbourne Age on Saturday morning. I did know the fact to which it referred-Barry Everingham's expulsion from the Press Gallery. I can confirm to the Senate that that is the Barry Everingham who organised the meeting in the Malvern Town Hall and spoke as the representative of concerned parents. It was also widely believed that he was the author of a particularly unpleasant and unattractive little gossip column called 'Betty' in a throwaway Sunday newspaper which I think was called the Sunday Post. Certainly , when it reached its demise, no citizen in Canberra regretted its disappearance . He is the same Barry Everingham who was the organiser and main spokesman for the concerned parents in the Malvern Town Hall on Monday night.

—My question, which I direct to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, refers, first, to the Minister's statement in the Senate on 10 November 1983 that a decision by the Government on the future funding and administrative arrangements for the Australian Film Archive is 'expected shortly'. Has the Government made a decision? If so, when will the decision be announced? If not, when will the decision be finalised? If the answer to this question is still 'shortly', how much longer than the month since her statement to the Senate is 'shortly'? Is consideration of the same matters-funding and administration-also being undertaken with respect to the sound archives?

—On consulting the brief from the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment I find there is no updated information from what I gave Senator Martin in the Senate recently. However, coincidentally, Senator Martin's colleague Senator Reid raised this matter informally with me yesterday. I have just had drafted a letter asking Mr Cohen for urgent consideration and finalisation of this matter. As soon as that information is available, I will make it available to the Senate. I can assure Senator Martin and other senators that I am as concerned as she is and as Senator Reid is that a proper and stable future for the National Film Archive be established. Of course, I am also aware that there are similar problems facing the sound archives. I will pursue the matter very urgently with my colleague and I hope to have a reply for Senator Martin and the Senate before the end of this week.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Is it correct that most World War II ex-service personnel are relatively better placed than other members of the community if they are forced into early retirement? Can the Minister advise whether some employers have reduced their staffing levels by retrenching ex-service personnel or inviting them to accept so-called voluntary retirement? What is the Government's attitude to this practice?

—It is true that ex-service personnel who served in a theatre of war and who meet the income test are eligible to receive a service pension at the age of 60. The wives of such ex-servicemen are eligible to receive a pension at 55. It is true that some evidence has emerged in recent times to suggest that employers are taking advantage of this to bring about the early retirement or premature retirement of ex-servicemen. I have had brought to my attention two cases in which employers having to make a choice about retrenching workers have told ex-servicemen that as they are 60 years of age and therefore eligible for the service pension they should be first to go in the retrenchment plans of the company. I believe that is reprehensible conduct because it is placing the burden on the Commonwealth, which has to pay these people an age pension five years earlier than would otherwise be the case. I have suggested to the union that raised this matter with me that it is a clear matter of discrimination when people are singled out just because the Commonwealth can pick up a welfare responsibility and thereby allow a company to retrench workers. Certainly Senator Colston can be assured that the Government is appalled at this practice. In every case that has been brought to my attention I have suggested that the matter is one for determination by the Anti-Discrimination Board.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's Gallery of Sir Harold Young, a distinguished former President of the Senate, and Mr Peter Sim, a former senator. On behalf of all senators, I wish them a warm and friendly welcome on their return to Canberra.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which I address to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, relates to a report released by the Australian Film Commission entitled 'Women in Australian Film Production', which concludes that there is a distinct imbalance between the number of men and the number of women working in film in all areas and at all levels. Firstly, will the Minister comment on this report compiled by the Australian Film and Television School and the Women's Film Fund and, in particular, the claim that most women in the film industry are employed in jobs with low status, low pay and a low level of responsibility? Secondly, what explanation can be given for the current imbalance and will action be taken by the Government to rectify the situation? Thirdly, will a campaign be mounted by the Australian Film Commission aimed at encouraging more women to enter the film industry both in top level positions such as producer and director and in the key technical areas of camera , sound and lighting, where they are comparatively so underrepresented at present.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the report to which Senator Missen's question refers. I am also aware of the description it contains of the unequal participation of women in different levels of the film industry. Although the film industry, of which we are all duly proud, has often been cited as an example of a non-sexist industry and an industry in which women have been able to be successful, I think this widely held view reflects the prominence achieved by a small number of well -known women producers and directors who include women such as Jill Robb, Margaret Fink, Margaret Kelly, Pat Lovell, Joan Long, Gillian Armstrong and so on. Their achievements are outstanding and have been acknowledged. But the reality is that few women have gained entrance to the mainstream film industry areas and there is, as the report points out, a serious underrepresentation of women in creative jobs and in key technical areas. The report issued by the Women's Film Fund confirmed this and made some recommendations.

ANSWER.PARA: In answer to Senator Missen's question about what action is going to be taken, I indicate that the Government has announced a special women's film production unit to be established under the auspices of the Women's Film Fund. This unit will be funded by a grant of $400,000 under the community employment program. It will be housed at Film Australia and employ up to 40 women film makers in the development and production of four film and television programs. In launching the report the Chairman of the Australian Film Commission said that the Commission would give priority to programs designed to enhance women's access to employment and decision-making in the film industry. Steps taken in this regard include a 40 per cent increase in the Women's Film Fund budget from $130,000 to $180,000 in this financial year and the establishment of an internal working party to develop initiatives designed to give practical effect to equal employment opportunities policy. So I think that the deficiencies, in terms of women's access to all sections of the film industry which have been drawn attention to in the report, are now being constructively addressed and I am sure that Senator Missen joins me in expressing the hope that those initiatives will be successful.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations whether he has seen an article in the Advertiser of 5 December headed 'Why not girl apprentices?' which reports grants of $11,000 to three South Australians to study small employers' attitudes to employing women apprentices in traditionally male trades. I understand that the term 'small employers' refers to the size of the work force and not to the height of the employer. The report comments that while the Government is encouraging young women to consider trade apprenticeships and providing courses to support them, there has been little study of attitudes of employers. Can the Minister say whether there is any evidence that government programs are ahead of industry preparedness and acceptance to participate, not only in this area of women apprentices, but also in efforts to solve this country's unacceptably high unemployment levels? Is the Minister aware of any other research to establish whether such industry attitudes do exist, or is the seeming co-operation of industry at the National Economic Summit Conference continuing?

—I was not aware of the study to which Senator Crowley has referred. A number of questions associated with government attitudes to these matters arise from the information that Senator Crowley has provided regarding the study. I will address each of those questions to the Minister and obtain an early answer.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Defence whether the Government is aware that a decision that Royal Australian Air Force No. 3 Squadron, with its aging Mirages, quit Butterworth, will widen the current rift between it and the Association of South East Asian Nations. To overcome this problem and the need to integrate and train for the introduction of the FA18 Hornet into the Force from 1985, will the Government consider replacing the Mirages with the Australian-displaced Skyhawks, thereby keeping content ASEAN, the Butterworth community and the presently disillusioned Skyhawk pilots, each of whom cost more than $1m to train and many of whom are now seeking work with the British Navy?

—A number of questions contained in that disarming piece of guile by Senator Watson involve making value judgments-about the Australian rift with ASEAN, about whether particular actions will heal it or otherwise-and I am certainly not able to comment on any of them. I am sure that the Government will consider the proposition advanced by Senator Watson in relation to the Skyhawks but equally I am fairly confident that it will be rejected. I will direct the honourable senator's question to the Minister for Defence and obtain a detailed answer.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations aware that in a paper entitled 'Estimates of Unemployment by Local Government Area', the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations lists 36 local government areas, of a total of 145, as having unemployment rates in excess of the Queensland average of 10 per cent? A study of community employment program announcements in Queensland made to date indicates that only a few of these high level unemployment areas are, in fact, represented, leaving up to 30 areas not as yet recognised by the allocation of funds for vital job creation projects. Given that many of these areas are in northern, central and western Queensland, can the Minister assure Queenslanders that there will not be a capital city-south-east corner bias in the implementation of the Federal Government's important employment initiatives in that State?

—The community employment program has been developed according to guidelines which, as far as possible, try to eliminate biases of various kinds, whether on the basis of age, sex or geographical location. As the honourable senator is aware, as is quite apparent from her question, consideration has been given to priority of allocations under the program, having regard to employment levels in particular districts. I would be very surprised if, in the allocation of money for the community employment program in respect of Queensland, there was any departure from the general approach. I am sure that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations would be very concerned if in fact there were. There was certainly no intention that a capital city bias should be allowed. However, as the question is more probing than the response to now would indicate, I will direct its more specific details to the Minister. I am fairly confident that the answer will be along the lines I have suggested.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Defence to the environmental impact study conducted to evaluate the proposal to establish a Royal Australian Air Force base at Tindal in the Northern Territory and ask: Have any conclusions been drawn by the Government as a result of this study? If so, when will a decision be made on the development or otherwise of an RAAF base at Tindal? If the project is agreed to, when does the Government anticipate that construction on the base could begin?

—I am not aware of the details of this matter, but I believe that the Government has certainly not reached any conclusions about it. In the circumstances, the question as to when contruction will commence is not relevant . I will address the specific matters of timing and Government conclusions, and the supplementary elements of the question, to the Minister for Defence and obtain an early answer.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, refers to two aspects of the community employment program. Can the Minister say whether the Government is satisified with the present efforts to encourage participation in the program by community welfare groups? Can he also advise whether the State consultative committees will be regularly monitoring job placements to ensure that the program policy of helping the most disadvantaged unemployed groups is effectively carried out?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question has two aspects. The first relates to the general aspect of the community employment program and whether the Government is satisfied in relation to its promotion. The Government has conducted a broadly based promotional program in the community related to the CEP. Approximately 25, 000 letters were sent in the course of that promotion to various community, welfare and other groups which might logically be concerned with the importance of the program and its development. Also, an extensive radio and newspaper advertising campaign was conducted at the national and local level, directed at bringing the program to the attention of prospective sponsors, in particular community organisations. Whether one can gauge the success of these campaigns accurately is difficult to say but there have been some 17,000 inquiries about the program and more than 7,500 project applications, by various eligible organisations, including community groups, have been received. Also, some 30 area project offices have been put in place by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations to promote the program to community groups and local government, and to assist prospective sponsors to develop proposals.

ANSWER.PARA: Insofar as the second part of the question relating to the functions of the State and Territory consultative committees is concerned, I make the point that their functions include encouraging and facilitating the development of worthwhile projects throughout the community in such a way as to ensure that the targets and objectives of the program are met. That involves, as the honourable senator's question implies, the regular monitoring of job placements and other performance indicators. I am led to believe that the results of this monitoring will be provided to the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations on a regular basis. It is the Government's intention also that the objectives of the community employment program of assisting the most disadvantaged groups of unemployed will be achieved through the involvement of the Commonwealth Employment Service as the sole referral agency to job vacancies created under the program. In essense, the Government is satisfied, as well as it can be satisfied, with the promotional activities in relation to the community employment program. Insofar as the work of the State and Territory consultative committees is concerned, the Government is at this stage, subject to reports to date, satisfied that the monitoring function to which Senator Elstob referred in his question is being carried on in a satisfactory manner.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Haines proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The alarming and increasing incidence of physical, emotional and sexual abuse of children, particularly within family units, and the lack of readily accessible support mechanisms for these children and their families.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 December last year, the Australian ran an article which, in its headline, connected Christmas and child abuse. It began by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: The decorations are up, the stores are full, the Santas are at work-and throghout the nation hospitals are busy as the battered babies are brought in.
According to Adelaide social workers in the field of child protection, there's only one other season like it-the approach to Mother's Day.

At both times of supposed family goodwill, frustrations, anxieties and a desperate sense of inadequacy send hundreds, possibly thousands, of parents over the edge. They lash out at the weakest, most vulnerable person around-usually the child.

In 1981, in Victoria a five-year-old boy was admitted to hospital after he had been burned by a blow torch in a row that involved his mother and her husband. The boy is permanently disfigured. In the middle of this year it was reported that a 15-year-old girl had become pregnant after being raped by her father in New South Wales. The 44-year-old man pleaded guilty to having sexual intercourse with his daughter without her consent twice between November and December of last year.
On 12 April this year, I gave notice of the following motion:
That the Senate-
(a) notes with concern the alarming incidence of sexual and emotional abuse of children, particularly within family units;
(b) deplores the lack of available support mechanisms for these children and their families; and
(c) requests that action be taken to investigate the matter, collect statistical data, and provide recommendations for overcoming the problem.

Given the rapid approach of Christmas 1983, the Australian Democrats and I thought that it might be reasonable to remove that notice of motion from the Notice Paper and to debate the matter as a matter of public importance today. I put that notice of motion on the Notice Paper seven months ago. During that time , approximately 7,770 children have been battered. Some of those children have died. Some have suffered grave injury. All of them have been scarred emotionally , physically and psychologically.

I make it quite clear at this stage that when I am talking about child abuse I am not talking about a child who is smacked for being naughty but about a child who is picked up and thrown across the room repeatedly. I am not talking about a child who has been sent to his or her room without his or her supper for some infraction of the family rules. I am talking about a child who has been repeatedly chained up outside in all weathers as a form of punishment for something which may have been unintentional, something which the child did not even realise he or she was doing. It may simply have been an overreaction by a parent at a time of crisis. I am not talking about the normal forms of discipline that all of us who are parents have exercised on our children.

Fatal child abuse, according to the experts, is now the third major cause of violent death for pre-school children in Australia. An average of 37 children each day in Australia are physically abused. The South Australian Health Commission's report that was recently brought down states:
. . . between 1977 and 1982, the number of reports of child abuse to the Department of Community Welfare increased by 56 per cent.
Sexual abuse reports almost doubled in the same period.

The sorts of abuse that the report listed include bruises, welts and scars, injuries to the upper lip, human bite marks, marks from the use of a blunt instrument or from lash marks, plus tattoos inflicted with a sharp instrument and choke marks on the neck. The report stated that a common presentation is a hot water burn which may be the dunking type, particularly resulting in burns to the buttocks. Burns have been inflicted also with matches or lighters. Dry contact burns occur from the forceful holding of a child under or against a hot object.

The report describes sexual abuse as incest, rape and other forms of sexual activity, including fondling of the genitalia, inappropriate genital contact, mutual masturbation and child pornographic activities. Examples of emotional abuse listed are when a young child is repeatedly locked out of the home or a disobedient teenage girl has her head shaved. The report says that child abusers come from 'all socio-economic groups and all levels of education'. It will therefore be apparent from that list of abuse forms that physical abuse is far from being the only way in which a child can be maltreated.

It has been estimated that, in the seven months to which I referred between listing the notice of motion on the Notice Paper and raising this matter of public importance today, up to 17,500 cases of sexual abuse will have occurred. Only a small proportion of these cases will have been reported and the rest will have been swept under the carpet and concealed. The reason for that, of course, is that people do not like to talk about it. It is not something nice. It is not something that we bring out into the light for us to see and, as a consequence, very little is done about it since it is not one of those things that produce a violent community push for reform.

If sexual abuse is difficult to prove because often the victim is not aware of the fact that she is being abused since many sexually abused daughters believe that this is the way all fathers treat their daughters, because the mother will not believe the child or because the child is too embarrassed or afraid to report it, emotional abuse is even more difficult to define and to prove. But that it exists is not in any doubt at all. It involves things like constant scapegoating within a family, terrorising a child, neglecting a child or simple rejection of that child by one or more members of the family. What we do know is not only the forms it takes but also that it results in inevitable mutilation of a child's personality at the very stage when that child's personality is developing. Other forms of child abuse in this area, of course, include medical care neglect which sometimes results from a parent's desire not to let a doctor know that a child has been physically abused in some way, drug abuse and nutritional neglect. All too much of it takes place within the confines of the immediate family and is perpetrated by the natural parents.
In the Institute of Family Studies discussion paper entitled 'Violence and the Family', Donald Stewart stated:

One of the paradoxes of our society is that the group to which most of us look for love and gentleness is also the most violent civilian group or institution in our society. And much of this violence is treated as normal or is laughed off . . . To those who argue that all families provide a 'haven in a heartless world ' one only has to point to the growth of women's refuges, rape crisis centres, women's health centres and the like, and the increasing demand for similar services. The sensitive nature of the topic-
that is, of violence within families-
with cultural expectations of marital harmony and fear of violent reprisals-
this, of course, is something which prevents many women from acting-
makes family violence one of the most difficult areas in which to get accurate information.

Most parents who abuse their children are to all intents and purposes outside the family home 'normal' people acting under stress. They are not pathological or paranoiac in any way. They appear to be perfectly normal people. Dr Brian Fotheringham in an article in the Adelaide Advertiser in February of this year said:

Most parents who physically abused their children were normal people under stress . . . Less than 10 per cent who mistreat their children are psychotic; the vast majority are normal and have no psychiatric abnormality.

That makes one wonder how those who are psychotic or who have some form of psychiatric abnormality behave. Stress, isolation, alcohol, drugs, unemployment, going on the dole, the cost of health care, housing, mortgage repayments, the cost of living, problems at work and other problems, all add up and cause apparently normal people to rage against their children, to take their own sense of frustration, inadequacy and apparent pointlessness in life out on a child. Like wife-beating, child abuse is found in every country and throughout the social spectrum. It is certainly not something which is limited to the lower socio-economic bracket. It should not be associated necessarily with a drunken male parent of low intelligence quotient. It certainly occurs throughout the socio-economic strata and at all professional and work levels.

The idea that domestic violence is essentially a lower class phenomenon is not only a gross over-simplification of the problem but can also act to prevent a close and accurate study of the problem. By so doing, it makes it much harder to prevent the problems that occur in society through the scars that are inflicted by child abuse on the recipient of that abuse, because those scars remain throughout a child's life. They will affect it not only physically through the retention of burn scars or the effects of a broken arm when the child was thrown against a wall or whatever, but also socially, in that they will affect that child's future relationships with other people as individuals and with society as a whole. An American study of children who have committed a murder shows that a large majority have one thing in common. They have been victims of child abuse . The social genetics of child abuse, the psychological modelling that occurs in families repeatedly means that it goes on to the next generation. Children who are brought up in a violent environment believe it is a normal environment and therefore have a tendency to continue this form of behaviour through to when they become parents themselves. One of the most noted social workers at the Adelaide Children's Hospital, Janie Barbour, who is an internationally recognised authority on child abuse, had this to say about the effects of that problem:

There are high incidence of retardation, growth and neurological problems and, almost inevitably, impaired emotional function among physically abused children. Reports indicate that abuse and neglect bear a fairly direct relationship to social maladjustment and juvenile delinquency.

I add that that relationship is much higher than that of some of the things that are traditionally blamed for social maladjustment and juvenile delinquency, such as both parents working or a child coming from a split family. She went on:
Abused, neglected and sexually exploited children are hostile,-
which is hardly surprising-
fearful-
which is also hardly surprising-
and unable to relate effectively to others.

If their idea of relating to others is to operate on a violent scale clearly they will not be able to relate socially in the ways in which a modern society expects them to operate. Janie Barbour also said:

It is more than probable that degrees of child abuse and neglect may be the variables that account for socially unacceptable behaviours . . . unreported maltreatment can mean unattended physical injuries resulting in scars, defective vision, loss of hearing, misshapen extremities and urinary tract infections in the short term. In the long term, failure to report child abuse and neglect can result in irreversible developmental damage and academic delays.

Most of these effects are equally apparent in the case of sexual or emotional abuse. Sexual abuse has other equally devastating effects, particularly on young girls and women, since sexual abuse is almost entirely restricted to being perpetrated on females. For instance, a study of addicts attending the Odyssey House drug scheme in Victoria has shown a strong link between child abuse, particularly sexual abuse, and drugs. More than 80 per cent of drug addicts suffered mental, physical, or sexual abuse as children. Seventy per cent of female addicts, for example, were sexually abused as children either by rape or incest. Sixty-three per cent of this 70 per cent later turned to prostitution to support their drug habit. I find a nice if unpleasant irony in that vicious circle. According to Mrs Shirley Campbell of the Children's Protection Society in an article in relation to the people she deals with printed in the Australian in October of this year:
By the time they reached 11 years, 30 per cent of the females had been sexually abused, including 26 per cent involving incest.
Female sexual abuse jumped to 48 per cent as the girls entered puberty at 12 years and above.
The article reported that more than half the girls above the age of 12 had been raped and that boys were not exempt from sexual abuse and incest. Mrs Campbell was also reported as saying:
Twelve per cent of the male addicts reported incestuous encounters before they were 12 years old, and 16 per cent some form of sexual abuse.

I suggest that statistics such as those underline the horror of the situation and the need for something to be done on a national government level. A social worker from New South Wales sent a letter to the Australian recently in which he said:

The level of understanding of this problem both within the community and of the professionals who should bring help, is practically non-existent . . . Our society does not want to know about the problem, and, more worrying than that, our professionals and politicians don't want to know . . . Our politicians . . . need to face up to the fact that sexually abused children and their families require specialist services that cost money . . . These children face the grave risk of long term emotional and personality problems. They have the right to skilled and sensitive help; as a society we have a fundamental responsibility to provide it.

I do not think one member of the Senate would not fully endorse that view. The question arises of what we will do about it. Unlike this writer, I believe that the level of awareness of the problem of child abuse in all its appalling forms has increased. It has increased because State and Federal governments have provided funding for the establishment of rape crisis centres, women's centres and crisis care centres around the country. Therefore, there has been some opportunity for the collection of data and for the cataloguing of details and appalling case studies relating to child abuse. Although the frequency of child sexual abuse is unknown, because it is very difficult to get the children to admit to this, as I have said, and it is even harder to get the families to report it outside the family, it has been estimated by Stewart that 70 to 75 per cent of offenders are known to the child-I think that most honourable senators are familiar with these statistics-that 20 per cent of offenders are parents or parent figures, and that the home is a common site for the offence.

In a Perth study, it was found that 31 per cent of cases of child abuse under the age of 13 were incestuous, with 10 per cent of girls in the 13 to 18 year age group also in this class. I might add that some studies have shown a higher incidence of incest. It is likely that reports of incest, the most ancient of taboos in this country, despite Human Rights Commission recommendations on this subject, with its consequent devastating effects on the family and the enormous guilt with which the victim is often burdened, are even less indicative of the total incidence than are reports of other forms of child abuse. It is important to recall and to remember that the victim in cases of incest is often blamed for the problems.

I appear to be rapidly running out of time, Mr Deputy President; so I say only this in conclusion: Family violence is society's problem and one that must be confronted. We see frequently on cars a bumper sticker which says: 'Children are this country's greatest natural resource'. If we are not willing to expend time, expertise and money on their behalf, I wonder whether there is any point at all in expending them on anything else.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the Australian Democrats on bringing to the Senate's attention the problems of child abuse, because it is certainly a matter of great concern to the whole of the Australian community. The matter of public importance reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The alarming and increasing incidence of physical, emotional and sexual abuse of children, particularly within family units, and the lack of readily accessible support mechanisms for these children and their families.
I raise only one question, and that concerns the phrase 'alarming and increasing incidence'. I would question that; but I shall come to that matter later.

Child abuse occurs in many forms, as has been stated by Senator Haines-physical , emotional and sexual. Concerning physical abuse, the most common child at risk is the very young baby who cries a lot or the young child who is overactive, because the mothers are under pressure and that is often taken out on this age group. Concerning emotional abuse, this again comes in various forms. There are varying degrees of emotional abuse about which we are told, and many papers have been written about it. Concerning sexual abuse, in the majority of cases it is associated with young girls, although, as Senator Haines has said, it can also apply to young boys; but often it is associated with young teenagers as well. It is mostly committed by a father, an older brother, an uncle or some other close relative. We do not know a great deal about it, but we know these particular facts. Very few surveys have been done, but one survey by Rosenfeldt shows that out of 530 female college students, 8.5 per cent had had some sexual activity with a family member. That figure should be of great concern to us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that survey done in Australia, Senator?

—Yes. Sexual abuse is seen as a very difficult matter to handle. I have sat on two committees in this area. One of them looked into the question of homeless youth, and the other is presently looking into matters concerning children within institutional care. Sexual abuse and physical abuse have entered into both of these inquiries. We have been told that as far as sexual abuse is concerned, social workers feel that the prosecution of the father is very detrimental to the family situation; that it ends up only with the splitting up of the family and that therefore the father, in the majority of cases, should be counselled, and that education is the best way to approach this matter. We are told that by many of the social workers who have given evidence before us, in the homeless youth area in particular. But again, as I say, we have had the same groups telling us the same story in our inquiry into institutional care.

SPEECH.PARA: There was only one social worker, who, not very long ago, put a totally different point of view. She said that the majority of children who have been abused will also, when they grow up, abuse their children, and that it is a cycle that is very difficult to overcome. This particular social welfare worker said that in her opinion it was necessary to prosecute the father because unless one broke the cycle there was very little that one could do about it; counselling was not enough. Indeed, we saw one young girl at a shelter-and Senator Elstob, who is in the chamber, will recall this-who told us that she had run away from home and was in a shelter with the blessing of her mother because she was being sexually abused by her father. When we questioned her, she assured us that there were younger sisters at home, no doubt still being abused by the father, but she had escaped. We, as a community, accepting the social welfare officer's comments that if we prosecute the father, that will end only in breaking up the family, are very reluctant to do that and are more inclined to counsel the father. As Senator Haines has already indicated, it is very difficult for these young children to come forward and give evidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do these social workers suggest that you do? Tell him that it is wrong?

—They do; that is the point that I was making. They say: 'Do not disrupt the family; just counsel the father'.
