But as I have said, one social welfare officer said that that was impossible, that it was stupid, that it did not break the cycle, and that the father should be prosecuted. It is a very difficult area because the young girls do not like to let their mothers down. They do not like the shame of it. They do not like to give evidence against their fathers.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Haines has said, when one looks at some of the shocking cases of physical abuse, one wonders about the mentality of the parent. I should like to quote from an article in the latest edition of the Medical Journal of Australia, of 26 November. It says:

Bizarre forms of abuse . . . have tended to substain the belief that parents who abuse little children are psychotic or very seriously disturbed. This is not so; abuse is an irrational act, often caused by a momentary loss of control, to which most of us are susceptible.

It makes one wonder just how a parent can lose his or her temper and commit an irrational act. But parents are under pressure. These days, particularly, women are coming under more and more pressure because in many cases they are attempting to hold down two jobs. Some mothers are working full time, going home , picking up children from creches, and trying to do a full day's work in the house in just an evening. They lose sleep; perhaps the baby has a wakeful night and continues to cry. In the majority of cases in which a woman works, the husband does not accept equal responsibility in the home.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the real problem.

—That is the real problem, as Senator Haines says. The husband does not accept an equal share of responsibility in the home and the wife is left to do both jobs. I attended recently a shower tea for a young woman getting married. The advice given to her by many of her young friends was: 'If you are going to work, do not work for too long. You will find your husband still expects his meal on time. You will find the children must be attended to.'

SPEECH.PARA: History shows that child abuse, has gone on forever. The mid-seventeenth century, of course, saw the introduction of the very famous Punch and Judy show, which is a very violent show. Punch rocks the baby but the baby continues to scream and he finally hits the baby over the head and throws it out the window. Everybody thought that amusing in the mid-seventeenth century, and it has gone on ever since. In the mid-eighteenth century children five years of age worked in factories for 14 hours a day seven days a week and were ill-treated. An Act was passed to stop children who had been separated from their families-but only those children-from working in the factories. The parents, who were entitled to the children's income, were still able to send their children to work in the factories. The Act did not stop that. In 1860 the first study was done of 32 children who had been battered to death. Ambrose Tardieu wrote a paper on that. Indeed, as early as 1860 we had a very clear description of what now has become known as the battered child syndrome. It has been going on for a long time.

But it was not until Bowlby in the 1940s spoke about the emotional needs of children that we really began to listen to the fact that children had emotional needs. He warned that unless we had constant, stable and loving backgrounds, especially in the early years of our childhood, there would be very great problems later in life. It is only in the last 20 years that there has been public acceptance that there is a great problem in the community and that the battered child syndrome has finally got through to the Australian people.

What is being done in Australia? I am proud to say that my State was the first State to introduce mandatory child abuse reporting legislation. That was in 1975 . Because it is a State matter, all the States are at different stages. Professor Lewis has done a tremendous amount of work in our State in this area. South Australia followed with legislation the following year, in 1976, New South Wales in 1977 and Queensland in 1980. Victoria still has only voluntary reporting. Western Australia, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory have no reporting legislation. Along with the mandatory child abuse reporting, in Tasmania we have protection for people who in good faith report child abuse. They have complete protection from the law in case the parents threaten to sue them and stop them from reporting the incidents.

Perhaps I can explain what has happened in Tasmania because I believe we are at the forefront in dealing with this problem; we are making some overtures in the area, at least. In 1972 an advisory committee based in the Attorney-General's Department looked into any cases that came to its notice. But with the passage of the Tasmanian Child Protection Act a Child Protection Assessment Board was set up. It comprised five members. It is chaired by a lawyer and the members must include a paediatrician, a social worker, a psychiatrist and one other person, who is now the Director of Community Health. That Board has done a tremendous amout. It has two regional offices. Certain groups in the community are compulsorily required to report any suspicious cases. The groups include doctors, some social workers, community nurses, principles of kindergartens and primary schools, directors of child care centres, probation officers, school guidance officers and child welfare officers. It covers quite a group of people. South Australia has just joined us. I note that this year, apart from doctors, teachers, dentists and police officers, it has now included kindergartens, psychologists, hospitals, social workers and pharmaceutical chemists.

However, the only factor that will really make effective this legislation that is slowly coming in throughout Australia is the attitude and co-operation of family support services. The setting up of the support services is a State responsibility. Tasmania has several projects which work to identify the child at risk as it is believed that the majority of families from which abused children come are usually known to an agency or some community worker. Professor Lewis has written in his paper that he believes that these children at risk can be picked up through this knowledge.

I now come to the statement that I queried in the matter of public importance, that is, 'the alarming and increasing incidence of physical, emotional and sexual abuse of children'. There is no doubt that the figures for reported cases have gone up in the last eight or nine years. But those are only the reported cases. We have no idea of the real figures throughout Australia. Tasmania has kept note of the reported cases and I will mention those in a few minutes. But Australia-wide no surveys have been done which give us any indication of the full extent of the problem of battered children. The reported cases have increased because of greater public awareness and because of the compulsory reporting that has now been introduced in some of the States. The figures in Tasmania show that since 1975, when we introduced our compulsory reporting legislation, there has been an increase. In 1975, 42 cases of child abuse were reported. In 1976 the figure went up to 53 and it has continued to go up. Last year, there were 302 cases. Up to 30 September this year 237 cases had been reported, and we expect the 1983 figure to be about the same as the 1982 figure.

This figure does not really touch on the number of cases that are not reported. Therefore, I believe we need further surveys and further data collection so that we know the extent of the problem. We know that in Tasmania from 30 September 1981 to 30 September 1983, 312 physical abuses, 108 sexual abuses and 38 emotional abuses were reported. Physical abuse accounts for by far the greatest number of cases. The areas from which these figures come are also very interesting. The highest number of reports, 132, came from the Community Welfare Department. The Education Department reported 109, hospitals 97, relatives 67, the community at large-neighbours and so on-56, child health centres 51, general practitioners 38, mental health services 27, day care centres 21, self-referrals 21, probation services 20, the Department of Social Security seven, homemakers four and others 50. Those are the figures for September 1981 to September 1983. The fact that we do not have figures is a cause for great concern. I believe that little will be accomplished unless we have the data from all the States. I think it is up to the Commonwealth Government to try to encourage the States to get their data up to scratch. Perhaps we could then collate it and publish it so that we know the extent of the problem in Australia.
I conclude by quoting from Professor Lewis's paper. He said:

. . . children must have advocates in our community if their rights are not only to be protected, but also to be recognised. Children's voices are soft; it is the duty of all professionals working in fields such as child abuse to make certain that they are heard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As previous speakers in the debate have said , it is extremely difficult to know the extent of the problem we are debating today. On conservative estimates, in Australia 30,000 children per year suffer from some form of sexual abuse and, conservatively, 13,500 children are reported as being deliberately physically injured per year in Australia. Over the last few months I have made efforts, through the police departments in the various States to try to ascertain the number of children who go missing in Australia every year. It is impossible to tell. On those conservative estimates, we are facing a massive social problem and one which really, in terms of the future of the country, will have a detrimental effect probably beyond all other events which are occurring now. As other speakers have said, the injuries suffered by children are not something that happen and then are put aside. Those children have to live with them and, in many ways, they carry the injuries with them. All too often, unfortunately, they are something that they, in turn, inflict on their own children.

SPEECH.PARA: The setting for most of the violence about which we talk is in the family. This , I believe, requires and is currently receiving attention from various groups. Not so long ago we discussed in this place the issue of divorce. I want to look, not at the families that break up, but rather at the families that stay together and in which there is constant tension and conflict, wife bashing, child abuse and misery. It is in those families that we find our most difficult social problem because when the family breaks asunder it is often at that point that other groups within the community such as social welfare agencies come forward and assist. Really, this is the paradox of the problem. The problems that children suffer in a divorce situation are not necessarily as massive as the problems that children suffer in families that stay together. If a family remains as a unit it is extremely difficult for the community to intrude into its affairs. The family tends, very often, to cover up. Indeed, there are many cases, when one looks at the histories that are provided in a sanitised way by various agencies or hospitals, where it is in the family situation that the mother often covers for the father with an incest problem or vice versa and where the parents collude to concoct a story as to how a child suffered some appalling injuries. Senator Haines mentioned the case of a child having his body burnt with a blow torch. Other examples include a boy who is deaf because his father punched him on his ears, an 18-year-old child admitted to hospital with seven fractured ribs and broken legs and a child who spent nearly a year locked up in a cage. These are examples from Australia, from within our own enlightened society.

The personal tragic problems of children unfortunately are not often raised in debate in this place. In many ways, children do not have the political clout or the public advocacy that other groups have. Oddly enough, it seems that in this country in many ways animals are more of a concern to many people than children. The types of problems that children suffer range right across the board. Indeed, in just a small handful of problems, we could come up with every conceivable inhumanity committed by one person upon another. I refer to a survey that was taken in Queensland in 1980 by Women's House Shelter and Rape Crisis which is a women's refuge. It was well advertised. It was a telephone survey on incest in which victims of incest or their friends were asked to phone the centre in three days. The respondents were asked a series of questions within the constraints of a supportive counselling interview. One hundred and eighty-eight people contacted the centre: 108 victims, five assailants and 75 friends or relatives of victims. Victims of alleged intercourse were as young as one-year-old and the incidence of incest often went over 16 years of age or more. Twenty-four of the callers said they had been raped and molested by more than one relative, generally a family member as well as a near family member. In 14 cases the sexual relationship was still continuing. The overwhelming point to incest was that it was a male assailant and a female child phenomenon. Over 75 per cent of the assailants were male and a similar percentage of victims were female. Half of the victims were under 11 years of age when incest first occurred. That is one quite small survey. It is very difficult to know the validity of it. When one listens to the people who took the survey, one is struck very much by the reality of the problems that faced the people who contacted the women's refuge. That was one small survey carried out in my State of Queensland. I am quite sure it would have been duplicated with increased numbers in every State of Australia .

Previous speakers have said that the large problem in this area is non- detection and non-reporting. Indeed, something which falls within the purview of the Federal Government is the lack of national standardisation of available statistics and definitions. That makes it very difficult to obtain comprehensive statistics relating to the problems of child abuse and then, upon these statistics, to base appropriate policy initiatives. The current Government has investigated this matter, through an interdepartmental committee, and presumably the Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes, will tell us how far we have been able to go down that road towards obtaining an adequate understanding of the extent of the problem. I believe the usefulness of having that understanding is not simply that we happen to know how many people have been abused but rather the enormous problem that undoubtedly would be uncovered by adequate statistics would impel us to undertake action. During the Liberal Party policy speech in the 1980 general election, the then Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, undertook that his Government would:
. . . with the States and voluntary organisations . . . establish a national children's foundation to help tackle the problems of child abuse.

It is a pity that that proposal never went ahead. As a policy, it was extremely far-sighted. It is unfortunate that in the following three years it did not occur because I believe that if it had we may now, in 1983, in this debate be more adequately informed and have a greater comprehension of the problem which we are attempting to tackle.

I raise another question in this area which is not often thought of, but it is a problem which is of just as much concern as those that I have already raised. I refer to children who run away from home. What we are often confronted with is an inability on the part of our various organisations to cope with and understand the extent of the problem. For example, I have not been able in Australia to get figures comparable with those I was able to obtain for the United States. Every year in the United States 100,000 children run away from home. In addition, an estimated 20,000 to 50,000 children a year simply disappear. Undoubtedly some of these children return home but every year in the United States 2,000 missing children are discovered dead. That is a massive, incredible problem. When I read that a few months ago I sought from police departments whether we had any comparable data. I was unable to get any although I was told that, per capita, the problem in Australia is identical to that in the United States. If that is the case, we have on our hands another problem, a problem which often is hidden and tucked away, rarely brought together to assume the enormity that it would assume if we could view the problem as a whole each year. Of course not all of these children come to an untimely end but many of them become involved in child pornography or in drugs--

TALK.START.PARA: —Or prostitution.

—And prostitution. Again, it was impossible to find accurate figures on this aspect but when one talks to the social welfare agencies in areas where this is a peculiar problem one finds that they all say, without exception, that it has dramatically increased since the recession. That is understandable and is acceptable in that it is what we expect might occur, but it is totally unacceptable that we have not yet taken the first step to come to grips with that massive and very real problem.

SPEECH.PARA: I think even those people who are able to take other pornography in their stride certainly cannot take in their stride the repulsive situations that occur in pornographic films being made with children often as young as three years old . Indeed, they are made more repulsive and to my way of thinking less understandable when the vast bulk of the adults involved are their parents.

That is a tale of woe and an extent of woe that I believe is important to raise at this time of year and I hope that the Minister for Social Security, speaking next, might be able to clarify where we are heading in Australia in relation to this at the Federal level. Of course the vast bulk of the work that must be done in this area has to be done by State governments. It is a State government responsibility. They are finding it very difficult to cope. I believe that if we could at the national level follow the suggestion of Malcolm Fraser in 1980 and set up a national children's foundation to bring together State and Federal governments and the various voluntary agencies, we would start to bring together the people who have a deep and abiding concern for the rights and the lives of these children. If that could occur, my hope would be that in a few years time in a debate like this we might be able to say that we have taken some steps forward in tackling this very real, very tragic human problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance raised by Senator Haines is a serious and important one. I think everyone in the Senate agrees with that. It is worded as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The alarming and increasing incidence of physical, emotional and sexual abuse of children, particularly within family units, and the lack of readily accessible support mechanisms for these children and their families.

Those matters should be of concern to us all although, like Senator Walters, I will raise some questions about the first part of the matter proposed for discussion. Certainly we cannot do justice to this discussion in 15-minute speeches over an hour or so but we can assist in the process of raising the level of awareness in the community about this important subject and particularly we can impress upon all authorities and all parliamentarians the necessity for what Senator Haines describes as readily accessible support mechanisms for the people in this area.

The problem of child abuse in society is a problem with which society has always had difficulty coming to grips. On the one hand there is general abhorrence at the abuse of children, be it sexual, emotional or physical. One knows the abhorrence through all levels of society for people who are caught in such situations. On the other hand, there has always been a great reluctance not only in parliaments but also in the society in general to raise to a rational level the level of discussion of these unfortunate instances. Although we have come a long way in recent times and are willing to discuss this matter without putting down the importance of the subject we should question the tendency to assume that the underlying level of child abuse, whether it is sexual, emotional or physical, has in fact increased alarmingly in our society in recent years. That is a point Senator Walters made. The first point is that there is more than a grave doubt that this is a fact and the second point to make, again made by Senator Walters but also Senator Macklin, is that tragically, in this supposedly enlightened era, because of the lack of information we just do not know what the incidence is in recent times compared with past times. There certainly has been, thank heavens, an increased interest, an increased awareness and an increased desire to help, and certainly there has been a rapid increase in the literature available and the research carried out in this area. I point out that this does not necessarily mean an underlying increase in the incidence.
I think a proper perspective is best summed up by the final report of the Royal Commission of Human Relationships, which said on this subject, on page 159 of Volume 4:

The way children are treated in our society relates to the way we value children and the way we define their rights. It relates to the degree of submission and conformity we expect from children and the extent to which we sanction physical force as a means of getting children to obey.

The fact that our society is now concerned with the problem of child abuse does not mean that parents have suddenly taken to beating their children, but that our tolerance to child maltreatment has declined, and we are now appalled by acts to which our ancestors would have been indifferent. It is part of a growing awareness that the human rights, dignity and integrity of every man, woman and child should be protected.

I think it is also worth recalling that child abuse, which was considered abnormal even in the last century, was known in the last century and reported by physicians and social commentators at the time. So we should remember that although we are more aware of the problem and although we are more keen to do something about it, to assume that something inherent in our society means that we have a great deal more child abuse than there has been in the past, is very questionable to say the least.

Another important point to remember I believe is that in considering the causes , the prevention and the treatment of child abuse we are dealing with a multitude of situations in which the common factor is abuse of children, but in fact the causes and the underlying factors are many. The victims of the deranged psychotics, the schizophrenic or depressive parent, the victims of the frustrated, emotionally immature and non-coping parent, the victims of the alcoholic, the parent with a low IQ, the psychopathic personality, the pedarist and at times just the ignorant, all appear together frequently in the statistics and in the media coverage of this problem. The victims of abuse in institutional situations, which we hope is less common than in the past, and in school situations, which we similarly hope is less common than in the past, equally may not be recognised as representing different facets of many different problems.

We also have to recognise-I think this came up in debate here yesterday-that what may be the norm in one religious or ethnic group may be viewed with distaste and as an abuse by another. So we are dealing with a multifactorial problem and we are dealing with a problem which involves far too many children, as Senator Macklin and other speakers have delineated. We are dealing with many different situations. What we do know is that child abuse, whatever the cause, is an important cause of death and disability and social and emotional ills in our society. We know also, as has been quoted by previous speakers, that the reported incidents are far exceeded by the unreported incidents, particularly in those cases within families. As well as this we know that people in the lower socio-economic groups are more likely to be reported because they are more likely to come into contact with the authorities and because they are more likely to use public facilities such as hospital out-patient facilities. Therefore I think every writer on the subject questions very seriously, and I certainly do, the usual truism that in fact this is mainly a problem of lower socio-economic groups.

I think one of the things that impress every medical practitioner such as I who goes into general practice, certainly in the time I trained, is the extraordinary incidence of violence within families, be it violence to children or violence between husbands and wives, which most of us or all of us in fact were not prepared for at all during our training. That strikes one wherever one practices. That was my experience and it was certainly the experience of colleagues of mine who graduated about the same time as I did.

We know also that earlier estimates, as recently as in the mid-1970s, of the extent of child abuse in this society particularly, were gross underestimates. One thing that the mandatory reporting or notification resulted in in New South Wales and other States was a fuller awareness of the extent of the problem. When I first became a member of this Parliament there was a tendency to believe that the figures in the United States for instance did not apply in this country and that there was something specially different about the United States and that we did not have anything like that problem. What has happened in recent times with reporting and with notification, with more careful research and with more careful looking into the subject, is that we find we are in the same boat as everybody else. What has been brought into stark relief is the fact that child abuse, baby battering et cetera, are almost certainly now the third most common cause of death in those under five years of age in our society and that innumerable children suffer tremendously each year but in fact do not die because of it.

It seems to me that everyone recognises the need to achieve certain conditions to tackle the problem. Firstly we need early recognition of and early intervention in cases of abuse and potential abuse. Secondly we need the provision of supportive services for those at risk and those already abusing and being abused to which such unfortunate people can be referred or to services to which they can go voluntarily, as they frequently will if those services are available and accessible. Thirdly we need a system of follow-up and long term assistance to prevent recurrences and to support the victims who suffer almost inevitable long term emotional and psychological trauma as a result of the situations they have been in.

Even though there is general recognition of the importance of these factors there is by no means unanimity on how to achieve that ideal state. I believe that everyone so far has talked about notification or mandatory reporting of cases and this would seem to be an automatically sensible procedure for us all to follow, but it is not without its critics and is not without questioning largely because the number of reported cases, even where there is mandatory reporting, is only a percentage of the whole, and that is accepted by everybody. The failure of the relevant authorities adequately to follow up such notification with the provision of adequate services, in fact, discourages reporting. In the higher socio-economic groups in our society there is a reluctance by doctors and others in positions of authority in fact to notify cases, and this does not apply only to the child abuse area; it applies to other notifiable diseases in our society generally. There is also the problem of the results of mistaken notification, and I have seen a couple of these, which are frequently tragic both for the parents and for the person who does the notification. I must say that certainly on balance I favour notification; firstly to protect those who would otherwise not be protected, however few they may be; secondly, to increase community awareness; and, thirdly, to put pressure on the relevant authorities to provide adequate resources and to provide those accessible services that Senator Haines talked about.

We need other things. We need improved training and a heightened awareness of doctors and others to the existence and the extent of child abuse. This can be achieved only through the education and training processes. As Senator Haines said, the chief need is for resources; resources in high risk areas for high risk families, resources which are accessible to those who need them and resources which cost money. The human resources needed in this area involve the provision of people with proper training, with sensitivity and a non-judgmental approach to the problem. I think it is important for us to realise that professional qualifications do not automatically result in this approach, but without a non-judgmental and sensitive approach the results can be catastrophic.

We have been talking about an area which impinges on many facets of human behaviour. It concerns medical, psychological, sociological and legal factors. It involves sensitive areas such as the rights of parents, civil liberties and privacy, but above all it involves the rights of the child and the duty of society to protect those rights. As Senator Haines I think put it, it is society 's problem. The handling of that problem, with all those pitfalls, involves a fairly sensitive approach and a fair bit of tightrope walking by authorities, but the rights of the child to safety and security and freedom from abuse are paramount. The Commonwealth Government gets embroiled with State governments in this area, but I believe in recent years we have been taking a more rational approach. The Commonwealth Government has taken part in the establishment of the Welstat secretariat to collect proper statistics to overcome the appalling problem of ignorance in this area, and if ever there were an area in which ignorance is not bliss but a sin, it is this.

In various sections of my Department and other departments, under the children' s services program, under the family support services and under the youth services scheme and even in the Attorney-General's Department where counselling is involved in the Family Court, there are many programs which are increasingly causing problems in this area. In that description lies one of the real problems that we have: The programs are fragmented between Commonwealth and State governments and they are fragmented between public and private agencies. That is a situation which is no longer satisfactory. The establishment, or attempted establishment, of the national children's foundation by the previous Government foundered on the old difficulty of Commonwealth-State relationships. There was an effort to set up that foundation. By the time I became Minister the negotiations had been protracted and difficult and in the end it was decided mutually that we would not proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —State governments have a lot to answer for.

—I am not necessarily just condemning them. However, I still believe with Senator Macklin that some sort of organisation like this or like the national centre in the United Kingdom, which will have to be a Federal initiative, where the Federal Government will have to be responsible for national standards and national statistics gathering, is the only way we can contribute sensibly at a national level on this subject. It is an important subject. It is a pity we cannot debate this matter further. I am sure we will in future. But at least the existence of this debate and the approach of honourable senators in the debate is a large step forward.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 December 1983, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill seeks to amend the Telecommunications (Interception) Act to enable transcripts and tapes of legally intercepted telephone conversations which may be relevant to proceedings before the New South Wales Special Commission of Inquiry headed by Mr Justice Cross to be forwarded to the inquiry at its request. The problem arises because the Telecommunications (Interception) Act has very properly very strict limits on the divulging of transcripts of tapes of intercepted telephone conversations. That Act lays down a very strict code in regard to the circumstances in which telephone tapping in this country can take place. It can occur only on warrants that have been obtained in two areas-by the Director-General of Security in matters relating to security and for the investigation of serious narcotic offences on application to a judge by the Australian Federal Police. The information obtained is to be used only in those two areas, except information which may be contained in such tapes which may be relevant to the possible commission of an offence carrying not less than three years imprisonment-so it is a serious offence-which may be passed to the relevant prosecuting authority. Except for the authorised purposes for which the interception has been made, this is the only way in which information can be divulged. The inquiry being conducted by Mr Justice Cross does not come within that authority. Therefore, the object of this Bill is specifically to deal with that problem. The Bill achieves that purpose and the Opposition fully supports and endorses it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill provides a rather different method of divulging the information from the scheme of the Act itself. It provides for the Attorney-General to exercise the authority to decide whether such a matter should be divulged. However, in the first place, as I said, there must be a request from the commission of inquiry. When such a request is obtained the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police must provide, as the Bill says, 'in his opinion' the matters which are relevant to the inquiry. That must then be provided to the Attorney- General who then makes, as I said, a decision whether or not to communicate. That seems to be a somewhat cumbersome arrangement, certainly compared with the form in which such material may be divulged, as I said, in the strict limitations under the existing Act. However, the Opposition can accept that this arrangement keeps a closer brake on the divulging of information because of the intervention of the Attorney-General. It certainly will not be left to the discretion of the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police to provide the information as it is under the existing legislation.

However, the Opposition is concerned about the way in which the Bill has been structured. We believe that the Attorney-General should have all conceivably relevant information available to him when he makes his decision. As I said, we believe this is a very cumbersome arrangement whereby the Commissioner of Police makes the decision in the first place as to what material is relevant and then passes that to the Attorney-General who decides what is to be conveyed to the inquiry. We believe that as the ultimate decision is to be made by the Attorney- General he ought to have all information which conceivably could be relevant. He should make the decision on what in fact is relevant as well as what ought to be conveyed. Therefore, the Opposition will be moving an amendment to this effect at the Committee stage.

Apart from that, as I said, the Opposition supports the principle of the Bill. We believe that it is justified to extend the principle of the existing legislation which has strict controls on the divulging of very sensitive material. We believe that an inquiry of the kind being conducted in New South Wales by Mr Justice Cross is of such importance that it justifies an extension of the principle. It is notorious, of course, that there are in existence some tapes which are relevant to this inquiry because this Government itself made a decision some time ago, as has now become common knowledge, that some transcripts or some tapes of intercepted conversations pursuant to a warrant are relevant to some aspects of the matter which has now become one of the subjects of Mr Justice Cross's inquiry. We hope that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), when he acquires the power under this Bill, will in fact make a thorough examination of the tapes, unlike the cursory examination that he gave them and which was the subject of some questions and discussion in this Senate a few weeks ago. With those observations, the Opposition supports this measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the Bill, which provides for the substance of phone taps undertaken by Federal authorities to be given, where the Federal Attorney- General sees fit to do so, to the New South Wales Special Commission of Inquiry headed by Mr Justice Cross. We are pleased that the Bill has been modified from the original draft by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), which would have provided for this general power to remain on the statute books and be applicable to all commissions of inquiry. As I understand it, the Australian Labor Party Caucus refined the proposal so that it would apply only to the Cross commission of inquiry and not remain on the statute books, to be applied to other inquiries. The Democrats support that refinement.

SPEECH.PARA: The debate over organised crime must lead to retaining a balance of civil liberties and it is our view that there is enough phone tapping going on in Australia at the moment. Measures which call for the exercise of caution in using material gained from these phone taps, such as this refined Bill provides for, are to be supported. The granting of a general power, under which the results of phone taps could have gone to any commission, would have produced a situation in which there were fewer safeguards and fewer checks and balances against buse.

However, we recognise that the Attorney-General must have authority-which is essentially political authority-to determine whether material gained from phone taps should be given to this particular inquiry, or withheld. However decisions of this importance, made by the Executive Government or by a member of it, the Attorney-General, should be open to scrutiny and review by the Parliament. The Attorney-General has recognised this because the Bill provides for a report to be made to the Parliament within 15 days of supplying transcripts to the New South Wales inquiry. I commend the Attorney-General and the Government upon that provision. However, the Democrats would like to see an addition to that provision incorporated in the legislation and will be moving accordingly in Committee. Our proposed amendment will ensure that the Attorney-General will also report to Parliament when he has decided not to give transcripts to the New South Wales inquiry. It provides not only for that notification to be given, but also for the Parliament to be given the reasons for the withholding of transcripts. In other words, under the Bill, if the Attorney-General decides to provide a transcript, he must report to Parliament within 15 days. We say that that should be extended to include cases where he has refused to give, or decided not to give, transcripts. Such a decision also ought to be reported to Parliament, with his reasons. We propose moving such an amendment because we recognise that a decision not to provide transcripts is as important as, if not more important than, a decision to provide them. Accordingly, Parliament should be informed of these decisions. We commend the Government and commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Opposition senators, the shadow Attorney-General and the Leader of the Democrats (Senator Chipp) for their general support of this legislation. Both Senator Durack and Senator Chipp have briefly explained its purpose. That is already on the parliamentary record in the second reading speech and I do not think that there is any need for me to take time to deal with the very obvious purpose of the legislation in this very obvious situation. The Government was mindful, of course, of the need to be able to respond quickly to calls likely to arise from the inquiry in New South Wales, and the legislation represents that response. Insofar as amendments have been foreshadowed, they are concerned mainly with limiting the measure as far as possible. Senator Chipp, in particular, pointed to the fact that the operation of the legislation was limited to this one inquiry in New South Wales. That is important. I think the desire is to ensure that as far as possible, within the necessary framework of confidentiality and so on which will have to apply in this process, safeguards apply in respect of parliamentary accountability for any actions taken by the Attorney-General under the legislation, if passed. They are matters that should appropriately be addressed in the course of the Committee stage of the Bill. Accordingly, I commend the second reading of the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —As foreshadowed, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 2, clause 3, proposed sub-paragraph 7A (4) (a) (ii), lines 31 and 32, leave out the proposed sub-paragraph, insert the following sub-paragraph:
''(ii) relates, or appears to relate, to the purpose of an inquiry, or may be otherwise incidental to or connected with the subject matter of that inquiry; and''.

The Bill provides that where the Attorney-General receives a request, and decides that it is appropriate, he may direct the Commissioner to ascertain whether there is in the possession of the Australian Federal Police any information lawfully obtained by interception, or by a warrant, of course, that may be in the opinion of the Commissioner relevant to the purpose of an inquiry. The Opposition's amendment would replace the phrase which leaves the complete discretion to the Commissioner of Police in determining what is relevant with the words:
Relates, or appears to relate, to the purpose of an inquiry, or may be otherwise incidental to or connected with the subject matter of that inquiry.

That provision is, I believe, wider than the provision in the Bill. The Commissoner would not then, in the first place, make the judgment as to what is relevant but will pass to the Attorney-General material apparently relating or incidental to the inquiry and the Attorney-General will then make the decision whether it is relevant, and whether it would be appropriate to communicate it. We believe that as the effective decision is to be made by the Attorney-General he should also determine the question of relevance. That is the purpose of the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the amendment moved by Senator Durack.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a brief comment and express a concern that has already been expressed elsewhere regarding this Bill and the powers given under it. As Senator Chipp has indicated, it is obvious that the orginal intention of the Attorney-General was refined, and with cause. There is also, no doubt, to be a review of the problems which arise under this legislation. The concern, of course, is that there is increasing interception. There is possibly a danger of information being gathered that is not relevant to the purpose for which the warrant was issued. It is the use of that information which concerns many of us. I do not know whether the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) who is in charge of the Bill at this time can answer the question I wish to ask. Nevertheless, I think it is important to ask this question: Is the obligation of the Director-General of Security under section 14 of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 to destroy records being efficiently carried out? Is that provision of the Act being efficiently carried out? It is important that those records, once they cease to be relevant, be destroyed as the Act provides. Are adequate security and other methods being instituted to prevent any unlawful communication of information gathered under section 20 of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979? Are all facilities provided and adequate methods instituted to ensure that the Commissioner of Police can carry out without delay the obligations under section 24 of the Act to destroy records and copies so that there will be no neglect in the ascertaining and destroying of all records and all copies which are not required and not likely to be required for the purposes stated in the Act? I do not expect the Minister to be able to answer that at this stage. It is important for me to indicate my concern that there may be some neglect in relation to the carrying out of provisions of the original Act.

SPEECH.PARA: I am also pleased-the Government has accepted this point-that the powers to reveal information have been limited to this particular inquiry. I believe that in some future debate the reasons for limiting, to a particular inquiry, the powers of this amendment to the Act will be revealed. There is a grave danger that the police forces of this country will be encouraged to widen the interception of communcations with the added ability to do so outside the law. They could gather information concerning the activities of citizens and use that information in, shall we say, both a covert as well as an overt way in order to intimidate. Evidence has appeared in New South Wales that certain sections of organised crime-unfortunately this applies to Queensland and certain sections of the police force special branch-are prepared to gather information by whatever means is made available to them, to withhold that information from general distribution and to make it available only to the persons concerned so as to intimidate and to impose upon them limitations in the carrying out of his of her public duties. Evidence has arisen in the Queensland Parliament that files and information received by means that could only be related to interception of communications have been used against individuals by special branch officers through members of Parliament. The whole of this area, of course, is fraught with concern. I merely introduce that concern at this stage. I hope that at a later stage, before we give any extra powers to the law enforcement authorities, we have a wide-ranging debate about the consequence of those extra powers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a similar matter to that which has been brought forward by Senator Georges. I acknowledge that there is increasing concern within the community about the extent of unauthorised telephone taps. My concern goes even further to what might be recognised as authorised telephone taps which may require a particular warrant or authority. My question to the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) is: When a radiotelephone hook-up is used, for example between here and Brisbane-I think also there are lines to Melbourne using radio waves-is it possible that anyone, including representatives from foreign governments, using appropriate equipment can connect into ordinary telephone conversations without authority?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will deal with the matters raised by Senator Georges first. I am not, as he surmised, able to answer the question as to whether the Director-General of Security is carrying out his functions efficiently under the principal Act in terms of the destruction of records and the obligation that he has to destroy records. That is a matter which peculiarly has to be directed by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) as a question to the Director-General. I will certainly convey the substance of Senator Georges's questions to the Attorney-General. It is not even a matter that I think comes within the province of his Department. It is very much a ministerial matter. Apart from that, I think Senator Georges raised a number of issues which articulated in a precise and lucid way a set of general concerns that I certainly have and I am sure a lot of other honourable senators have about these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: In a sense the question raised by Senator Watson falls into the same category. I cannot give an authoritative answer to Senator Watson's question as to whether a telephone hook-up can be tapped into, if that is the appropriate expression. The answer I can give in a qualified way is that I believe that is so. I believe that it is technically possible. On the basis of my own slight knowledge of communications technology, I certainly believe that that is so in respect of a wide range of telephone conversations and so on that might appropriately be regarded as private. In a sense, this question is very much directed to the technical capacity to do it. I am sure that the ill will, or whatever the appropriate expression is, exists if the technology is available. My belief is that the technology is available and that those things can happen. It is probably a very good rule of thumb never to say anything on the telephone that one would not say in the city square into a microphone.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not even to your wife?

—That is a matter that I ask each individual honourable senator to sort out for himself, Senator Chipp. It is not a matter upon which I would wish to pronounce a view. Insofar as the amendment which has been moved by Senator Durack is concerned-it is accepted and supported by the Australian Democrats-I want to make it clear that the Government does not oppose it. In a sense it puts a different emphasis on that part of the Bill, I think appropriately so, in that it involves the Attorney-General more in making a judgment on the basis of what relates to the purpose of the inquiry and what is relevant material. It is not a matter about which the Government wishes to enter into any contest with the Opposition parties. The amendment is accepted.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I move my amendment, I ask a question concerning clause 4 of the Bill. The Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) may not be able to give me an answer directly, but I would appreciate it if, at the conclusion of the debate, he could provide an answer. I do not have the precise details with me but, as I understand it, one of the matters into which Mr Justice Cross is to inquire is an allegation by a journalist that he had information that a magistrate had lunch with certain people and that as a consequence of that lunch, a certain charge against a certain person was dropped by that magistrate. As I understand it, that is one of the matters into which Mr Justice Cross has been asked to inquire. My question is: Would clause 4, or any other clause of the Bill, cover a situation in which Mr Justice Cross asked the Attorney-General, as provided for under clause 3, for any tape recording or transcript of a phone tap relating to that matter and the Attorney-General passes it on to the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police? Would this Bill allow that transcript to be transmitted to Mr Justice Cross? Has a 'relevant offence', as defined in clause 3, been committed? Is it enough under the terms of the Bill for an allegation of a relevant offence to have been made, as is the case in this particular instance ? I can understand the simple machinery that is invoked if a relevant offence has been committed, but I wonder about the situation in which an allegation of a relevant offence has been made. I presume that, if a magistrate improperly dismissed a charge, that would be a relevant offence; but at this stage it is clearly only an allegation: Would that situation be covered by the Bill?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chipp has outlined a particular circumstance as an example to illustrate his question. The answer to the question Senator Chipp has asked is simply this: If an allegation becomes the subject matter of an inquiry, it is not necessary for an offence to have been committed for this legislation to operate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Chipp

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister to clause 3 (a) (ii). Clause 3 (a) relates to information that:

INTERJECT.PARA: (i) is relevant to the purpose of the inquiry; and
(ii) relates, . . . to . . . a relevant offence . . .
The provision does not say 'or'; it says 'and'.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I read that clause, it relates to information that is relevant to the purpose of the inquiry. It would be necessary to look at the purpose of the inquiry. Senator Chipp directed his attention particularly to a term of reference of the inquiry. The word joining that provision and the next is 'and'. Paragraph (ii) then states:

SPEECH.PARA: (ii) relates, or appears to relate, to the commission, or intended commission, of a relevant offence specified in the notice of the request;

It does not mean that an offence has to be committed. It may be that somebody intended to commit an offence and that is the allegation, or it may be that it relates to an offence or appears to relate to the commission of an offence. I follow that on by going back to what I was saying. An offence does not have to be committed to invoke the provisions of this Bill in relation to this inquiry which is referred to in the earlier clauses of the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the reasons outlined in the second reading debate, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 3, clause 3, proposed new sub-section 7A (8), lines 18 to 25, leave out the proposed sub-section, insert the following sub-section:

' ''(8) Where the Attorney-General decides under sub-section (6) to communicate or not to communicate, as the case may be, information, he shall, subject to sub -section (9), cause to be laid before each House of the Parliament, within 15 sitting days of that House after the decision is made, a document-
(a) if information is communicated in accordance with sub-section (6)-
(i) stating that information has been so communicated;
(ii) setting out the conditions (if any) imposed as to the use that may be made of the information; and
(iii) stating whether or not any approval has been given in accordance with sub -section (7) in relation to the information; or
(b) if the Attorney-General decides under sub-section (6) not to communicate information-stating the reasons for his decision.'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, the Opposition supports this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has no objection to this amendment. It provides for an additional degree of parliamentary responsibility, which, I think, is generally welcomed.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have circulated a second amendment to clause 3 which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 3, Clause 3, proposed new sub-section 7A (11), lines 34 and 35, leave out the proposed sub-section.
The proposed sub-section reads:
(11) Subject to the Constitution, a decision of the Attorney-General under this section is not subject to review by any court or other tribunal.

I am really in two minds whether to proceed with my second amendment. I can see some reasons for having this particular provision. Normally, one would be very concerned indeed about such a provision. I hope this chamber will take very strong exception to a clause of this kind which would mean that the Attorney- General would not be subject to ordinary judicial review in relation to a decision made by him. I can see that there are some special reasons. Because of the very confidential nature of the information about which the Attorney-General makes the decision, it would be hard to see how any judicial review could possibly be commenced, because anybody who would be aggrieved would not even know of the decision until after it had been made and carried out. There is, of course, a parliamentary means of reviewing the Attorney-General's decision, as we have already passed an amendment to a clause in the Bill which puts the widest possible obligation on the Attorney-General to inform the Parliament of what he has done or not done.

I am disturbed about any clause of this kind appearing in legislation in this day and age. We have developed major initiatives in this Parliament in recent years on a bipartisan basis to expand greatly the rights of the citizen. Aggrieved people who have grievances against administrative decisions affecting them have the right to have those decisions reviewed either on their merits or by a court if such decisions are alleged to be contrary to law. I do not think that there should be ever inserted into any legislation now or in the future, in view of the great pioneering work that has been done in this Parliament in recent years on a bipartisan basis, any provision which would diminish or derogate those principles without the matter being properly explained to this chamber. Therefore, although I am prepared to move the amendment, if the Minister at the table can give me some good reason for that provision being contained in this legislation, I will not proceed with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Durack has indicated that he is in two minds. That seems to me a pretty dangerous state to be in; but I will try to persuade him to one mind, whichever is appropriate. On the basis of what he said, I am not sure which that might be. I understand his general concern about the desire for conformity in legislation on an issue of this kind and his desire to continue with the practices which have developed in this Parliament. I just make the point that this is a special Bill introduced for a quite particular purpose which is specified in the Bill. The real function of the Bill is designed to expedite the flow of information, if required, from the Commonwealth to the inquiry to be conducted by Mr Justice Cross. It is the Government's view that if the amendment were carried and decisions by the Attorney-General were able to be reviewed by courts or tribunals, the process of exchange of information and the making available of information by the Attorney- General to Mr Justice Cross's Commission could be bogged down in technical legal arguments and challenges.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the attention of the shadow Attorney-General to the fact that in any case there are procedures in the Bill for the Attorney to put on the table of the Parliament details of communications that have passed from him to the inquiry. That position has been further strengthened by the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats, which has been agreed to. It is the Government's view that it would be inappropriate for a court or tribunal to be reviewing a decision of the Attorney-General as it may mean that sensitive information relating to drug investigations, narcotic inquiries and matters of that kind would be discoverable by that court or tribunal in the course of the review process. It is believed that the proper place for that sort of information should be before the court if and when charges are ultimately brought as a result of any investigations by the Federal Police and not as a result of a review procedure in relation to the Attorney-General's discretion under this legislation.

That is the Government's view of the matter. I appreciate the spirit in which Senator Durack's suggestion is put forward, but we think that with those considerations, confined as they are to this case-and we would not seek to set any precedent from this situation-in those circumstances this should be so treated as a particular case for a particular purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not had the benefit of Senator Button's eloquence in explaining the reasons why Senator Durack's amendment was not acceptable to the Government. I had the benefit of the advice from the officers, if they will pardon me, in less eloquent terms than those delivered by Senator Button, but just as compelling. I have informed Senator Durack that for those reasons and for the reasons that have just been given by Senator Button, the Democrats would not support the amendment circulated by Senator Durack, whilst seeing the force of it. We see the force of the amendment by the Democrats which has been accepted, and it goes part of the way towards meeting some of the concerns of Senator Durack and the Liberal Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Button has persuaded me to be of one mind instead of two on this matter as a result of what he has said; also, as a result of the great practical difficulties that anyone would have in being able to exercise this right if he had it, in these circumstances. Because of the very special nature of the exercise in which we are engaged, its very limited nature, as Senator Button has stressed, I shall not move the amendment that I have circulated. However, I am very pleased to note Senator Button's comments on behalf of the Government, and to note Senator Chipp's comments in acceding to them. This is a very special case and the Government will not be pursuing a policy of depriving people of the great rights that have been developed in recent years of judicial review of administrative decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to, with amendments; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Button) proposed:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I compliment the Government and the Opposition on the way in which this matter has been dispatched. It has been done with reason, logic and good sense. It has been a pleasure to participate in a debate such as this and to find the receptivity of the Government to suggestions made from this side of the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Public administration is thought to be not only arcane but also incapable of rational evaluation. This belief is often well founded when one looks at the annual reports of departments. On this occasion, however, I congratulate the Department of Health on producing this report, the first report from its new Director-General, Mr Willett, which sets out goals for the Department and goals for each division within the Department. Honourable senators will know that the Senate has had an interest in evaluation and has recommended that public administration be associated with goal setting as part of a rational process of public activity. To the best of my knowledge, the Department of Health, in producing the goal statements contained in this report, is the first department to have so moved. The Department deserves considerable credit for what it has set out to do.

The goal statements fall within two groups. First, there are those which relate to the Department itself, the departmental goals; secondly, there are the goal statements which relate to the divisions of the Department, to the State offices , and so on. I suggest that the quality of the goal setting is different as between the departmental goal setting and the goal setting within the divisions. The departmental goals deserve considerable praise. I look, for example, to the goal which says that the Department will seek to administer programs to contribute to the improvement of health throughout the world. That is at least a testable goal. One can come back and look at the functioning of this Department next year and evaluate its function against that goal. It has set out a testable statement. Similarly, when it identifies as a goal the administration of programs to ensure that individuals are not precluded from adequate access to health care, and then it lists a series of conditions, that again is a testable goal against which the functions of the Department of Health will be tested next year. Similarly, when it says that it wishes to ensure cost-effectiveness of programs, and it goes on with some more words, that again is a testable goal which the Department is seeking to achieve.

On the other hand, the Department lists a number of goals which are simply processes. The trouble with identifying processes as goals is that they really cannot be evaluated. One may say that one wants to run programs to encourage individuals to be more responsible for maintaining their health, but the running of programs is something that will be done anyhow, and the Department will come back and say: 'We have run the programs'. The goal that it should be seeking might be the improvement of individual health, or the goal might be the maintenance of a safe physical and social environment, because they are testable . Processes are not so testable or, if they are testable, the results are worth a lot less. Outcomes are testable.

I now turn to what the divisions have set out to do. I must say that the goal setting in the divisions has been patchy. Again, I give full credit to the Department of Health for going down the management by objectives road. If one looks at the Quarantine Division of the Department of Health, above all that should be able to identify outcome goals. Clearly, the Quarantine Division should aim to prevent the entry into Australia of a series of diseases. But the Division has no outcome goal for itself. It simply says that its goal is to plan , implement, administer and review policies and progams which were designed to prevent the introduction or spread of certain diseases. The goal of that Division clearly should be to prevent the introduction or spread within Australia of certain diseases. The statement, as it comes out, could be better.

On the other hand, the Public Health Division of the Department has some thoroughly admirable goals. The Public Health Division has set itself goals to prevent sickness, amongst other things. Its goals include improvement of the health of Aboriginals. Its goals are outcome goals which can be tested. I believe that this report reflects credit upon the Department of Health for the reasons I have outlined. Many of us in the Senate who have been interested in evaluation have valued goal setting. The fact that the Department of Health is going down this road is something that I believe will be good for public administration in this country and I wish the Department well in its endeavours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am interested in Senator Peter Baume' s remarks because, from my involvement in health, the debate about whether one can evaluate process or outcome has been a long running one. Many people suggest that it is much easier to evaluate the process than the outcome.
—Much safer, too.

—Yes, but it is more measurable. Yes, one can say 'We did it', but it is very difficult to measure whether or not one has changed the health status of the community. I suppose that if I look at some of the aims and goals, 'maintaining a physical and social environment free of hazards to health' is no doubt admirable, but I do not think we will ever achieve a freedom from health hazards. So I guess that we have to temper justice with mercy as ever and hope that in the process or program evaluation we take into account some measure of the outcome. I do not think we have too much dispute there but I am interested in Senator Baume's comments.

SPEECH.PARA: I was particularly taken with the extensiveness of the report and its thoroughness. Of course, I have not addressed myself to all of it but I was particularly interested to look at the occupational health section which comes under the heading of 'Social Health' and to notice that the Department has devoted quite an amount of effort and energy into promoting occupational health and safety practices within the Government's departments and instrumentalities as a first step. They have been very involved with the establishment of a code of general principles of occupational health and safety in Australian Government employment. They have also worked very closely with the National Health and Medical Research Council and the National Labour Consultative Council's Committee on Occupational Safety and Health.

Much of the rest of this section is devoted to listing the many occupational health programs or practices that the Department of Health has been involved in. While I am interested to read those, and I think they are important and ought to be done, it is not until we come towards the end of that section, where we see that interdepartmental consultations have begun concerning the establishment of a national institute of environmental and occupational health, which is one of this Government's most important policies-that we begin to look at the establishment of occupational health and safety planning rather than programs to deal with specific bits and pieces of occupational health and safety. While they are important, I do not believe that until now there has really been a thorough addressing of the prior to programs planning and administration so that occupational health and safety is not a series of piecemeal projects but part of an approach, to try to achieve the goal of maintaining a physical and social environment free of hazards to health and work place structures conducive to good health. I am certainly delighted that the Department is addressing these areas with the many efforts that it lists here.

I ought not get into assessing whether the number of inches in the book measures the commitment of the Department, but I do not mind putting on record that women's health covers half a page. It seems to be addressed to toxic shock syndrome and following that problem in Australia, and also to the change in cancer patterns and mortality from cancer amongst women in this country, with some research into caesarian section rates and conditions of births. I hope that in future women's health is a matter of more substantial consideration by the Department of Health but I appreciate that this may not be a full report of all its activities.

Again, I found it interesting under the heading 'Nursing and Health Facilities' to note that the Nursing (Standing) Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council, which is serviced by the Branch, met twice during the year. I hope that is no measure of the significance or importance placed by the Department on nursing. But, as I flipped through this report mention of nursing was infrequent and small. That is a considerable disappointment because I think the nursing profession probably has the most people in the field practising health, and I do not believe we can lightly ignore planning for the nursing profession if we are to try to look at total and adequate delivery of health services in this country.

Finally, I simply make a comment about an area headed 'Sectional Research, Occupational and Environmental Health Section' alluding to some very interesting research done in the Antarctica into the effects of cold on humans and the proposals to continue that to look at the effects of bush fires and heat stress on humans. There is a proposal currently before the Government for money to support that research which could possibly take place over the next summer. The research done last year by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's Division of Forests Research discovered things about bush fires that this country was quite unaware of and which has contributed enormously to what we might see by way of prevention of the horrible bush fires that this country suffered last year.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

This is the fiftieth report of the Commonwealth Grants Commission. The Commission is celebrating its jubilee this year and for half a century it has been the expert body which has made financial determinations to State and local government for funds from the Commonwealth Budget. The Commission was established in 1933 and in its third report in 1936 laid down the basic criteria which have persisted to this day by which it makes determinations of moneys paid to the States from the Commonwealth, particularly the criteria which enable the Commission to pay special grants to the States. Essentially, special grants are made to enable the States, by reasonable effort of their own, to function at a standard not appreciably below that of the other States so that they can deliver public services at a standard not appreciably below those of the better-off States of Australia.

Since 1910 special grants have been paid in this country but it was really the establishment of the Commonwealth Grants Commission which put the payment of special grants on a systematic and consistent basis. Over the years since 1910 four States of Australia have received special grants at various times. Tasmania , Western Australia, my State of South Australia and Queensland have all received special grants from the Commonwealth Grants Commission. Those grants have involved the Commission in general terms making comparisons with the so- called standard States of New South Wales and Victoria in arriving at those payments to the other States.

It is noteworthy that for the first 40 of the 50 years of existence of the Commonwealth Grants Commission its functions changed very little. But in the last 10 years we have seen some quite extraordinary changes to the role of the Commonwealth Grants Commission, beginning with the initiative in 1973 of the Whitlam Government to provide funds to local government for general revenue expenditure without strings attached. Initially, those grants were made on the recommendation of the Commonwealth Grants Commission but more recently it has had the role of determining the allocation of funds to local government between the States. It is noteworthy that in the Commonwealth Budget of this year $459m is to be paid to local government. The Commonwealth Grants Commission has had quite a key role in developing the system by which those funds are paid.

In 1978 we saw the commencement of the review of the tax-sharing relativities. That took several years, created a great deal of interest and finally resulted in recommendations to change the shares of the various States of Australia in Commonwealth tax-sharing funds. That determination is now being put into effect over a period so that the shares of the Australian States in the total tax cake from Canberra will be more in line with those determined by the Commonwealth Grants Commission.

In 1978 the Commission was also given a new function, to look at the finances of the Territories. It has done several examinations in respect to the Northern Territory and, more recently, has provided information on the position of finances to the Australian Capital Territory. The Commission, through its relativities and the share of tax-sharing funds determined by it for the States, has a role in the allocation of $8,500m from the Commonwealth Budget to the States and an extra $150m this year for special revenue assistance for the States. That is all being paid out on a formula laid down by the Grants Commission.

This report points to some problems that the Grants Commission has in respect of its precise role in determination of tax-sharing relativities. It has expressed concern about the lack of definition of its position in the present arrangements. This is something that will have to be looked at in the future by the Government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
