In fact, to my mind the one vital element which is lacking in the question and which is the most fundamental one is that the proposal abolishes fixed terms for senators. There is absolutely no reference to that at all. If I were sitting here preparing a draft proposal, which I am not, I would be inclined perhaps to move something along these lines: 'To abolish senators fixed terms and to provide that upon each occasion when the House of Representatives expires or dissolves one half of the Senate shall be dissolved'. I think that is a closer reflection of the truth. It removes the camouflage of what has been put to us by the Government.
—What you are suggesting is not even in Senator Walters's amendment.
—I am just lifting it to a higher plateau. On the basis of what is before us, I support Senator Walters.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Proposed new clause 28A, proposed Forms 1, 2, and 3, leave out 'To ensure that elections for the Senate and the House of Representatives are always held on the same day, and to adjust the terms of senators accordingly.' (wherever occurring), insert 'To give power to the Government of the day to call half the Senate to election at the same time as the House of Representatives and to adjust the terms of senators accordingly.'.
I do not think there is any point in my debating the amendment. I had intended to add my amendment to Senator Harradine's amendment.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Proposed new clause 28A, proposed Forms 1, 2 and 3, leave out '2: PARLIAMENTARY TERMS: To extend the maximum life of Parliaments from 3 to 4 years .' (wherever occurring), insert '2: PARLIAMENTARY TERMS: To extend the maximum terms of members of the House of Representatives from 3 to 4 years and of senators from 6 to 8 years.'.

It is obvious that there is considerable concern about the expression of the question on the parliamentary referendum proposal in relation to parliamentary terms as indicated by the three proposals. I intend to be very brief. I am sure that we have all read the proposals and understand what we are talking about. However, for the sake of people listening perhaps on the radio, although I should not imagine there are many left listening to this sort of debate, the proposal put by the Government is that instead of the long title of the Bill there is the short title 'PARLIAMENTARY TERMS' followed by the words 'To extend the maximum life of Parliaments from 3 to 4 years'. My proposal is that instead of that, the expression should read: 'PARLIAMENTARY TERMS: To extend the maximum terms of members of the House of Representatives from 3 to 4 years and of senators from 6 to 8 years'. The reason is fairly obvious. The Government's proposal, as it stands, makes no mention of the fact that senators would end up with terms of eight years. My proposal would make that quite clear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I foreshadow my amendment. I hold the view-I have maintained it before-that as far as possible we should try to keep to the long title of Bills. I hope in future we will always keep to the long titles. A lot of care should be taken to ensure that the long title is presented. Therefore, I think we should try as far as possible to keep the long title. I agreed that the Government's proposal to say 'To extend the maximum life of Parliaments from 3 to 4 years' is inadequate because it does not refer to the Senate and people may well be confused and think that that is going to be the term of the Senate as well. I know it is not right but people may well think that. I think that one must refer in the prosposal to the effect the legislation will have on both Houses.

SPEECH.PARA: My amendment, which I foreshadow, is actually the same as Senator Harradine's except I have added one word. The amendment seeks to include the word 'maximum' in the long title. The long title would then read: 'To alter the Constitution to extend the maximum duration of the House of Representatives and the terms of service of senators'. I think 'maximum' ought to go in because we recognise that it does not mean there will be no fixed three or four year term or no fixed eight year terms. That is the maximum. It may well be less. Of course, a Senate term may well be quite less. Those of us who have never seen a six year term- only the President in this chamber has ever seen a six year term-would be amazed if we ever got such a term. It may be a seven year term, it depends on when Parliament is called. There is no fixture involved. I think, therefore, the long title ought to include the word 'maximum' to indicate that the Parliament will not necessarily run for that period. Apart from that, my amendment is the same as that moved by Senator Harradine. I think we should stick as far as possible to the long title.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — As I have not moved my amendment I do not need to seek leave to withdraw it. I will not move my amendment because Senator Missen's amendment contains a perfectly valid point which was not picked up in my amendment. Having said that, though, it appears that we are moving a little away from the title of the Bills as we have done in the first proposal. Let us have a look at what the Government proposes to put to the people in respect of parliamentary terms. What the Government proposes to do is ask the people this question:

SPEECH.PARA: Do you approve the proposed alterations to extend the maximum life of parliaments from three to four years?

I think everyone around this chamber who has looked at the Bill will see that that is an inappropriate manner of putting forward the essence of the Bill. The title of the Bill is: 'An Act to alter the Constitution to extend the duration of the House of Representatives and the terms of service of senators'. The Bill then sets out the short title. The first part of the Bill deals with the Senate. It says this:
Section 7 of the Constitution is altered by omitting from the fourth paragraph 'six years' and substituting 'eight years'.

For the Government to say that the proposition to extend the maximum life of Parliament from three years to four years properly reflects the purposes of Bill , boggles the imagination. I think we should all agree that the Government's proposal is totally inadequate. What then should the proposal be? Having now seen Senator Lewis's proposal, I feel that what he is proposing is somewhat nearer to the point but only to the extent that it mentions that terms of senators are going to be extended from six years to eight years.

I am sorry that I have not been able to discuss the amendment with him because I have only just looked at it. However, the words 'to extend the maximum terms of members of the House of Representatives from 3 to 4 years' appear to need qualification. I am just wondering whether strictly speaking that is correct because I imagine the terms of members of the House of Reprsentatives commence from the date on which they are declared elected after the return of the writs. After all, the writs are the authority for holding an election and for the election of successful candidates. The writs must be returned 90 days after their issue. In turn they must be issued, from memory, not more than seven days from the dissolution of the House. Of course, the House need not sit immediately and normally it does not sit immediately after the return of the writs. Normally a month elapses before the House actually sits. It is three years from that date that we are talking about, so the Government could well be extending the terms of members of the House of Representatives to four years and 120 days.

TALK.START.PARA: —What?

—Yes. If one looks at the Constitution, one finds that that is so. That is my difficulty with what is proposed. The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) will be happy to know that I am coming around to supporting what is proposed, provided that he will agree to add a few more words. If it were to be said that the proposal was to extend the maximum life of parliament from three years to four years, and the maximum terms of senators from six years to eight years, that would truly reflect what is contained in the Bill.

—Could I suggest that you are supported by section 28 of the Constitution, which states that every House of Representatives term 'shall continue for three years from the first meeting of the House, . . .' It does not start from that point but continues from it. That backs up your argument.

—I acknowledge what Senator Missen has said relating to section 28 of the Constitution which states that every House of Representatives shall continue for three years from the first meeting of the House and no longer , but may sooner be dissolved by the Governor-General. I repeat that a true reflection of what is contained in the Bill would be what is described by the Attorney-General in his proposal with the addition of the words indicated by Senator Lewis 'and to extend the maximum terms of senators from six to eight years'.

— The proposition put by Senator Harradine seems reasonable. I think that when one looks at the actual terms that the Government proposes one appreciates that undoubtedly we run into trouble in relation to No. 2 by interpreting it in such a way as to indicate that No. 1 has been carried. That is essentially the difficulty of carrying these two propositions together, as it was in the drafting of the Bills themselves. What the Government has here is, I think, correct, whether No. 1 is carried or not. However, I believe that some of the other proposals, particularly that of Senator Lewis, have a certain amount of dependence upon the simultaneous elections provision being carried, to enable them to work correctly. I wonder whether Senator Harradine's point might be taken care of if, at the end of what is proposed, if the Government adds the words that it added to the simultaneous elections proposal-'and to adjust the terms of senators accordingly'.
—It does not mean from six to eight years.

—That might or might not be the case, unfortunately or fortunately, depending upon what happens with the simultaneous elections proposal. The difficulty is that it must be so framed as to be able to stand on its own merits, regardless of whether the simultaneous elections proposal is carried. That is my worry at the moment, with the various proposals that we have . Somehow or other we must make sure that it can stand on its own merits. The Government's proposal does at the moment. I felt that Senator Harradine's proposal to add words at the end was reasonable. Then again, technically, ' parliament' includes both the Senate and the House of Representatives and it can be understood to mean that the Parliament runs for that particular time and that the Senate runs for two parliaments, whatever those parliaments happen to be. It is very difficult to come up with anything very much better than what is already proposed.

—Senator Harradine said that the proposal of the Government was inadequate. I go one step further and say that the proposal, in that it does not mention that it is intended, by this referendum, to increase the life of the Senate, whether to eight years or eight years and three months, as I presently understand it to read, is deceptive, not merely inadequate.
—The Senate is part of the Parliament, surely.

—Yes. I say that not to mention that the life of the Senate is to be increased to eight years or eight years three months, or eight years and four months, whatever the period is, is deceptive. I do not believe that the people of this country will agree to giving anybody an eight year term. Therefore, I say that for the Government not to mention that the term of a senator will be increased to about that extent is deceptive. I would therefore very strongly support what Senator Lewis is saying, whilst agreeing with what Senator Macklin said a moment ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —After that bizarre contribution by Senator Townley-
—If you want to talk about bizarre things, I will mention what you said to me during a division today.
—Senator Townley happens to say that the question ought not to be phrased in a particular way because the electorate is likely to answer in the negative.
—It was very unparliamentary.
—It will be even more unparliamentary if you do not mind your own manners in the future and the way in which you conduct yourself in this place.
—I was being polite to you and you were being most impolite to me. If you want a point of order on it right now, you will get one.
—Order! The honourable senator will address his remarks to the Chair.

—Through you, Mr Chairman, I object to your referring to my colleague in that way. I believe you should consider what you have said and moderate your language, otherwise we might keep you here till Christmas time.
—You are referring to the Chairman?
—Order! Tempers are becoming a little frayed, and I think some intemperate remarks may have been made. The Attorney-General must address his remarks through the Chair.
—Let me recommence-at the beginning-
—Well, be polite.
—Just calm down.

—Let me begin at the beginning once again. There is a certain fundamental principle of communication which says that if you want to convey a message to anybody, including a voter-and I presume that is the unanimous desire of all honourable senators in this place-you use concrete language rather than abstract language; you use simple and short language rather than long and convoluted language. The difficulty with the language of the long title as it now stands, the difficulty with the language of Senator Missen's amendment as it now stands, the difficulty with the language that Senator Macklin was proposing as possibly apropriate to add to the tail end of this in each case is they are couched in obscure and abstract language rather than precise and concrete language. They talk in terms of extending duration but do not use '3', '4', '6' or '8' for that matter. As such, it is just likely to look to the average voter coming in to confront it as a long line of lawyerly mumbo- jumbo. If any of us is genuine about wanting to ensure that people do understand what they are being asked to decide upon, he will agree that they ought to be confronted with language that is readily understanble. That is the essential reason why the Government has proposed that all this language be stripped back to its simplest and most concrete form to talk in terms of simply extending the maximum life of parliaments from three years to four years.

SPEECH.PARA: Everyone is familiar with talking in terms of parliaments. For instance, we are sitting now in the 33rd Parliament. We are used to talking in terms of parliaments having a life of three years, at the moment. What this particular proposal is about will be readily understood. The Government could well lay itself open to a charge of selectivity or possibly even deception, were it to say 'to extend the life of the House of Representatives or the terms of service of members of the House of Representatives from three to four years' and then say nothing about the position of senators. That would be being selective. That would be choosing just to focus on one side of a two-sided equation. But that argument does not hold when the language here employed is, in fact, chosen- language referring to 'parliaments' rather than to 'House of Representatives'. Under those circumstances I do not believe it is necessary for me to say very much more, observing Senator Lewis's stricture, except to say that if anything I prefer Senator Lewis's language to that of Senator Missen and the other more abstract and vague language because it is concrete and at least it does make the point which many people in Australia seem to fail to appreciate at the moment- this has been shown in research that has been done for us already-that is, that we are elected to the Senate for six years at the moment. Very few people seem to be aware that that is the case. One of the reasons they are so upset, as indeed many people are, by the notion of extending the term to eight years, is that they do not appreciate that we have six-year terms at the moment. At least Senator Lewis's proposition makes that clear. To that extent it makes it rather easier, I think, to convey to the electorate that no very substantial change is involved in this amendment after all. But I think the issues are remarkably clear on this matter. There is not much more any of us can do than vote upon it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans) recognises that the amendment moved by Senator Lewis has merit. It is all very well for you to talk about extending the terms of the Parliament--
—Are you referring to the Chairman again when you say 'you' ?

—I address my remarks through the Chair. I would like to talk to the proposition that was put by the Attorney-General in his simplistic, humble, honest and forthright way without wanting to delude the electorate at all. If people come to me and tell me that they have no objection to extending the life of the Parliament from three to four years I ask the question: 'What do you think about extending the life of the Senate from six to eight years?' They say: 'We did not think about that'. I am glad to say to you, Mr Chairman, that I appreciate the acknowledgment of Senator Evans in support of Senator Lewis's amendment. I support the amendment. I gather from what the Attorney-General said that the Government supports it. We need say no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — I foreshadow that I will move an amendment which incorporates what is generally agreed to be the appropriate course. The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) said that the benefit of Senator Lewis's proposal was that it was clear, unequivocal and presumably reflects the content of the Bill. Senator Lewis's amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: To extend the maximum terms of members of the House of Representatives from 3 to 4 years and of senators from 6 to 8 years.

I have explained why the word 'terms' is not appropriate. I have simply provided to extend the maximum life of the House of Representatives. I believe the words 'House of Representatives', are more appropriate than is the word 'Parliament' because this proposal is to reflect what is contained in the Bill. Clause 4 of the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill 1983 talks about the House of Representatives. It does not talk about the Parliament. In fact by voting for this measure the people will be changing the Constitution. What part of the Constitution will they be changing? They will be changing, as the Bill says, section 28 of the Constitution. They will be changing it in this way:
Section 28 of the Constitution is altered-
(a) by omitting three years and substituting 4 years; and
(b) by adding at the end thereof the following paragraph: In relation to a House of Representatives-
not the Parliament-

whose first meeting occurred before the commencement of the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) 1983, the last proceding paragraph has effect as if the reference to 4 years were a reference to 3 years'.

In fact that is why I agree with Senator Lewis that the words 'House of Representatives' should be included. When the people vote they will be voting to alter the term of the House of Representatives. They will not be voting to alter the terms of members of the House of Representatives but the term of the House of Representatives. The amendment which I foreshadow and which will be circulated shortly in my name in part states:
. . . to extend the maximum terms of service of senators from 6 to 8 years'.

That is precisely what the Bill means. I should like to come back to the point made by Senator Macklin. In his contribution he more or less presupposed that the first proposition, the simultaneous elections proposition, will be carried. Who is to say that the simultaneous elections proposition will be carried? It may not be carried.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will not be carried.

—Exactly, Senator Jessop; it will not be carried. In fact there are honourable senators in this chamber who strongly oppose the simultaneous elections provision but who support this provision to increase the term of the House of Representatives from three to four years. I think Senator Hill is in that situation. Senator Jack Evans is in that same situation. They oppose the first proposition of simultaneous elections but support the change to the term of the House of Representatives. If the people will follow the recommendations of those two honourable senators they will reject the first proposition and accept this proposition. The Australian Democrats have said all along the line that they want these matters to go truthfully to the people, no matter whether they agree with them or not. The policy of the Australian Democrats is that referenda should go to the people. If referenda should go to the people let us put the questions to the people as they are contained in the legislation. Let us not hide anything. The amendment which I foreshadow is simply a refinement of Senator Lewis's proposition to extend the maximum life of the House of Representatives from three to four years and to extend the maximum terms of service of senators from six to eight years. That is how I believe the proposition ought to be put to the people. I hope the people will solidly defeat it. (Quorum formed)

—I support Senator Harradine's amendment. I take pleasure in asking Senator Chipp just one question. He indicated to me earlier today when we were debating these amendments that he doubted whether people would bother to read what was in their letter boxes. I agreed with him that people know very little about how parliament works. Unless they read every bit of the material in their letter boxes, they will be completely unaware that the life of the Senate is to be extended to eight years. It is all very well for the Attorney-General to say that the Parliament is to be extended from three to four years. I ask Senator Chipp how many people in Australia really know that senators will serve eight years if it is said that parliament will be extended from three to four years? Does Senator Chipp really believe that words to the effect that the Parliament will be extended from three to four years clearly indicate to the people of Australia that if that occurs the Senate will be extended from six to eight years?

—I make it clear for the record that the Government opposes the amendments of Senator Lewis and Senator Harradine for reasons set out by Senator Macklin. The Government does not want to play around with the suggested alternative tentatively proposed by Senator Macklin, because of its abstract and non-concrete character. We believe that the language of the present provision is concrete, sharp, precise, and non-deceptive . I am sure that at the conclusion of the No case there will be no misunderstanding on the part of the Australian people about the implications of this proposal for the terms of senators.

—I pay Senator Walters the courtesy of answering her questions. I agree with her. In fact, I am glad that she now acknowledges part of the thrust of my interjection today that many Australians do not really absorb with the fascination that we politicians do the pros and cons of any referendum issue. I agree, if she wants me to, that there will not be very many people who will look at this question on the notice paper and say: 'Hah! If they are increasing the maximum term of the House of Representatives to four years, therefore the term of the senators will be eight years'. I concede that point. But that does not necessarily lead me to a view that we should put the wording that Senator Harradine or Senator Lewis suggests on the ballot paper.
—Why not?

—Why do we not put the salary of politicians on it? Why do we not put all explanations? What attracted me about the progressive idea of the Government-I call it a progressive idea because in my adult life I have voted in so many referenda in which on the ballot paper has been printed simply the title of the Bill; I would not have had the faintest idea what the question meant-is that at least it is an honest attempt-
—That is right.
—I believe it is an honest attempt. Honourable senators might suggest-
—Inept, but honest.

—To that extent, the honourable senator might say it is inept, but I do not agree with that. I think it is an efficient, 'ept', an honest attempt to put in the mind of the voter when he or she is in the cubicle the information on what he or she is voting for. To embellish that information with all sorts of other considerations that are caught up in the question would be to have almost an essay on the matter. I think it is an honest question to put to electors whether they approve of the maximum life of a parliament being extended to four years. If honourable senators say that means that senators from now on will have an eight-year term, I suggest that the likelihood of an eight-year Senate term is almost in the land of the fairies. In practice, this is not the case. We have had a number of short term Parliaments. The average length of parliament since Federation, as I understand it, is two years and four months. Therefore, while I concede Senator Walters's point-I did not want to enter this debate because it has been capably handled for the Democrats by Senator Macklin-out of courtesy, I have risen and given Senator Walters, I hope, an honest response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that many of the amendments with which we are dealing are being taken on the run. There have been three amendments with regard to one section of the Bill. As I see it at the moment the Democrats do not know what the Liberal Party is doing and the Liberal Party certainly does not know what the Labor Party is doing. I think it would not be a bad idea for this country if we sought an adjournment on this motion so that the Whips, the Government and the Australian Democrats can get together and work this out. At the moment, some motions that should not be defeated most probably will be defeated, and some that should not be carried will be carried. The whole thing is getting to a quite ridiculous state. The Democrats do not know what the Liberal Party will support, although they have certainly heard from the Attorney -General which ones the Government will support.

SPEECH.PARA: I see that we have 14 minutes before the Senate is due to adjourn this evening. I see that I have about 13 minutes to go. I do not intend to take that time, but I do not want to see passed in this chamber legislation that is not properly thought through. I think that we should have a brief adjournment and come back later tonight. I am not saying that we should put off consideration of the legislation until tomorrow, but if we do not know quite what is happening we will have to talk this through. We could negative the adjournment or come back tomorrow or next week to fix up this thing because at the moment it is a total mess. The Attorney-General is the guy who is responsible for the mess that this country is getting into.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that it is very difficult for people in the electorate-I would like Senator Chipp to listen to me on this-to understand what the word 'parliament' means. I think that is the point. I know that Senator Chipp and his colleagues are very fair about wanting to present the people with the facts about these things so that it is clear in their minds. I believe that the question of the extension of the life of the Parliament from three to four years is very difficult for many people in the community to understand. I would be grateful if I could be afforded the courtesy of the Attorney-General listening to me, rather than perambulating around trying to coerce people into supporting his attempts to subvert the issue. It is very difficult for people to understand the issue. People have come to me and said: ' What is this extension of the Parliament to four years all about?' I tell them that it means an extension of the term of the House of Representatives to four years, but it also means an extension of the Senate term to eight years. I think that is very important.
—There is nothing sinful about that.

—I am not talking about it being sinful. I am talking about a proposition that we have to put to people who do not understand the issue as the Democrats do. Quite clearly, they know what parliament is all about; I know what parliament is all about, but the people of Australia do not understand. It is very important, though, to understand that the public at large needs to be guided in this way before people exercise an intelligent vote at the referendum. Senator Gareth Evans is gabbling away to himself. I want him to listen to this.
—At least I am sober, Senator.
—Order! I ask the Attorney-General to withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw it, Mr Chairman.

—There is no need to be nasty. I would not want to insinuate anything about the honourable senator who has just made that statement. But I heard him say earlier that he supported Senator Lewis's amendment. I think that he was quite right in doing that. I do not know why he changed his mind. I suggest that it is in the interest of this Parliament to consider what I have said-that many people outside it do not really understand what Senator Chipp has said, but I think that on reflection--
—It is not only outside.
—I know that.
—I cannot understand what you have been talking about. I have been listening to you for five minutes. I have watched your hands waving around.

—The honourable senator wants to sit here for eight years, but the people outside this place do not want him to do that. It is very important to explain those things to the people before they vote in the referendum. I suggest that, on reflection, Senator Chipp might agree with the proposition that I am putting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a good deal of discussion on this matter. The matters that have just been raised by Senator Jessop are eminently relevant to this matter. How can the Government propose and how can this chamber accept a proposition to go to the people which deals with only five lines out of a Bill of 40 lines? That is what will be done. This proposition by the Government is to put to the people a proposal to alter the Constitution to extend the life of the Parliament from three years to four years. In fact, it does not even do that. Those five lines are to amend section 28 of the Constitution, to extend the duration of the House of Representatives from three to four years. The remaining 34 or 35 lines or so of the legislation deal with the extension of the terms of senators from six years to eight years. In other words, it would bring senators in Australia into line with senators in Brazil. I say that just as an aside; that is not in the legislation. But the remainder of the Bill, those 30-odd lines, is to amend the Constitution to extend the maximum term of senators from six years to eight years.

SPEECH.PARA: If this Committee refuses to accept the amendment that has been proposed by Senator Lewis and refined by me, it will not be putting to the people what is contained in this Bill. It will be practising a deception against the people. In a way, I hope that it does that, because that is the first point that some of us will start off with when writing the No case. Honourable senators should think about that.

Senator Lewis has said that the points that I have raised relating to his proposal are acceptable to him. In other words, my amendment simply picks up the technical point that is doubtful in his proposal, and that is, as he says, to extend the maximum terms of the members of the House of Representatives. I am suggesting that it ought to be to extend the maximum life of the House of Representatives. Some honourable senators were not present when I explained that the terms of members of the House of Representatives, under the proposition, can go for four years and 120 days. Naturally, Senator Lewis has accepted the refinement that I am suggesting. I shall not say anything more. I hope that the Committee passes what Senator Gareth Evans is proposing, because we will go out and say that it is just practising deception.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, Senator Lewis does not seem to be present at the moment. I have had no confirmation of his accepting that amendment.
—Yes, he had accepted it.
—That can be tested in a vote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —While we are waiting for Senator Lewis to return-I hope that someone will find him-I simply want to comment on the various amendments before the Committee. The Opposition, on behalf of which I am now speaking, as the Committee would know, has taken the firm view that the long title in the legislation proposing constitutional alterations should be the form of the questions put to the people. That is based on the fact that that is the legislation that has passed through the Parliament, and the Parliament presumably regards that as adequate, knowing that traditionally that has been the form of the question that has gone to the electors.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem that we face tonight is due to the Attorney-General, in his usual style, trying to be too clever by half in bringing down regulations to change that position. He has found that there are, perhaps, some doubts about it, and, for what other reason I do not know, he has now brought forward another amendment to the legislation for extending the benefits of the constitutional change in 1977 to the electors in the Territories. We are now considering different questions from those in the long title of the Bill. This debate is only revealing the difficulty that exists in that sort of exercise. The Senate is forming itself into a drafting committee, with numerous different views being put forward. The present proposal is in relation to the extension of the life of the Parliament from three years to four years; in other words, to change in the Constitution the figure '3' to the figure '4' for the House of Representatives, and to change the figure '6', which is the fixed term of Senators, as the Constitution provides, to a fixed term of eight years.

To paraphrase that in the way in which the Attorney-General proposes by saying that the proposal is to extend the maximum life of parliaments from three to four years, is quite dishonest. It is not a true statement at all about this proposal. The Opposition will support Senator Lewis's amendment. I understood that that amendment was foreshadowed to the Australian Democrats last night. There really should not be any doubt on the part of anyone on the Opposition side of the chamber about where the Opposition stands. Because some doubt has been raised as to where we stand, I have spoken in the debate simply to make that quite clear.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis, it has been suggested that you had accepted a rewording by Senator Harradine of your amendment. Is that correct?
—That is not so, Mr Chairman. My amendment is as I moved it. I am afraid that Senator Harradine will have to move his own amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since it has become apparent that the Opposition leadership has lost all control of its back bench members and that we will not get a vote on this matter tonight, I rise only to say this quickly, on the record: There is no attempt at deception and there never has been on the part of the Government on this matter. All that we have been doing is trying, in an honest way, to simplify the questions that are to be put to the Australian electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: I make one quick response to the rather peculiar arithmetic advanced by Senator Harradine to a hushed assembly a few minutes ago. The Bill is 60 lines long. Eight of those lines deal with the provision in the House of Representatives. Six of them deal specifically with the extension of the terms of senators and the remaining 46 lines deal with purely formal and transitional matters. It is a nonsensical illustration which I am afraid does not assist the cause of Senator Harradine's argument.
Consideration interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
The Chairman having reported accordingly-

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: RAAF Aircraft Accident-Importation of Russian Vehicles

PROCTEXT.PARA: RAAF Aircraft Accident-Importation of Russian Vehicles

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: — In the adjournment debate tonight I wish to raise only one item, and that briefly. Today a Royal Australian Air Force plane crashed in Victoria. The pilot, who was a personal friend of mine, an exceptional Australian, was killed. The point I wish to make is that many members of the armed forces day in and day out, not only during war time but also during peace time, risk their lives for this country and occasionally, as we have seen in the last few weeks, a number of them are killed. The pilot of the aircraft today, David Groves, was a Queenlander, with a family. He was going about normal service duties. Those duties eventually led today to his death. It seems to me that too often, in the words of the motto of the Returned Services League of Australia we do tend to forget the types of activities that are undertaken and the types of dangers that are faced by many Australians in defence of their country not only during war but also during peace. I wish today to pay tribute to this man.

—I feel that I should raise a matter as the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button, is still in the chamber. Some weeks ago I asked Senator Button a question relating to the importation of vehicles manufactured in the Soviet Union, component parts of which, according to reports emanating from Canada, are manufactured in slave labour camps in the Soviet Union. The Minister did say that he would obtain a response for me on this matter, and in particular in respect of the provisions of the Customs ( Prohibited Imports) Regulations. As yet that response has not come through and I am hoping that it will because it is important not only that the Customs ( Prohibited Imports) Regulations be upheld, particularly those parts prohibiting the import of materials and manufactured goods produced in slave labour camps or by slave labour anywhere outside this country, but also, from the point of view of the Minister's portfolio of Industry and Commerce, that the vehicle industry in this country can be assured that those vehicles are not being improperly imported into this country and are not being manufactured by non-union Gulag labour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall the question which Senator Harradine addressed to me some time ago and I apologise for not giving him an answer. Subsequent to the question being directed to me, I made inquiries from my Department and was told that it had no information about the matters which Senator Harradine raised. That does not mean that it would not be able to get information.
—From our Embassy in Moscow.
—There is no information to get. How can they get information that is not available? It does not exist.

—If Senator Georges will let me answer the question from my point of view, the Department informed me at that stage that it had no information about the matter. I do not advance that as a reason for not seeking to obtain information about it. I suggest to Senator Harradine that if he is able to give me the source of the information, which allegedly comes from Canada, that might be a useful avenue in order to obtain further information to enable us to provide a satisfactory anser to the question.
—I thought I gave you the reference but I may not have.

—With respect, the honourable senator did not. This is the first time I have heard Canada mentioned. I am not in any way seeking to resile from seeking an answer to the question. I have done that and the answer I have is that there is no information available at present. If Senator Harradine gives me a source through which I can start inquiries, I will certainly see that that is done.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.07 p.m.
